EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms developed in the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of June 6th. As this activity tracked east, a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls, thunderstorm wind gusts to 70 MPH and a brief tornado touchdown were reported. Heavy rain also fell leading to flash flooding in western Keith county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail predominately penny size with some quarter size hail mixed in.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the hail was penny to nickle sized with some ping pong ball size hail mixed in.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Vermont and northern NY influenced by heat ridge but just on the periphery, thus thunderstorm clusters riding over the ridge across Ontario/Quebec into VT/NY along the international border. Thunderstorms moved into VT/NY just around midnight on July 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees downed by thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Vermont and northern NY influenced by heat ridge but just on the periphery, thus thunderstorm clusters riding over the ridge across Ontario/Quebec into VT/NY along the international border. Thunderstorms moved into VT/NY just around midnight on July 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least half dozen trees downed or snapped along Route 109 between Waterville and Belvidere.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tornado briefly touched down in a field 5 miles northwest of Grant Nebraska. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of showers and thunderstorms moved through eastern Kentucky this day. One broken line of storms became strong to severe during the late afternoon and early evening as it progressed from Breathitt through Pike County. Isolated tree damage as well as structural damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of NWS employees reported trees blown down along Kentucky Highway 30 from northeast of Jackson to just southeast of Rousseau. Additionally, a shed was damaged from thunderstorm outflow winds near the Jackson Inn Motel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed this afternoon and evening across eastern Kentucky in the presence of numerous outflow boundaries. A cluster of storms, which developed west of Whitley City, became strong enough to produce minor damage as outflow winds blew through town.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Skywarn Spotter reported a portion of a roof of a commercial building blown off, along with a couple of carports being blown over, in Whitley City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of strong to severe thunderstorms developed across the Lake Cumberland region and Interstate 75 corridor late this afternoon and early evening ahead of an approaching upper level disturbance. Instability became great enough in order for these storms to briefly develop robust updrafts, which later descended thus leading to isolated wind damage across McCreary and Whitley Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported several trees knocked down along Bee Creek Road in Bark Camp.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement reported a couple of trees blown down just southeast of Turkey Creek and near South Williamson along Kentucky Highway 292.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level storm system moved across the Tennessee Valley from November 14 into November 15. Rain spreading across the region became a wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow across the far western and northwest counties of Middle Tennessee from the afternoon hours on November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Up to 1.5 inches of snow and 0.2 inches of ice were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow affected Perry County from the afternoon of November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. CoCoRaHS station Linden 7.9 NNW measured a total of 0.5 inches of snow.

Humphreys County Emergency Management reported around 0.13 inches of ice accumulation from freezing rain on elevated surfaces in Waverly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: River levels remained high across central and northern Iowa especially along the West Fork of the Des Moines River. Rainfall through early to mid May caused the river to go back into flood at Emmetsburg and Humboldt for a short period in mid May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fork of the Des Moines River at Emmetsburg crested at 11.15 feet on 13 May 2018 at 14:00 UTC.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled out boundary continued to linger across southern Iowa and northern Missouri for the third day/event in a row. South of the boundary, SBCAPE values were modest in around 2000 J/kg, however much of the action for Iowa was north of the boundary within an elevated MUCAPE environment of 2000+ J/kg. Add in lackluster effective bulk shear under 35 kts, and the result was predominantly storms with little residence time for consistent large hail development.  A number of storms produced sub-severe hail, but a couple did produce severe reports, including up to around golf ball sized hail in south-central Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported quarter sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: River levels remained high across central and northern Iowa especially along the West Fork of the Des Moines River. Rainfall through early to mid May caused the river to go back into flood at Emmetsburg and Humboldt for a short period in mid May.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fork of the Des Moines River at Humboldt crested at 10.63 feet on 16 May 2018 at 08:30 UTC.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: River levels remained high along the West Fork of the Des Moines River at Estherville and additional heavy rain toward the middle to end of May led to the river going back into flood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Fork of the Des Moines River at Estherville crested at 8.42 feet on 25 May 2018 at 17:15 UTC.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An energetic storm system moved from the Great Lakes across the St. Lawrence Valley into Ontario/Quebec during the afternoon and evening hours of May 4th. Instability was marginal for thunderstorm development during the afternoon and evening hours with thunderstorms ahead of a cold front. However, winds were unseasonably strong in the atmosphere, accounting for some thunderstorms to produce damaging winds and there was some localized damage in non-thunderstorm winds accompanying the arrival of  colder air.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half dollar sized hail reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving line of thunderstorms developed from mid to late this afternoon across central Kentucky. As this line progressed east into the Bluegrass region of eastern Kentucky, these storms increased in coverage as rainfall rates increased. This led to instances of flash flooding across portions of Bath and Montgomery Counties. These storms continued to move east into the evening hours, creating additional flash flooding from Morehead to west of Sandy Hook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management observed water flowing over Flemingsburg Road about four miles north of Morehead. Additionally, a local creek in Morehead quickly overspilled its banks, leading to water flowing down a local road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms once again developed this afternoon across southeastern and far eastern Kentucky with an upper level disturbance nearby. One of these storms briefly became strong enough to produce quarter sized hail in Harlan County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A citizen near Closplint reported quarter sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving line of thunderstorms developed from mid to late this afternoon across central Kentucky. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A citizen reported water flowing over a bridge on Aarons Run Road near Bunker Hill Road northwest of Judy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed this afternoon ahead of an upper level disturbance, bringing moisture from the Gulf of Mexico into eastern Kentucky. Isolated wind damage occurred in Laurel County as one storm initially grew very strong. Additional storms produced penny to nickel sized hail, while portions of northeast Letcher County experienced flash flooding due to persistent storms producing between 2-3 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A citizen reported penny sized hail near Payne Gap via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and thunderstorms developed this afternoon, extending into the evening ahead of an upper level disturbance. While storms were progressive in nature, continued development and repeated rounds of moderate to heavy rainfall over certain locations led to instances of flash flooding. The heavy rainfall also caused a mudslide which damaged a mobile home in Perry County. Additionally, a cloud to ground lightning strike near Somerset set a hay barn on fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media relayed a report of a hay barn set on fire by a lightning strike near Somerset.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving line of thunderstorms developed from mid to late this afternoon across central Kentucky. These storms continued to move east into the evening hours, creating additional flash flooding from Morehead to west of Sandy Hook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local Emergency Management reported water flowing over Kentucky Route 7 near Wells Creek Road southwest of Sandy Hook. Crews were called to rescue a dog stuck in high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms called a Quasi-linear Convective System (QLCS) developed across west Tennessee and moved eastward across Middle Tennessee during the late evening hours on Monday, November 5, 2018 into the early morning hours on Tuesday, November 6, 2018. This system spawned at least 10 tornadoes across Middle Tennessee that occurred in the darkness of night, including an EF-2 tornado that struck the Christiana area of Rutherford County, which unfortunately killed one woman and injured three others. Other tornadoes in this outbreak affected central Kentucky, northern and central Alabama, Mississippi and northern Louisiana. This tornado outbreak was the worst to affect Middle Tennessee since the December 23, 2015 tornado outbreak, which also occurred at night during the secondary severe weather season that occurs in the fall and early winter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down in the yard of a home at 2230 Old Snow Hill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions developed over parts of Central Texas by the first of February. Some of these locations missed out on beneficial rains which occurred across much of the region, allowing severe drought conditions to linger through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe (D2) drought conditions were ongoing at the beginning of February and continued through the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Grass fires burned approximately 500 acres in Roger Mills county on the 15th.
The Red Horse fire burned approximately 2549 acres in Woods county on the 18th.

A warm front lifted through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 6th. Surface temperatures across portions of West Virginia remained at or below freezing through mid morning while temperatures above the surface had already warmed above freezing. This resulted in a period of light freezing drizzle, with a light coating of ice across a narrow swath of central and western West Virginia.

An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Corona Public Library weather station reported sustained winds periodically between 40 mph and 48 mph for several consecutive hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in northwestern Cherry county during the early evening hours of June 8th. This activity developed along a stationary front which was anchored from northwestern Nebraska into east central Nebraska. As this activity pushed east along the front, a line of storms developed and tracked to the east southeast into portions of central Nebraska. Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to golf ball size hail reported at this location.

The heavy rainfall also caused a mudslide which damaged a mobile home in Perry County. Additionally, a cloud to ground lightning strike near Somerset set a hay barn on fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported flowing water covering the road on Lick Branch near the Kentucky Highway 437 bridge in Dingus. Near Moon, heavy rainfall caused water to quickly rise and inundate area basements.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure was prevalent over South Texas for most of the month of May. Well below normal rainfall occurred during the month. Severe drought developed over portions of the western Brush Country and over the Coastal Bend by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought developed over northern Goliad County toward the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: D2 (Severe) drought conditions continued across parts of eastern Missouri.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed this afternoon as upper level energy moved across eastern Kentucky. Numerous outflow boundaries helped to spawn additional thunderstorms, including one near Morehead. This storm slowly drifted toward the west, producing heavy rainfall of over 2 inches in and around Morehead. Additionally, gusty outflow winds up to 43 mph were recorded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media relayed a report of a downed tree near Morehead as gusty thunderstorm winds moved through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed across much of eastern Kentucky this afternoon as an upper level disturbance moved through. One of these storms produced penny sized hail in Cressy.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Cooperative Observer in Cressy observed penny sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms developed ahead of an upper level trough moving through the Pacific Northwest. Large hail and gusty winds were associated with these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Baker County Sheriff deputy reported quarter size hail 9 miles northwest of Baker City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud formed from a strong thunderstorm just east of Horse Thief Reservoir.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public sent a picture through social media of a funnel cloud near Horse Thief Reservoir.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low moved northeast out of California and spread strong to severe thunderstorms across Southeast Oregon and Southwest Idaho with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media post reported quarter size hail 6 miles south of Pueblo Mountain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low moved northeast out of California and spread strong to severe thunderstorms across Southeast Oregon and Southwest Idaho with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Harney County Dispatch reported trees and power lines down in Burns due to damaging thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water over LA 134 about 1/4 mile east of Swartz Fairbanks Road, Highway 554 in Perryville near the gravel pits, and Barnes Road. Reports from the Ouachita Parish Sherriff's Office Facebook page.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low moved northeast out of California and spread strong to severe thunderstorms across Southeast Oregon and Southwest Idaho with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported golf ball sized hail just north of New Meadows along U.S. Highway 95.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold moved east across the region firing off severe thunderstorms in South Central Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social Media reported half dollar sized hail around the Murtaugh area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level low moved northeast out of California and spread strong to severe thunderstorms across Southeast Oregon and Southwest Idaho with large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters south of Caldwell reported lime and half dollar sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms moved across South Texas as an upper level disturbance moved across south-central Texas. Severe storms produced wind damage in Three River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down across the city of Three Rivers. An abandoned building collapsed. The Boys and Girls Club building received roof damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms moved through the Brush Country into the Coastal Bend during the evening hours of the 20th. Wind gusts around 35 knots occurred between Corpus Christi Bay and Baffin Bay.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: TCOON site at South Bird Island measured a gust to 34 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep tropical moisture in place across the Florida peninsula allowed for the development of widespread showers and thunderstorms. Gusty winds were observed across portions of Tampa Bay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought mixed wintry precipitation to the region. Precipitation began as snow during the morning hours but changed to a mix of sleet, freezing rain and snow during the afternoon hours, mixing as far north as the town of Schenectady. Precipitation transitioned back to snow during the evening hours before exiting the region northwest to southeast. Snowfall and sleet totals ranged from 1 inch to 12 inches, with the higher totals generally north and west of the Greater Capital District.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms moved north through west central Florida on the morning of the 30th. One of the storms produced a brief tornado touchdown east of Arcadia, destroying a barn.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: DeSoto County emergency management reported a barn was destroyed by a brief tornado touchdown east of Arcadia. There were 5 antique cars in the barn at the time that were not damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of showers and thunderstorms moved onshore in the wake of Subtropical Storm Alberto. A couple of these storms produced marine thunderstorm wind gusts along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A WeatherFlow station on Egmont Key (XEGM) recorded a 34 knot thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell in northeastern Hillsborough county, with some sites reporting over 7 inches of rain. This led to street flooding along Highway 60 near Plant City, resulting in two vehicles ending up in the ditch and becoming partially submerged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed pictures of two vehicles in a flooded ditch along Highway 60 south of Plant City. The water was up to the hood of both cars. Nearby rain gauges reported as much as 7 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure strengthened over the area on May 28 and May 29 and resulted in widespread triple digit heat on the 29th as the main upper ridge axis moved over Central California. An upper trough pushed into Central California on the May 30 and May 31  displacing the high pressure area and bringing cooler temperatures along with windy conditions to the west side of the San Joaquin Valley on the 30th and over the Kern County Mountains and Deserts on the 31st. Several reporting stations on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley measured wind gusts exceeding 40 mph on the 30th and several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts measured gusts exceeding 50 mph on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS reported a peak wind gust of 64 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at MacDill Air Force Base measured a wind gust of 36 knots...41 mph.

CZ_NAME: ENGLEWOOD TO TARPON SPRINGS FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of showers and thunderstorms moved onshore in the wake of Subtropical Storm Alberto. A couple of these storms produced marine thunderstorm wind gusts along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A home weather station in the northwestern corner of Pinellas County (EW7468) recorded a 36 knot thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and potent winter storm crossed western and central Wyoming and brought heavy snow and high wind to many locations. Strong winds occurred ahead of the storm in portions of central Wyoming, with some of the strongest gusts were 78 mph at Fales Rock and 75 mph along Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper. Following that, heavy snow fell. Over a foot of new snow fell in portions of the Tetons, Absarokas and Casper Mountain as well as in Yellowstone Park. In the lower elevations, the heaviest snow fell around Casper where up to 15 inches was measured. Other areas with over 6 inches included around Rock Springs, northern Big Horn County and around Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in portions of Yellowstone Park. The heaviest amount was 14 inches at the Canyon SNOTEL site and at the Old Faithful Ranger Station.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in association with an upper level disturbance moving through the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The spring breakup of the river ice on the Kuskokwim River resulted in several ice jams along the river that impacted multiple communities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As the spring river ice breakup front moved downstream on the Kuskokwim River, an ice jam formed downstream of the villages of Upper Kalskag and Lower Kalskag. The road connecting the two villages was flooded and impassable. Access to the shared power plant was also cut off. Many yards had floodwaters affecting them.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The spring breakup of the river ice on the Kuskokwim River resulted in several ice jams along the river that impacted multiple communities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As the spring river ice breakup front moved downstream on the Kuskokwim River, an ice jam formed downstream of the village of Tuluksak. Reports were received of water levels rising rapidly into the lower portions of the village, and the community prepared for more substantial evacuations. Thankfully, the water levels began to slowly fall as the ice jam released slowly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The spring breakup of the river ice on the Kuskokwim River resulted in several ice jams along the river that impacted multiple communities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: As the spring river ice breakup front moved downstream on the Kuskokwim River, an ice jam formed near Birch Crossing, downstream of Aniak. Water levels rose steadily in Aniak and began to flood the low-lying areas of town with up to 6 ft depths of water. The most significantly impacted areas were the gravel pit outside of town, and the barge landing downstream of the main town. Eventually the ice jam released and water levels steadily dropped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful coastal storm impacted the region Friday through Sunday with North to Northeast Gale to Storm force winds. This resulted in several tidal cycle of minor to moderate coastal flooding Friday morning through Sunday morning, with the most widespread moderate to locally major impacts occurring with the Saturday Night high tidal cycle. In addition, prolonged high surf from energetic easterly swells during this time period resulted in widespread areas of dune erosion and localized washovers along the Atlantic Ocean beachfront.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS tidal gauge in Hudson Bay at Freeport recorded a peak water level of 6.5 ft. MLLW at 930 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 6.2 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 918 to 1018 am EST. The USGS tidal gauge in Reynolds Channel recorded a peak water level of 6.8 ft. MLLW at 930 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 6.8 ft. MLLW was touched from 912 to 942 am EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall fell during the month of March 2018, with very little snowfall as well. This led to severe drought conditions spreading across most of the area, with some areas of south central Kansas now moving into extreme drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened during the month of March, 2018. By the end of the month the county had climbed into the extreme drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Rhode Island was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms moving east from Connecticut produced damaging wind gusts in Western Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 5:13 PM EST, a large tree was blocking North Road in Hopkinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Connecticut was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts, large hail, and heavy downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:40 PM EST trees and wires were reported down on Springfield Road at Turnpike Road in Somers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure located over Iowa.  Northwest winds on the western and southwest side of the low, produced wind of 50 to 60 mph across portions of central and south central Kansas during the daytime hours of March 6th, 2018.  The strongest wind gust was reported near the Russell airport of 61 mph.

An early spring snow storm occurred from the evening of March 23rd into the evening of March 24th.  This system brought heavy wet snow to much of northwest Illinois.   A very sharp cutoff of snowfall was seen with this system.  Snowfall totals between 2 and 8 inches were common, with the heaviest snow of 6 to a nearly 14 inches falling in a 30 mile wide line from LeClaire IA, to Anamosa, to East Of Princeton, IL.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of a trace to 9 inches of snow were reported across the county ranging from near 4 inches in the far south to about 6 inches around Thomson IL.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early spring snow storm occurred from the evening of March 23rd into the evening of March 24th.  This system brought heavy wet snow to much of northwest Illinois.   A very sharp cutoff of snowfall was seen with this system.  Snowfall totals between 2 and 8 inches were common, with the heaviest snow of 6 to a nearly 14 inches falling in a 30 mile wide line from LeClaire IA, to Anamosa, to East Of Princeton, IL.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of less than 3 to nearly 7 inches of snow were reported across the county ranging from less than 3 inches in the far northeast around La Moille Illinois to almost 7 inches around Neponset Illinois.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area over the Great Lakes the morning of May 4th moved to the Maritimes the morning of May 5th.  As it moved, the low swung a cold front west to east through Massachusetts shortly before midnight.  Winds behind the front became west to northwest and produced gusts near 50 mph overnight.  The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 10:38 PM EST on May 4th, a tree was down on Groton Road at Farmer Way.  At 11:36 PM EST, a tree and wires were down along Glendale Avenue in Tyngsborough.  At 12:15 AM EST on May 5th, a tree and wires were down along Dadant Drive in Wilmington. At 1:02 AM EST a tree was down across State Route 30 and Candleberry Lane in Weston.  At 1:40 AM EST a tree was down on Dunstable Road in Chelmsford.  At 1:55 AM EST a tree was blocking Great Road in Stow.  At 1:56 AM EST an amateur radio operator in Westford reported a wind gust to 50 mph.  At 2:35 AM EST a large tree was down across Newfield Drive in Natick.  At 2:35 AM EST a tree was partly blocking East Street in Tewksbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area over the Great Lakes the morning of May 4th moved to the Maritimes the morning of May 5th.  As it moved, the low swung a cold front west to east through Massachusetts shortly before midnight.  Winds behind the front became west to northwest and produced gusts near 50 mph overnight.  The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:28 PM EST on May 4th, a tree was down on Davis Street in Plymouth.

The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:37 PM EST on May 4th, a tree was down on Conant Street in Danvers.  At 11:50 PM EST a large tree and wires were down on Euclid Avenue in Marblehead.  At 11:53 PM EST, the Automated Surface Observing System at Beverly Municipal Airport measured a wind gust to 47 mph. At 1:55 AM EST on May 5th, a large tree was down across Sylvan Street in Danvers.  At 2:55 PM EST a large tree was down on Beacon Street near Whittier Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area over the Great Lakes the morning of May 4th moved to the Maritimes the morning of May 5th.  As it moved, the low swung a cold front west to east through Massachusetts shortly before midnight.  Winds behind the front became west to northwest and produced gusts near 50 mph overnight.  The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 11:48 PM EST on May 4th, a tree was down on High Street at Flint Circle.  At 1:07 AM EST on May 5th, the Automated Surface Observing System at Lawrence Municipal Airport measured a wind gust to 51 mph. At 1:30 AM EST a tree was blocking Broadway in Lawrence.  At 2:07 AM EST a tree was down on wires on Warren Avenue in Amesbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area over the Great Lakes the morning of May 4th moved to the Maritimes the morning of May 5th.  As it moved, the low swung a cold front west to east through Massachusetts shortly before midnight.  Winds behind the front became west to northwest and produced gusts near 50 mph overnight.  The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1:15 AM EST on May 5th, a tree was down on a house on Highland Avenue in Needham. At 2 AM EST a large pine tree and wires were down on South Grove Street in Foxborough. At 2:05 AM EST a tree and wires were down on Village Gate Road in Canton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful coastal storm impacted the region Friday through Sunday with North to Northeast Gale to Storm force winds. This resulted in several tidal cycle of minor to moderate coastal flooding Friday morning through Sunday morning, with the most widespread moderate to locally major impacts occurring with the Saturday Night high tidal cycle. In addition, prolonged high surf from energetic easterly swells during this time period resulted in widespread areas of dune erosion and localized washovers along the Atlantic Ocean beachfront.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS tidal gauge in Glen Cove recorded a peak water level of 11.0 ft. MLLW at 1200 pm EST. This was 1 tenth of a foot shy of the moderate coastal flood threshold of 11.1 ft. MLLW. The NOS tidal gauge at King Point recorded a peak water level of 11.1 ft. MLLW at 1224 pm EST. This exceeded the moderate coastal flood threshold of 10.5 ft. MLLW between 10am to 106 pm. EST. 3 to 5 ft wave action resulted in locally moderate coastal impacts across vulnerable Northern Nassau county shoreline locales during the Friday afternoon high tide.

As it moved, the low swung a cold front west to east through Massachusetts shortly before midnight.  Winds behind the front became west to northwest and produced gusts near 50 mph overnight.  The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2:40 AM EST on May 5th, a large tree was down on wires on Seven Mile River Drive in Attleboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Rhode Island was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms moving east from Connecticut produced damaging wind gusts in Western Rhode Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 5:10 PM EST, a tree was reported down on a house on Pin Oak Court in Coventry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area over the Great Lakes the morning of May 4th moved to the Maritimes the morning of May 5th.  As it moved, the low swung a cold front west to east through Massachusetts shortly before midnight.  Winds behind the front became west to northwest and produced gusts near 50 mph overnight.  The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 10:05 PM EST on May 4th, a street light was brought down on Dana Avenue at the Truman Parkway in Boston. At 12:37 AM on May 5th, an amateur radio operator in Boston reported a wind gust to 52 mph.  At 3:05 AM EST, a tree was down on power lines on Corey Road in Boston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area over the Great Lakes the morning of May 4th moved to the Maritimes the morning of May 5th. The winds then diminished by sunrise on May 5th.

At 10:24 PM EST a tree was down on power lines and blocking West Princeton Road in Westminster.  At 12:20 AM on May 5th, a tree was down on a house and cars on Onset Street in Worcester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful coastal storm impacted the region Friday through Sunday with North to Northeast Gale to Storm force winds. This resulted in several tidal cycle of minor to moderate coastal flooding Friday morning through Sunday morning, with the most widespread moderate to locally major impacts occurring with the Saturday Night high tidal cycle. In addition, prolonged high surf from energetic easterly swells during this time period resulted in widespread areas of dune erosion and localized washovers along the Atlantic Ocean beachfront.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS tidal gauge in Hudson Bay at Freeport recorded a peak water level of 7.0 ft. MLLW at 954 pm EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 6.2 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 812 to 1106 pm EST, and the major coastal flood threshold of 6.9 ft MLLW was exceeded from 912 to 1012 pm EST. The USGS tidal gauge in Reynolds Channel recorded a peak water level of 7.2 ft. MLLW at 942 pm EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 6.8 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 830 to 1036 pm EST. The USGS tidal gauge in East Rockaway recorded a peak water level of 7.3 ft. MLLW at 936 pm EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 7.0 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 842 to 1024 pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow on the 17th with rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were followed by strong winds the evening of the 17th into 18th. Snowfall totals of 12 to 18 inches were common along with wind gust of 35 to 45 mph.  Severe driving conditions were widespread.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow on the 17th was followed by snow and gusty winds late on the 17th into the 18th leading to periods of severe driving conditions.  Snow amounts of 8 to 12 inches were common with 18 inches at Marion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy bursts of snow with amounts around 12 inches were common leading to difficult travel over area mountain passes. The highway department noted that it was difficult to keep up with snow rates near Lolo Pass late on the 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and potent winter storm crossed western and central Wyoming and brought heavy snow and high wind to many locations. Strong winds occurred ahead of the storm in portions of central Wyoming, with some of the strongest gusts were 78 mph at Fales Rock and 75 mph along Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper. Following that, heavy snow fell. Over a foot of new snow fell in portions of the Tetons, Absarokas and Casper Mountain as well as in Yellowstone Park. In the lower elevations, the heaviest snow fell around Casper where up to 15 inches was measured. Other areas with over 6 inches included around Rock Springs, northern Big Horn County and around Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in portions of the Tetons. The highest amount was 15 inches at the top of the Jackson Hole Ski Resort.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and potent winter storm crossed western and central Wyoming and brought heavy snow and high wind to many locations. Strong winds occurred ahead of the storm in portions of central Wyoming, with some of the strongest gusts were 78 mph at Fales Rock and 75 mph along Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper. Following that, heavy snow fell. Over a foot of new snow fell in portions of the Tetons, Absarokas and Casper Mountain as well as in Yellowstone Park. In the lower elevations, the heaviest snow fell around Casper where up to 15 inches was measured. Other areas with over 6 inches included around Rock Springs, northern Big Horn County and around Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in portions of the Absarokas. The heaviest snow fell at the Beartooth Lake SNOTEL site where 15 inches of new snow was recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy upslope snow fell on the 24th into the 25th with some heavier snow banding late on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of 12 to 20 inches were common from the weekend storm with reports of over 2 feet at Elk River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy upslope snow fell on the 24th into the 25th with some heavier snow banding late on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour were observed on U.S. Highway 12 between Lowell and Bald Mountain with general amounts of at least a foot. Heavy snowfall made travel difficult.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving area of low pressure passed south of Pennsylvania during the evening of Saturday, February 17 and brought a quick period of moderate to heavy snow across south-central Pennsylvania. Snowfall rates of 1-2+ per hour were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced 6 to 7 inches of snow in a 12 hour period across Juniata County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Connecticut was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts, large hail, and heavy downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:45 PM EST, a tree and wires were down on Buckley Highway in Union.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Connecticut was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts, large hail, and heavy downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 3:45 PM EST numerous trees were reported down on Old Farms Road near Tollgale Lane, Holcomb Street at Cardinal Road, and Barndoor Hills Road at Firetown Road.  A single tree was down across Richard Road.

In addition, prolonged high surf from energetic easterly swells during this time period resulted in widespread areas of dune erosion and localized washovers along the Atlantic Ocean beachfront.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A COOP observer, CoCoRaHS observers, and the public reported 3 to 5.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, CoCoRaHS observers, and the public reported 5 to 10.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio, trained spotters, and CoCoRaHS observers reported 2 to 5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fox River near New Munster reached moderate flood stage, cresting at 13.37 feet. Floodwaters are into the lower levels of some homes along Riverside Dr. and Shorewood Dr. in the Village of Salem Lakes. A portion of 77th St. in the Town of Wheatland in flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southern Connecticut. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearby CoCoRaHS observers in southern New London County reported 2 to 4 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southern Connecticut. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers reported 2 to 4 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southern Connecticut. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A COOP observer, CoCoRaHS observers, and a trained spotter reported 3 to 6 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station in Larchmont Harbor reported a gust to 66 mph at 341 pm. The ASOS at Westchester Airport measured a 64 mph wind gust at 229 pm. At 204 pm in the city of Yonkers, the Department of Highways reported a downed tree on the Sprain Brook Parway northbound north of Tuckahoe Road. In Scarsdale, a tree fell onto the Sprain Brook Parkway southbound north of Jackson Avenue at 224 pm. The media reported trees and wires down in Bronxville around 220 pm. A trained spotter reported 2 trees down, blocking Bryant Avenue and Mamaroneck Avenue, which resulted in wires down and power outages across the area in the city of White Plains at 309 pm.  Around 415 pm in Maplewood, a tree was reported down per social media on New Wilmot Road at the Iona Prep entrance. The downed tree took down traffic lights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1228 and 1232 pm, the ASOS at JFK International Airport measured a wind gust to 63 mph. Sustained winds of 48 mph were observed at 1235 pm at JFK. Around 2 pm, the public reported a tree down on multiple cars on Homeland Street in Jamaica Estates. At 349 pm in Jamaica, a tree fell onto a car at CUNY York Campus resulting in an injury per the broadcast media. The ASOS at JFK International airport measured a wind gust to 64 mph at 440 pm. Then, a gust to 67 mph was measured at 527 pm at JFK. Per social media, trees and power lines were downed at 935 pm in Jamaica on Tudor Road near surrey Place.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of winter storms impacted the Great Basin producing widespread light to moderate snowfall. Localized heavy snow occurred in Winnemucca and Golconda Summit, where 11-16 inches of snow was observed. Additionally, heavy snow fell across southern Lander and Eureka Counties. Snow amounts observed were 11-14 inches in Austin and Eureka. The heaviest snow fell from March 14th to 15th in central Nevada, and March 16th to 17th for northwestern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of heavy snow developed across southern Lander and Eureka Counties during the morning and afternoon of March 14th. Snow continued in southern Lander county into the 15th. Austin received 6.5 inches, with a two day total of 10 inches. Eureka picked up 7.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada. Some of the heavier snowfall amounts included 10 to 20 inches in Spring Creek and Lamoille, 14-17 inches in Eureka, and 7 inches in Ely. In addition, high winds gusting to 65 mph with the storm caused some property damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow was reported over much of the area. Spring Creek and Lamoille reported between 10 and 20 inches, and 6 to 8 inches were reported in Elko and Carlin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada. Some of the heavier snowfall amounts included 10 to 20 inches in Spring Creek and Lamoille, 14-17 inches in Eureka, and 7 inches in Ely. In addition, high winds gusting to 65 mph with the storm caused some property damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Elko Daily Press reports a snowmobiler was injured by driving into an earlier avalanche in Lamoille Canyon Sunday evening. Heavy snow fell over the previous two days in the Ruby Mountains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area passing east across Iowa and IL spread snow across southern WI during the afternoon and evening. 1 to 4 inches of powdery snow accumulation occurred with the highest amounts near the IL border. Some schools closed early west and south of Madison. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around one inch of powdery snow. Snow covered roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area passing east across Iowa and IL spread snow across southern WI during the afternoon and evening. 1 to 4 inches of powdery snow accumulation occurred with the highest amounts near the IL border. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Westchester Airport, a gust to 64 was reported at 229 pm. The Department of Highways reported downed wires and a power pole on NY100 at 837 am. All lanes were closed. Around 946 am, a tree was knocked doen in Sleepy Hollow on US 9 southbound. At 120 pm, a large tree fell onto a house in Ossining. The broadcast media reported wires down and burning in Tarrytown at 220 pm. The media also reported multiple tractor trailers were overturned on the Governor Mario Cuomo bridge at 236 pm. Estimated wind gusts over the bridge were between 70 and 80 MPH. At 440 pm in the town of Shrub Oak, multiple trees were knocked down onto power lines across town. A personal weather station measured a 55 mph gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early spring snow storm occurred from the evening of March 23rd into the evening of March 24th.  This system brought heavy wet snow to much of eastern Iowa.   A very sharp cutoff of snowfall was seen with this system.  Snowfall totals between 2 and 8 inches were common, with the heaviest snow of 8 to a near record 14 inches falling in a 30 mile wide line from Waterloo, to Anamosa, to Clinton, IA for this late in the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of 9 to nearly 14 inches of snow were reported across the county ranging from about 9 inches in the southeast to nearly 14 inches around Wyoming Iowa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weeks with little or no rain and dry air, with rainfall totals at 10 to 25 percent of average (average for the period in the area is approximately 3 inches), deteriorated drought conditions to severe (D2) across the ranchlands of extreme southeastern Brooks and extreme southwestern Kenedy County by March 27th. A burst of locally heavy rainfall on the late evening of the 28th and early morning of the 29th would improve conditions at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weeks of little to no rainfall, leaving departures from monthly averages (January and February through mid March) at 10 to 25 percent of the 3 inch or so average for the period, resulted in a brief period of Severe (D2) Drought in southeastern Brooks County during the final few days of March. A band of heavier rainfall from late evening on the 28th through early morning of the 29th would improve conditions for the start of April.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds behind a trough of low pressure or Pacific front occurred across the western half of the area during the morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed at a location 4 miles northeast of Hayne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding of lowland and agricultural land including some roads. Highway 83 was closed for a time between County Highway CW and the Waukesha and Washington County border. Two homes were threatened by high waters within the Wambold Channel in the Town of Eagle. One home sustained minor flood damage. The high water within the channel was due to high water downstream in Jericho Creek backing up into the channel. A couple roads near Jericho Creek and the Mukwonago River were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station measured a 65 mph wind gust at 745 pm at Great Gull Island. A trained spotter measured a 58 mph wind gust in Orient at 525 pm. At 7 pm, a trained spotter reported a tree down causing wires to come down in the town of Orient.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred behind a deepening area of low pressure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1153 am, a trained spotter reported a tree down in Scotch Plains. The tree was blocking all lanes on US Route 22 due to persistently gusty northwest winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 1 to 3 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rip related rescues occurred at both North Myrtle Beach and Wrightsville Beach.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were ten rip related rescues at North Myrtle Beach. There were also three rip related rescues at Wrightsville Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough extending from Tropical Storm Alberto produced heavy rain and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was several feet of water in the Inlet Square Mall Parking lot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One of few upper level disturbances to cross south Texas and the Rio Grande Valley in spring 2018 did so late on March 28th, creating welcome rainfall for parts of the region where drought had worsened.  Starr County, which had seem some late winter rainfall to keep drought at bay, was hit again - this time with local hailstorms across the eastern half of the county.  Large hail up to golfball size was reported around Rio Grande City and points east just after 7 PM.  Other hailstorms formed in southeast Jim Hogg County, as well as northern and northeastern Zapata County later that evening, but there were no reports available as of this writing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Facebook reports relayed to the NWS office in Brownsville reported two large hail reports east of Rio Grande City: Golfball sized hail 4.6 miles east, near La Puerta, and half-dollar sized hail (1.25) 4 miles east southeast of Rio Grande City near Los Velas road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful coastal storm impacted the region Friday through Sunday with North to Northeast Gale to Storm force winds. This resulted in several tidal cycle of minor to moderate coastal flooding Friday morning through Sunday morning, with the most widespread moderate to locally major impacts occurring with the Saturday Night high tidal cycle. In addition, prolonged high surf from energetic easterly swells during this time period resulted in widespread areas of dune erosion and localized washovers along the Atlantic Ocean beachfront.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS tidal gauge in Hudson Bay at Freeport recorded a peak water level of 6.7 ft. MLLW at 1006 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 6.2 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 842 to 1100 am EST. The USGS tidal gauge in Reynolds Channel recorded a peak water level of 6.9 ft. MLLW at 948 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 6.8 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 924 to 1018 am EST. The USGS tidal gauge in East Rockaway recorded a peak water level of 7.0 ft. MLLW at 1006 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 7.0 ft. MLLW was touched from 954 to 1012 am EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful coastal storm impacted the region Friday through Sunday with North to Northeast Gale to Storm force winds. This resulted in several tidal cycle of minor to moderate coastal flooding Friday morning through Sunday morning, with the most widespread moderate to locally major impacts occurring with the Saturday Night high tidal cycle. In addition, prolonged high surf from energetic easterly swells during this time period resulted in widespread areas of dune erosion and localized washovers along the Atlantic Ocean beachfront.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS tidal gauge in Lindenhurst recorded a peak water level of 3.8 ft. MLLW at 1142 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 3.6 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 1042am-1242am EST. The USGS tidal gauge in West Sayville recorded a peak water level of 3.7 ft. MLLW at 1206 pm EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 3.5 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 1048am-112pm EST. The USGS tidal gauge in Watch Hill Fire Island recorded a peak water level of 3.7 ft. MLLW at 1154 am EST. The moderate coastal flood threshold of 3.6 ft. MLLW was exceeded from 1106am-1236pm EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to heavy snow bands moved across Long Island and New York City with lighter snow across the Lower Hudson Valley. The heaviest snow occurred in New York City and Long Island Wednesday night into early Thursday morning. The highest snowfall rates occurred on Long Island with generally 2 to 4 inches per hour at times. The NWS official observation at the Islip Airport indicated a snowfall rate of 5 inches per hour between 9pm and 10pm on March 21st with around 9 inches of snow falling from 8pm to 10pm. Within these heavier bands, near-blizzard conditions occurred with visibilities one quarter mile or less and winds gusting 30 to 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Official NWS Observation at Islip Airport was 18.4 inches of snow. The FAA Contract Observer at the Airport reported snowfall rates 2 to 4 inches per hour during the night of March 21st with a one hour rate of 5 inches. NWS Employees reported similar snowfall rates in Ronkonkoma, Patchogue, and Sayville. Snowfall amounts ranged from 9 to 20 inches across Southwest Suffolk as reported by NWS Employees, trained spotters, social media, and the public. Near-blizzard conditions occurred with visibility falling below one quarter mile at times and winds gusting 30 to 35 mph during the highest snowfall rates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local media reported a scaffolding collapse on Broome Street between Clinton and Ridge streets in the lower east side of Manhattan. This occurred around 245 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 5 pm, a large tree was uprooted and knocked down across multiple properties causing property damage in the Flatlands section of Kings. This was via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Per social media, a tree was knocked down on Henrey Hudson Parkway at 236 Street in Didgewood around 530 pm. This report was courtesy of the New York city Transit buses twitter account.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers and trained spotters reported 11 to 20 inches of snowfall. Significant tree damage was reported across eastern Passaic county due to heavy wet snow and strong winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 19 to 22 inches of snowfall. Significant tree damage was reported across western Passaic county due to heavy wet snow and strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep low pressure located over Iowa.  Northwest winds on the western and southwest side of the low, produced wind of 50 to 60 mph across portions of central and south central Kansas during the daytime hours of March 6th, 2018.  The strongest wind gust was reported near the Russell airport of 61 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be between 50 and 60 mph.

A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada. Some of the heavier snowfall amounts included 10 to 20 inches in Spring Creek and Lamoille, 14-17 inches in Eureka, and 7 inches in Ely. In addition, high winds gusting to 65 mph with the storm caused some property damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long Hollow RAWS site measured a wind gust to 63 MPH. Strong winds also impacted Owyhee, with estimated wind gusts of 55 to 65 MPH. Power lines were reported down with scattered power outages in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weeks with little or no rain and dry air, with rainfall totals at 10 to 25 percent of average (average for the period in the area is approximately 3 inches), deteriorated drought conditions to severe (D2) across the ranchlands of extreme southeastern Brooks and extreme southwestern Kenedy County by March 27th. A burst of locally heavy rainfall on the late evening of the 28th and early morning of the 29th would improve conditions at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weeks of little to no rainfall, leaving departures from monthly averages (January and February through mid March) at 10 to 25 percent of the 3 inch or so average for the period, resulted in a brief period of Severe (D2) Drought in extreme southwestern Kenedy County during the final few days of March. A band of heavier rainfall from late evening on the 28th through early morning of the 29th would improve conditions for the start of April.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early spring snow storm occurred from the evening of March 23rd into the evening of March 24th.  This system brought heavy wet snow to much of eastern Iowa.   A very sharp cutoff of snowfall was seen with this system.  Snowfall totals between 2 and 8 inches were common, with the heaviest snow of 8 to a near record 14 inches falling in a 30 mile wide line from Waterloo, to Anamosa, to Clinton, IA for this late in the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of 9 to 11.3 inches of snow were reported across the county ranging from near 9 inches in the southeast to 11.3 inches around Independence Iowa.

A cold front over the Great Lakes moved through Southern New England during the late afternoon and early night of May 15th.  The air mass over Connecticut was very warm and humid, and as the cold front moved into this air it generated numerous thunderstorms. Some thunderstorms produced damaging wind gusts, large hail, and heavy downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 4:35 PM EST a tree and wires were down on Birchwood Heights Road in Mansfield.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL WATERS FROM BAFFIN BAY TO PT MANSFIELD TX OUT 20 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This is a test.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two men were rescued by the U.S. Coast Guard after their 21-foot fishing boat capsized (as reported by local TV media). One man showed signs of hypothermia, and the other was face-down with no pulse but revived with CPR. Both were airlifted to a local hospital. The exact cause of the capsize was unknown, though combined seas had built to nearly 8 feet with a swell period from the east of 9 seconds. Note: Time of the incident was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers, trained spotters, an emergency manager, and broadcast media reported 6 to 11 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked   close enough to eastern Long Island to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018.  Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times in the morning across eastern Long Island. A deep upper level trough over the northeast also aided in bringing lighter snow over the Lower Hudson Valley and portions of New York City, despite the low pressure tracking several hundred miles off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS and the public reported 2 to 4 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to portions of northern and central Nevada. Some of the heavier snowfall amounts included 10 to 20 inches in Spring Creek and Lamoille, 14-17 inches in Eureka, and 7 inches in Ely. In addition, high winds gusting to 65 mph with the storm caused some property damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant snow fell across northern Elko County, with the heaviest snow observed in the mountains and along State Route 225 from Adobe Summit through Owyhee. Montello also received significant snowfall in the eastern portion of the zone. Widespread 7 to 12 inches of snow fell in the valley locations, with 10-15 inches in the mountains. The snow was particularly heavy in Owyhee, where a frontal band stalled creating snowfall rates in excess of 1-2 inches per/hr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic during the early morning hours on March 2, 2018. The low moved slowly off the coast and became nearly stationary near the 40N/70W benchmark. The storm brought winter storm conditions to portions of the Lower Hudson Valley, especially in the higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county saw generally to 3 to 5 inches of snow, but there were isolated higher amounts at elevated locations. A CoCoRaHS observer reported 10.3 inches of snow three miles north of Fahnestock State Park. The public reported 7.6 inches of snow in Mahopac. The broadcast media reported one fatality due to the strong winds. An 11 year old boy was killed when a tree was knocked down onto a house at 1215 pm in Putnam Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Bridgeport Sikorsky Airport measure a 62 mph wind gust at 1028 am. The Broadcast media reported one fatality due to a downed tree onto a car near the Stamford, Greenwich line at 335 pm. At 4 pm in the town of New Canaan, one person was injured from a downed tree onto a vehicle. At 530 pm, a portion of a roof was blown off due to the high winds on an apartment building. The building was located on Myrtle Avenue in Stamford per social media reports. Around 3 pm in Stamford, a section of a roof was torn off an apartment building on Myrtle Avenue per social media reports. At the same time, one person was injured in the town of New Cannaan due to another downed tree onto a pickup truck on Canoe Hill Road. The driver was rescued by first responders.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 651 am, a trained spotter reported a tree down at 9W and Treack Road in Nyack. In Tappan at 1117 am, the Department of Highways reported a tree down on the Palisades Parkway, southbound south of NY 303. The broadcast media reported a downed tree blocking Route 9 West at Main Street and Hastings Lane in Stony Point at 1220 pm. Later in the day, at 535 pm, broadcast media reported a tree down on a house and car on School street in Upper Nyack. Power was knocked out in the neighborhood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of winter storms impacted the Great Basin producing widespread light to moderate snowfall. Localized heavy snow occurred in Winnemucca and Golconda Summit, where 11-16 inches of snow was observed. Additionally, heavy snow fell across southern Lander and Eureka Counties. Snow amounts observed were 11-14 inches in Austin and Eureka. The heaviest snow fell from March 14th to 15th in central Nevada, and March 16th to 17th for northwestern Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very localized heavy snow band formed and remained stationary over extreme southeast Humboldt County, including Golconda Summit and the town of Winnemucca. Significant localized snow amounts ranged from 11 inches around Winnemucca to 16 inches near Golconda Summit. This was a historic snow event for Winnemucca, breaking snowfall records.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to occasionally heavy snow bands moved across portions of northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 6 to 10 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to occasionally heavy snow bands moved across portions of northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 6.6 inches of snow in Bloomfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to occasionally heavy snow bands moved across portions of northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 6 to 7 inches of snow, but the snow occurred in over 12 hours not meeting NWS criteria for warning level snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure passed by to the south on the 20th. At the same time, high pressure was building to the north and this caused cold air to filter in from New England. Rain changed to a wintry mix on the 20th. There was enough cold air for a period of heavier snow around midday.  A light wintry mix continued on the night of the 20th. Coastal low pressure developed along the Mid-Atlantic Coast on the morning of the 21st. This caused a round of heavier precipitation to fall mainly in the form of snow. The snow tapered off later in the day as the low moved off to the north and east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix occurred on the 20th before a round of heavier snow developed on the 21st. Snowfall totaled up to 4.6 inches at Bayard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving eastward from the central United States on Thursday March 1st, intensified rapidly as it moved offshore Thursday night and early Friday, deepening to 974 mb by the evening of Friday March 2nd.||Strong winds were present in the low levels of the atmosphere due to the strengthening pressure gradient, and were able to mix down to the surface in strong wind gusts under northwest flow cold air advection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 61 mph was reported at the Hagerstown Regional Airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 60 mph as reported at Frosburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure area passing east across Iowa and IL spread snow across southern WI during the afternoon and evening. 1 to 4 inches of powdery snow accumulation occurred with the highest amounts near the IL border. Some schools closed early west and south of Madison. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two inches of powdery snow. Snow covered roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The NS149 and Highway 3 Wildfire began around 1522CST about nine miles north northwest of Logan Oklahoma in Beaver County. The wildfire consumed approximately two thousand acres. There was a report that one home was destroyed by the wildfire, however there were no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were also no reports of any other home or structures threatened. There were a total of fifteen fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire. The wildfire was contained around 1900CST.

The Airport Wildfire began around 1300CST about two miles north of Borger Texas in Hutchinson County near the Hutchinson County Airport. The wildfire consumed approximately one thousand acres. There were no reports of any homes or other structures threatened, damaged or destroyed by the wildfire. There was a report of one injury however no fatalities were reported. There were a total of nine fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The wildfire was contained around 0100CST on March 24.

A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to heavy snow bands moved across Long Island and New York City with lighter snow across the Lower Hudson Valley. The heaviest snow occurred in New York City and Long Island Wednesday night into early Thursday morning. The highest snowfall rates occurred on Long Island with generally 2 to 4 inches per hour at times. The NWS official observation at the Islip Airport indicated a snowfall rate of 5 inches per hour between 9pm and 10pm on March 21st with around 9 inches of snow falling from 8pm to 10pm. Within these heavier bands, near-blizzard conditions occurred with visibilities one quarter mile or less and winds gusting 30 to 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, social media, and the FAA Contract Observer at John F. Kennedy Airport reported 8 to 15 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall fell during the month of March 2018, with very little snowfall as well. This led to severe drought conditions spreading across most of the area, with some areas of south central Kansas now moving into extreme drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued during the month of March, 2018. Most of the county remained in the severe drought category.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of powdery snow. Snow covered roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of abnormal dryness, dry fine and medium fuels, a near flash drought day that preceded it, and near critical humidity with gusty east winds aided the development of wildfire on the Santa Ana NWR along the Rio Grande in southern Hidalgo County.  The fire was ignited by torching - embers that floated across the Rio Grande from a nearby sugar burn in northern Tamaulipas, Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local emergency management, fire departments, and the US Fish and Wildlife Service reported a 300 acre wildfire developed rapidly during the afternoon of March 7th, when embers from a sugar cane burn in northern Tamaulipas, Mexico, just south of the Rio Grande drifted into the refuge and began the process of torching brush and grass. The wildfire, aided by dry fuels, gusty east winds, and near critical relative humidity levels, continued for nearly 48 hours before being 100 percent contained.  The refuge was closed to public operations through the following weekend for safety precautions and continued clean-up activities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ninth Avenue Wildfire began about six miles east of Bushland Texas in Potter County around 1758CST. The wildfire was caused by downed power lines and burned towards northwest Amarillo which resulted in the Amarillo Medical District being threatened with evacuations being ordered. There were no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were fifty homes and twenty-six other structures that were threatened by the wildfire but were saved. There were no reports of any homes or other structures damaged or destroyed by the wildfire. The wildfire consumed an estimated four hundred acres. There were a total of fourteen fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The resources assigned included a TFS taskforce and a TIFMAS engine strike team. The wildfire was contained around 0600CST on March 19.

The Old Muddy Road Wildfire began about nineteen and a half miles northwest of Amarillo Texas in Potter County around 1815CST. The wildfire was caused by downed power lines and consumed four thousand and four hundred and eighty acres. There was a report of twenty homes threatened and thirteen homes destroyed by the wildfire. There were also forty other structures threatened and ten other structures destroyed. There were no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were a total of nine fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The  resources assigned included two TFS taskforces, two TIFMAS engine strike teams, two heavy air tankers, lead plane and an aerial supervision platform. The wildfire was contained around 1100CST and 1200CST on March 19.

A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers, trained spotters, COOP Observers, and broadcast media reported 15 to 20 inches of snowfall. Gusty winds combined with the heavy wet snow to bring down tree limbs and some power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 1 to 2 feet of snow across the county. The highest totals were in Monroe and Highland Mills with 26.0 and 24.3 inches respectively. The heavy wet snow combined with gusty winds to bring down tree limbs and some power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire department/rescue reported 13.5 inches of snow in Armonk. 9 to 14 inches was reported across northern Westchester from CoCoRaHS observers, a COOP observer, and the public. The heavy wet snow combined with strong winds to bring down tree limbs and a few power lines.
