EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred offshore and in the Delaware Bay waters. Also, due to extended cold snap portions of Delaware Bay were frozen over impacting commerce and other services.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weatherflow site.

CZ_NAME: MANASQUAN INLET TO LITTLE EGG INLET NJ OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred offshore and in the Delaware Bay waters. Also, due to extended cold snap portions of Delaware Bay were frozen over impacting commerce and other services.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weatherflow site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Gravel Pit Wildfire began about seven miles north of Amarillo Texas in Potter county around 1518CST. The wildfire consisted of three fires: one near Dumas Texas, another fire in Potter County near the Fain Gas Plant, and another fire near Masterson Texas. The Fain Gas Plant, the Blue Knight Oil Plant, and the J. Lee Milligan Asphalt Plant were evacuated. The wildfire consumed two thousand nine hundred and seventy-six acres. The cause of the wildfire was determined to from faulty vehicle equipment or vehicle dragging a chain. There were ten homes and forty other structures that were threatened by the wildfire but were saved, however there were no homes or other structures destroyed by the wildfire. There also no reports of injuries or fatalities. The wildfire was contained around 0100CST to 0130CST March 16. There were a total of two fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The resources assigned to the wildfire included a TFS taskforce, TIFMAS engine strike team, three single engine air tankers, an aerial supervision platform and other support overhead.

The County Line Wildfire began around 1708CST about four or five miles south southeast of Channing Texas in Oldham County. The wildfire was caused by smoking materials which was started in open field. The wildfire consumed fifteen thousand six hundred and eighty-two acres in Hartley, Oldham and Moore Counties. There were two homes and five other structures threatened by the wildfire but were saved. There were no reports of any homes or other structures damaged or destroyed by the wildfire. There were also no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were a total of twelve fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The resources assigned included two TFS task forces, three single engine air tankers, one heavy air tanker and an aerial supervision platform. The wildfire resulted in evacuations for residents near the Moore County and Hartley County line. The wildfire was contained between 0400CST and 0500CST March 16.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low across the NE Gulf of Mexico began to lift NE with a lobe of strong mid level energy overspreading the area from west to east. This energy enhanced thunderstorms that developed along the west coast sea breeze and east coast sea breeze mergers in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Craig Airfield ASOS measured a wind gust to 44 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pecatonica River near Darlington crested at 15.30 ft., which is moderate flood stage.  Highways 23 and 81 are flooded and closed in Darlington, as is a good part of Main Street. This includes the highway 23 bridge. The Lafayette County Fairgrounds are flooded. In addition, there is flooding in Calamine, Wisconsin, about 5 miles upstream of Darlington. Also, northwest of South Wayne, portions of Sargent Rd. and Larson Rd. are closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding of lowland and agricultural land including some roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ponders Place Wildfire began around 1451CST about ten miles west of Dumas Texas in Moore County. The cause of the wildfire was determined to be from pasture and field burning. The wildfire consumed one thousand two hundred and sixty-one acres. There was a report of one home and one other structure threatened by the wildfire and one other structure was reported destroyed. There were no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were a total of six fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire. The wildfire was contained around 1930CST.

The West Follett Wildfire began about one mile west of Follett Texas in Lipscomb County around 1316CST. The wildfire consumed approximately two thousand acres. The wildfire burned towards the western side of Follett and one hundred and eighty-two homes and ten other structures were threatened and evacuations were ordered. There were several plastic fertilizer tanks and a grain elevator that burned down. There were no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were no reports of any homes damaged or destroyed. There were a total of twelve fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The wildfire was contained around 1745CST and 1815CST.

The Channing Wildfire began about four miles north northeast of Channing Texas in Hartley County around 1717CST. The cause of the wildfire was downed power lines and power poles. The wildfire started after twelve power poles were downed by the high winds near Farm to Market Road 722 and US Highway 385 in an open field. There was a report of two homes, five barns, windmills and an oil infrastructure threatened although no homes or other structures were reported damaged or destroyed. The wildfire consumed an estimated forty-five hundred acres. There were a total of five fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The resources assigned included a TFS taskforce, three single engine air tankers, a heavy air tanker, lead plane and an aerial supervision platform. The wildfire was contained around 0000CST and 0100CST on March 19.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low over the NE Gulf of Mexico increased diurnal instability with enhanced a few storms that developed along the sea breezes as they drifted inland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down on the 2200 Block of SW 41st Avenue. The cost of the damage was unknown but it was estimated for the event to be included in StormData.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low across the NE Gulf of Mexico began to lift NE with a lobe of strong mid level energy overspreading the area from west to east. This energy enhanced thunderstorms that developed along the west coast sea breeze and east coast sea breeze mergers in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down across International Golf Parkway about 1 mile west of U.S. Highway 1. The time of damage was based on radar. The cost of damage was unknown but it was estimated for the inclusion of the event in StormData.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low across the NE Gulf of Mexico began to lift NE with a lobe of strong mid level energy overspreading the area from west to east. This energy enhanced thunderstorms that developed along the west coast sea breeze and east coast sea breeze mergers in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees limbs were blown down with wind estimated between 50-60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut Department of Transportation and amateur radio reported 7 to 11 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Connecticut Department of Transportation and broadcast media reported 6 to 8 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to heavy snow bands moved across Long Island and New York City with lighter snow across the Lower Hudson Valley. The heaviest snow occurred in New York City and Long Island Wednesday night into early Thursday morning. The highest snowfall rates occurred on Long Island with generally 2 to 4 inches per hour at times. The NWS official observation at the Islip Airport indicated a snowfall rate of 5 inches per hour between 9pm and 10pm on March 21st with around 9 inches of snow falling from 8pm to 10pm. Within these heavier bands, near-blizzard conditions occurred with visibilities one quarter mile or less and winds gusting 30 to 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, social media, broadcast media, and the public reported 10 to 20 inches of snowfall. Near-blizzard conditions occurred at times during the evening of March 21st with visibility falling below one quarter of a mile at times and winds gusting 25 to 30 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding of lowland and agricultural land including some roads. County officials sandbagged and pumped water out of areas in the Village of Arena, which saved 14 homes from flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding of lowland and agricultural land including some roads. Portions of highways 144, 175, and 167 near Friess Lake Dr. were closed due to high water. The southbound off ramp from I-41 to highway 60 was closed for a time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. The heaviest snow occurred in New York City and Long Island Wednesday night into early Thursday morning. The highest snowfall rates occurred on Long Island with generally 2 to 4 inches per hour at times. The NWS official observation at the Islip Airport indicated a snowfall rate of 5 inches per hour between 9pm and 10pm on March 21st with around 9 inches of snow falling from 8pm to 10pm. Within these heavier bands, near-blizzard conditions occurred with visibilities one quarter mile or less and winds gusting 30 to 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Official NWS Observation at Central Park reported 8.4 inches of snow. Law enforcement in Gramercy Park reported 10.0 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall fell during the month of March 2018, with very little snowfall as well. This led to severe drought conditions spreading across most of the area, with some areas of south central Kansas now moving into extreme drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued during the month of March, 2018. Most of the county remained in the severe drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic during the early morning hours on March 2, 2018. The low moved slowly off the coast and became nearly stationary near the 40N/70W benchmark. The storm brought winter storm conditions to portions of the Lower Hudson Valley, especially in the higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 14.0 inches of snow in Monroe, 9 inches of snow in Greenville, and 8 inches of snow in South Blooming Grove.  A trained spotter reported widespread tree damage around 1143 am in the town of Monroe due to the high winds. At 245 pm in the town of Otisville, a trained spotter observed a tree down at Sagamore Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly intensifying low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic during the early morning hours on March 2, 2018. The low moved slowly off the coast and became nearly stationary near the 40N/70W benchmark. The storm brought winter storm conditions to portions of Northeast New Jersey, especially in the higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 8.3 inches of snow in West Milford and 7.2 inches in Ringwood. Winds also gusted 40 to 50 mph across western Passaic county. At 2 pm, the fire department reported a tree down in the town of Wayne. The tree was knocked down at the intersection of Fairview Drive and Circle Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the town of Haddam, the Department of Highways reported a tree down due to the winds on Route 81 and Burr Road. The road was closed around 219 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement  reported a tree and wires down on Bayberry Hill in the town of Branchville at 315 pm. At 1230 pm, The Department of Highways closed Route 39 between Warwic Road and Ball Pond Road east due to a tree down onto wires. This occurred in the town of New Fairfield. In the town of Ridgefield, numerous trees were knocked down due to the high winds around the town at 220 pm. Route 116, West Mountain and North Salem Roads were impacted per social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The media reported a large tree down on Route 1 in Clinton at 908 am. The ASOS at nearby Groton New London Airport measured a wind gust to 59 mph at 908 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration period of relatively mild and moist air moving into the region, followed by a low pressure area and cold front resulted in several inches of snow accumulation. |The long duration snow resulted in 4 to 8 inches of accumulation over much of southern WI. Numerous vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred with five deaths reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked close enough to southeast Connecticut to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018. Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times during the morning and early afternoon. The heaviest snow occurred across New London county with 1 to 2 feet observed. Stronger winds combined with the heavy snow to bring down trees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observers, trained spotters, broadcast media, and the public reported 10 to 18 inches of snowfall. The Groton-New London Airport reported a 43 mph wind gust at 10:01 am EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sugar River reached moderate flood stage, cresting at 9.59 feet in Brodhead. There is widespread flooding of lowland and agricultural land in the Brodhead area. Floodwaters cover roads about 6 miles downstream into the Avon Township of Rock County.  Floodwaters are over Highway T which is on the border of Green and Rock Counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: NOS marine buoy site.

CZ_NAME: CP HENLOPEN TO FENWICK IS DE OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred offshore and in the Delaware Bay waters. Also, due to extended cold snap portions of Delaware Bay were frozen over impacting commerce and other services.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weatherflow site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor Flooding occurred along the Delaware River due to an Ice Jam. Flood stage is 20.0 feet and the river was between 19 and 20 feet throughout most of Monday. Lower Makefield twp was impacted with a few roads flooded. Roads closed included River, West Trenton, and Richard.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to minor flooding by an Ice Jam.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air flowing over the mountains caused snow for locations along and west of the Allegheny Front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 2.5 inches in Bayard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Coastal low pressure developed of the Mid-Atlantic Coast. A period of snow developed over eastern and northeastern Maryland before the low intensified and moved off to the north and east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 2.0 inches in Annapolis and 1.6 inches at BWI Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The FM 2381 wildfire began around 1736CST about three miles north of Bushland Texas in Potter county. The wildfire started just east of Farm to Market Road 2381 north of the Bushland High School. The wildfire consumed a measured four hundred and ninety-six acres. There were roughly fifteen to thirty homes threatened however no homes or other structures were damaged or destroyed. There were also no reports of injuries or fatalities.  Farm to Market Road 2381 and Farm to Market Road 1061 had been closed due to low visibilities. There were a total of two fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The wildfire was contained around 0900CST on March 3.

The County Line South Wildfire began around 1030CST about two miles south of Shamrock Texas in Wheeler County. The cause of the wildfire was a vehicle dragging a chain. There were two homes and two other structures threatened however no homes or other structures were damaged or destroyed by the wildfire. There was one near miss, however there no injuries or fatalities. The wildfire consumed three hundred and twenty-five acres. There were a total of five fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire. The wildfire was contained around 1330CST to 1400CST.

The 1062 Wildfire began about three miles north of Dawn Texas in Deaf Smith County around 1205CST. The wildfire consumed an estimated three hundred acres and began at the Top of Texas Cotton Gin north of Dawn and burned in grass fuels. There were no reports of any homes or other structures threatened and there were also no reports of any homes or other structures damaged or destroyed. There were no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There was a report that one hundred and twenty cotton modules burned. The wildfire was contained around 1500CST. The Texas A&M Forest Service, along with several other fire departments and fire agencies, responded to the wildfire. The resources assigned included a TFS dozer strike team.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to three inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Coastal low pressure developed of the Mid-Atlantic Coast. A period of snow developed over eastern and northeastern Maryland before the low intensified and moved off to the north and east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 2.0 inches near Kingsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed by to the south and high pressure filtered in cold air from the north. A tight gradient developed with the precipitation, but it was far enough to the north for snow to develop over central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 2.8 inches near Greenwood and 2.0 inches near Covesville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and slow moving low pressure developed along the Middle Atlantic coast on Wednesday, March 21st and moved slowly north and east along the coast through Thursday, March 22nd. Moderate to heavy snow bands moved across Long Island and New York City with lighter snow across the Lower Hudson Valley. The heaviest snow occurred in New York City and Long Island Wednesday night into early Thursday morning. The highest snowfall rates occurred on Long Island with generally 2 to 4 inches per hour at times. The NWS official observation at the Islip Airport indicated a snowfall rate of 5 inches per hour between 9pm and 10pm on March 21st with around 9 inches of snow falling from 8pm to 10pm. Within these heavier bands, near-blizzard conditions occurred with visibilities one quarter mile or less and winds gusting 30 to 35 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, social media, and the FAA Contract Observer at La Guardia Airport reported 9 to 14 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Below normal rainfall fell during the month of March 2018, with very little snowfall as well. This led to severe drought conditions spreading across most of the area, with some areas of south central Kansas now moving into extreme drought conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued during the month of March, 2018. Most of the county remained in the severe drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southern Connecticut. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, CoCoRaHS observers, and social media reported 10 to 19 inches of snowfall. The highest snow totals occurred in Wolcott with 18.5 inches and Northford with 15.7 inches. Trees and power lines were also brought down due to the heavy wet snow and gusty winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported 6 inches of snowfall. Strong winds in combination with heavy, wet snow also brought down tree limbs and a few power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported 7 to 9 inches of snowfall. Strong winds brought down power lines, which were on fire closing Bergen Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and CoCoRaHS observers reported 1 to 2 feet of snowfall. The highest totals occurred in Oakland and Mahwah with 26 and 18.4 inches respectively.  In Ho-Ho-Kus, a large tree snapped from the weight of the heavy snow taking down major power lines at the intersection of Hollywood Avenue and Sheridan Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS and trained spotters reported 6 to 10 inches of snow. Trees and power lines were also downed due to heavy wet snow and strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration period of relatively mild and moist air moving into the region, followed by a low pressure area and cold front resulted in several inches of snow accumulation. |The long duration snow resulted in 4 to 8 inches of accumulation over much of southern WI. Numerous vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred with five deaths reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches of snow accumulation. One death reported from a traffic accident related to the snow covered roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, CoCoRaHS observers, and the public reported 6 to 8 inches of snow. A large tree was blocking a roadway in Glen Head. Trained spotters also reported a tree on fire due to fallen power lines in Locust Valley. A transformer fire was also reported on Piping Rock Road in Locust Valley. A tree was downed on Main Street and Library Drive in Port Washington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The FAA Contract Observer at John F. Kennedy Airport reported 2.8 inches of snow. 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across southern Queens.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving across northern IL spread multiple bands of moderate to heavy snow across southern WI from the evening into the morning hours. Three to eight inches of snow fell with many schools closed from Madison to Milwaukee and south to the IL border. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP Observers and trained spotters reported 2 to 5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio reported a tree down across the Palisades Parkway closing the road in both directions at 1225 pm. Around 345 pm in the town of Hackensack, a large tree was knocked down on to power lines according the social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 115 pm, the Department of Highways reported a downed tree on NJ 19 northbound in the area of CR 509 and Broad Street. This occurred in the town of Clifton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the town of South Orange, the fire department reported a tree down at 379 Lenox Avenue at 139 pm due to the high winds. In Orange at 145 pm, a tree was knocked down across a fire truck on Berkeley Road. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 2 pm, the media reported an overturned tractor trailer on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge due to the high winds. An 84 mph wind gust at an elevation of 700 feet was measured at the bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station in Bayville measure a 78 mph wind gust at 526 pm. This station is elevated. At 530 pm, a trained spotter reported a scaffold collapse and perimeter fence uprooted on Devonshire Drive in New Hyde Park. Emergency managers reported LIRR service suspended at 544 pm due to a downed utility pole east of the Jamaica Station in Westbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station at Eatons Neck reported a 69 mph wind gust at 320 pm. At 215 pm, a trained spotter reported a large tree down on the corner of Roundtree Drive and Beaumont Drive in Melville. Around 220 pm in Smithtown, the Department of Highways reported a tree down on NY 25A at Sunken Meadow Road, with all lanes closed. In Mount Sinai, the public reported a tree down on Mead Avenue around 430 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter in Babylon measure a 61 mph wind gust around 535 pm. At 430 pm, the public reported trees down in Babylon and West Islip causing power lines to come down and power outages along Montauk Highway in both towns.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station in Napeague measured a 62 mph wind gust at 350 pm. At Montauk Airport, a 58 mph wind gust was reported at 7 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A upper level low developed across the far NE Texas Panhandle with an associated dryline back to the south and southwest. A jet streak working into west Texas during the afternoon helped bring strong shear throughout the column into the Panhandles. In particular, noticeable surface based directional shear right along the dry line, west winds to the west and east winds east of the dryline helped storms develop rotation along the converging boundary. Storms that developed had broad rotation along a small line of individual couplets. Some deeper cores did produce some severe hail across the northeastern Panhandles. A landspout was confirmed by spotters in far southeast Ochiltree County along with an  6 mile weak EF-1 tornado track through parts of Hemphill and Lipscomb counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Carson County Gin Wildfire began about two to three miles west southwest of White Deer Texas in Carson County near the Carson County Gin around US Highway 60 and County Road X around 1442CST. The wildfire was caused by burning sawdust piles. There were reports of one home and fifteen other structures threatened by the wildfire but were saved, however no homes or other structures were destroyed. There was one report of an injury, however no fatalities were reported. The wildfire consumed seven hundred and seventy-one acres. There were a total of seven fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The resources included a dozer strike team. The wildfire was contained around 2300CST.

Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The FAA Contract Observer at LaGuardia Airport reported 1.7 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow to southeast New York. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, Fire Department/Rescue and social media reported 8.5 to 26.0 inches of snow. The highest totals were in Sloatsburg and Chestnut Ridge with 26.0 and 19.5 inches respectively.  Broadcast media reported a fallen tree killed one person on Hillside Avenue in Suffern.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the town of Meriden, a large tree and power lines were knocked down by the high winds at 425 pm per social media. This occurred on Broad Street. At 335 pm, social media reports of a telephone polw and power lines down were received. This occurred in the town of Oxford, at Old State Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Groton New London Airport measured a wind gust to 59 mph at 908 am, and again at 320 pm. At 345 pm in the town of North Stonington, Route 216 was closed at 187 Clarkes Falls due to downed trees and power lines. This was according to the broadcast media. The mesonet station at the USCG Academy measured a wind gust to 69 mph at 329 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A crash involving 29 vehicles occurred in and near a patch of dense fog in the northbound lane of Highway 18/151 just south of Verona, WI. One death occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A crash involving 29 vehicles occurred in and near a patch of dense fog in the northbound lane of Highway 18/151 just south of Verona, WI. One death occurred and six people were taken to hospitals. The Dane County Sheriff's Office cited poor visibility and high speed as factors in the crash. The small patch of dense fog formed over Badger Mill Creek. The northbound lanes of Highway 18/151 were closed for much of the day due to the investigation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of low pressure moved northeast across WI. A surge of relatively mild and moist air aloft moved over cold air temperatures at the ground causing light freezing rain. Widespread icing resulted mainly north of Madison. Vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks from freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air at the surface, combined with a moist flow off the Pacific, resulted in heavy snow across the Sheridan Foothills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of 6 to 8 inches were reported across the area. Severe driving conditions were also reported on I-90 from Wyola to the Wyoming state line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air at the surface, combined with a moist flow off the Pacific, resulted in heavy snow over the Beartooth/Absaroka Mountains and adjacent foothills, as well as portions of the plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 4 to 8 inches was reported across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Tut Creek Wildfire began around 1500CST about four miles northwest of Lefors Texas in Gray County. The wildfire is located approximately seven miles southeast of Pampa Texas. There were no reports of homes or other structures threatened, damaged or destroyed by the wildfire and there were also no reports of any injuries or fatalities. The cause of the wildfire was reported to be from faulty oil field equipment. The wildfire consumed seven thousand three hundred and thirty-four acres. There were a total of ten fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Texas A&M Forest Service. The resources included a TFS Taskforce, a TIFMAS engine strike team, four single engine air tankers and an aerial supervision platform. The wildfire was contained around 2300CST.

The Arrington Ranch 2 Wildfire began around 1505CST about eight miles south southeast of White Deer Texas in Carson County. The wildfire was caused by downed power lines and consumed approximately three hundred and fifty acres. There were no reports of any homes or other structures threatened, damaged or destroyed by the wildfire. There were also no reports of any injuries or fatalities. There were a total of five fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire which was contained around 2000CST.

The Beasley Ranch Command Wildfire began around 0945CST about three miles southwest of Optima Oklahoma in Texas County. There were no homes or other structures threatened, damaged or destroyed by the wildfire and there were also no injuries or fatalities. The wildfire consumed five hundred and sixty acres. There were a total of eleven fire departments and other fire agencies that responded to the wildfire including the Oklahoma Forestry Services. The wildfire was contained around 1800CST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to three inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A decaying line of thunderstorms arrived across the Lake Cumberland and Bluegrass regions of eastern Kentucky late in the evening of February 24. This line progressed eastward through the night, producing a few severe wind gusts across Rockcastle and Pulaski Counties shortly after midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A citizen reported a large tree blown down in Brodhead.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A decaying line of thunderstorms arrived across the Lake Cumberland and Bluegrass regions of eastern Kentucky late in the evening of February 24. This line progressed eastward through the night, producing a few severe wind gusts across Rockcastle and Pulaski Counties shortly after midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported multiple trees blown down from northeast of Science Hill at the intersection of Kentucky Highway 452 and Etna Church Road to Dabney along Kentucky Highway 39.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A upper level low developed across the far NE Texas Panhandle with an associated dryline back to the south and southwest. A jet streak working into west Texas during the afternoon helped bring strong shear throughout the column into the Panhandles. In particular, noticeable surface based directional shear right along the dry line, west winds to the west and east winds east of the dryline helped storms develop rotation along the converging boundary. Storms that developed had broad rotation along a small line of individual couplets. Some deeper cores did produce some severe hail across the northeastern Panhandles. A landspout was confirmed by spotters in far southeast Ochiltree County along with an  6 mile weak EF-1 tornado track through parts of Hemphill and Lipscomb counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in rural Hemphill County northwest of Glazier and continued into Lipscomb County. The tornado caused damage to trees, power poles and out building equivalent to a lower end EF1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of low pressure moved northeast across WI. A surge of relatively mild and moist air aloft moved over cold air temperatures at the ground causing light freezing rain. Widespread icing resulted mainly north of Madison. Vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks from freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving eastward from the central United States on Thursday March 1st, intensified rapidly as it moved offshore Thursday night and early Friday, deepening to 974 mb by the evening of Friday March 2nd.||Strong winds were present in the low levels of the atmosphere due to the strengthening pressure gradient, and were able to mix down to the surface in strong wind gusts under northwest flow cold air advection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were down across Harford County.

CZ_NAME: CAPE FAIRWEATHER TO CAPE SUCKLING COASTAL AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weather front moved across the northern panhandle that spread moisture across the area, with cold air trapped in Lynn Canal. Periods of heavy snow developed along the Haines Road then developed on the Eastern Gulf Coast 	during the night of 2/27.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total 11.0 inches overnight for Downtown Yakutat for 2/27 to 2/28. Impact was removal of heavy wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A upper level low developed across the far NE Texas Panhandle with an associated dryline back to the south and southwest. A jet streak working into west Texas during the afternoon helped bring strong shear throughout the column into the Panhandles. In particular, noticeable surface based directional shear right along the dry line, west winds to the west and east winds east of the dryline helped storms develop rotation along the converging boundary. Storms that developed had broad rotation along a small line of individual couplets. Some deeper cores did produce some severe hail across the northeastern Panhandles. A landspout was confirmed by spotters in far southeast Ochiltree County along with an  6 mile weak EF-1 tornado track through parts of Hemphill and Lipscomb counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Land spout tornado reported with multiple photos. Was on ground for about 5 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of low pressure moved northeast across WI. A surge of relatively mild and moist air aloft moved over cold air temperatures at the ground causing light freezing rain. Widespread icing resulted mainly north of Madison. Vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks from freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The east branch of the Pecatonica River in Blanchardville reached major flood stage, cresting at 16.02 feet. McKellar Park was completely flooded including the swimming pool, tennis courts, and football field. Highway H in Blanchardville was flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate rainfall on February 19-20th resulted in 1.25-2.50 inches of rain. The rain fell on top of a snow cover of 0 to 3 inches and a frozen ground. Significant runoff resulted in widespread areal flooding and river flooding over southeast WI and portions of south central WI. Several rivers reached moderate and major flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sugar River flooded from Green County into Rock County. The Avon Bottoms State Natural Area and Sugar River Park is flooded, including County Road T, which is the border of Green and Rock County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked   close enough to eastern Long Island to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018.  Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times in the morning across eastern Long Island. A deep upper level trough over the northeast also aided in bringing lighter snow over the Lower Hudson Valley and portions of New York City, despite the low pressure tracking several hundred miles off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters, COOP observers, CoCoRaHS observers, and the public reported 6 to 12.5 inches of snow.  The highest amount was reported by a trained spotter in Orient with 12.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The mesonet station at Jones Beach Coast Guard measured a 66 mph wind gust at 548 pm. Around 1254 pm, the Department of Highways reported downed wires on the Long Island Expressway Service Road westbound between Searingtown Road and New Hyde Park Road, closing all lanes. At 210 pm, a trained spotter reported trees and wires and two telephone poles down blocking Oakfiled Road and Barrie Avenue in Wantagh. Also in the town of Wantagh, a trained spotter reported a tree down across the roadway at Park Avenue west of Oakland Avenue. This occurred around 330 pm. At the same time, a large tree was reported down onto multiple homes in Garden city per the broadcast media. At 415 pm in Franklin Square, a trained spotter observed a tree down on a car with live wires on New Hyde Park Road. At 515 pm, a tree down was reported down via social media in Oceanside. The tree fell onto a vehicle at the intersection of South Long Beach Road and Foxhurst Road.

Floodwaters get into the basements of some homes along South Water Street and in the basements of a few businesses on North Water Street in downtown Albany. Floodwaters affect the back yards of a few homes along South Mill Street. Floodwaters are into Village Park.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low across the NE Gulf of Mexico began to lift NE with a lobe of strong mid level energy overspreading the area from west to east. This energy enhanced thunderstorms that developed along the west coast sea breeze and east coast sea breeze mergers in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gust measured at the WeatherFlow site at Huguenot Park.

CZ_NAME: INNER CHANNELS FROM KUPREANOF ISLAND TO ETOLIN ISLAND
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The weather front swept over the central panhandle on 24 February, spreading snow over the cooler air trapped near the surface. An easterly flow pattern ahead of the front/low resulted in some upslope flow to the easterly slopes increasing the snowfall.  Temperatures began warming to in the afternoon leading to a wetter snowfall in the afternoon and compaction of the snowpack.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Petersburg trained spotter measured 10 inches of new snow at 1525 2/24. Impact was snow removal. No damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tight surface pressure gradients resulted in very gusty winds across Northern Sweet Grass and Southern Wheatland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 58 mph were recorded across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another outflow event was characterized by a 1050 MB high over the Yukon and temperatures in the mid -40s over  Canada.  Strong pressure gradients and moderate cold advection caused high wind gusts at the Skagway marine exchange site.  A more glancing blow of cold air as opposed to the last system combined with the lack of strong low pressure to the south limited gusts below 70 mph and also the length of the outflow event. No damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous gusts 60 to 65 mph were observed at the Skagway Airport during the night of 2/7 and all day on 2/8. No damage was reported.

CZ_NAME: JUNEAU BOROUGH AND NORTHERN ADMIRALTY ISLAND
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 979 MB gale force low moved onto Vancouver Island on the afternoon of 2/28 with 1035 MB High over the Yukon. This was a setup for a Taku wind event for Downtown Juneau and Douglas. The peak gust was 92 mph from a marine Exchange observation Downtown. No damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Taku wind gusts for Downtown and Douglas ranged from 65 to 92 mph during the night of 2/28 and daytime on 3/1. No damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along Ridgewood Road. Water flowed over the road and local officials had to block off a portion of the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved through the region, ample moisture was present for showers and thunderstorms to develop. Many of these storms trained across portions of northeast Louisiana and over the same locations. This resulted in significant flash flooding over portions of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred across portions of Fremont and Natrona Counties. The highest winds were at the RAWS site at Camp Creek where a maximum wind gust of 89 mph was recorded. Along Outer Drive south of Casper a maximum wind gust of 64 mph was measured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds were recorded across the higher elevations. Some maximum wind gusts included 89 mph at Camp Creek and 64 mph at Fales Rock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred across portions of Fremont and Natrona Counties. The highest winds were at the RAWS site at Camp Creek where a maximum wind gust of 89 mph was recorded. Along Outer Drive south of Casper a maximum wind gust of 64 mph was measured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The weather station along Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper recorded a maximum wind gust of 64 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and potent winter storm crossed western and central Wyoming and brought heavy snow and high wind to many locations. Strong winds occurred ahead of the storm in portions of central Wyoming, with some of the strongest gusts were 78 mph at Fales Rock and 75 mph along Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper. Following that, heavy snow fell. Over a foot of new snow fell in portions of the Tetons, Absarokas and Casper Mountain as well as in Yellowstone Park. In the lower elevations, the heaviest snow fell around Casper where up to 15 inches was measured. Other areas with over 6 inches included around Rock Springs, northern Big Horn County and around Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous wind gusts over 60 mph along Wyoming Boulevard south of Casper including a maximum wind gust of 75 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a strong pressure gradient and strong low level winds mixing to the surface brought high winds to wind prone areas of northern and central Wyoming. The strongest winds occurred in the vicinity of Clark where gusts as high as 93 mph were recorded. In central Wyoming, some of the highest wind gusts included 83 mph at the Fales Rock RAWS site in the Green Mountains and 68 mph along Wyoming Boulevard south of Casper.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred in portions of the Cody Foothills. The strongest wind gust recorded was 93 mph 5 miles west-northwest of Clark.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a strong pressure gradient and strong low level winds mixing to the surface brought high winds to wind prone areas of northern and central Wyoming. The strongest winds occurred in the vicinity of Clark where gusts as high as 93 mph were recorded. EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred in the higher elevations of the Green Mountains. The highest wind gust recorded was 83 mph at the Fales Rock RAWS site.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds occurred in the higher elevations of the Green and Rattlesnake Range. The highest wind gust was 78 mph at Fales Rock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain and isolated thunderstorms arrived late in late February. Two to more than four inches of rain was common in central and southern sections of the state. By the time the rain ended, forty-eight hour rainfall amounts through 600 am CST on March 1st included 4.53 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County), 4.10 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 3.42 inches at Pine Bluff (Jefferson County), and 3.02 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in the southern portion of Montgomery County were washed out and impassable.

By the time the rain ended, forty-eight hour rainfall amounts through 600 am CST on March 1st included 4.53 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County), 4.10 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 3.42 inches at Pine Bluff (Jefferson County), and 3.02 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Both lanes of Highway 247 west of Hattieville were blocked due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon of Monday, March 5th, thunderstorms initiated across south-central and southeast Arkansas. Most thunderstorms stayed under severe-thresholds. However, one storm did become strong enough to produce hail up to the size of golf balls in Desha County.

During the afternoon of Monday, March 5th, thunderstorms initiated across south-central and southeast Arkansas. Most thunderstorms stayed under severe-thresholds. However, one storm did become strong enough to produce hail up to the size of golf balls in Desha County.

An active and warm weather pattern in February produced widespread minor flooding across the area. Starting during the second week of February a blocking pattern developed keeping a warm ridge of high pressure over the eastern U.S. with a flow from the Gulf of Mexico into the Ohio River Valley. The heaviest rains fell near and along a quasi-stationary front that lingered between northern Indiana and over the Ohio River for about a two week period. Despite dodging the heaviest rain, the area received well above normal rainfall especially over southern and eastern counties including the Muskingum and Mahoning River basins.  Though very wet, most of the area rivers were able to contain the streamflows with only minor impacts. Non-river flooding was most problematic in Knox County and portions of the upper Muskingum watershed. Numerous road closures were reported but no inundation of properties were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall measured over 2.50 in Knox County produced flooding mainly south of Mt. Vernon and College Township  on the evening of the 15th. The flooding resulted in multiple road closures. Route 661 was closed south of Mt. Vernon with about a foot of water flowing across it. Rt 62 east of Mt. Vernon closed with several inches of flowing water across it. Water rescues were conducted on Lower Gambier Road after the Kokosing River overflowed its banks. The road was closed most of the day on Friday the 16th as well. Stricker Road was closed due to washed out culverts. Stull and Sapp roads, and many other were closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and wet pattern continued through the end of February continuing and creating new flooding mainly over southern and eastern Ohio. The most notable flooding was along the Ohio River, however the headwaters of the Muskingum also experienced minor flooding conditions. Rainfall totals for the month were 200% of normal with areas in Knox and surrounding counties over six inches. A rain event on February 25th alone produced one to two inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An inch and a half of rain fell over Marion County on the 25th, which had been preceded by wet conditions prior to this event. The Delaware Reservoir located south of Waldo was experiencing high water levels. This allowed the Olentangy River and its tributaries to back up. Flooding of area roads resulted from this excessive water. Some of the roads in the area, including those flooded from the Scioto River, include Deadwood Rd between Essex Rd and Mt. Olive Agosta Rd, Marseilles Galion Rd W between Hillman Ford Rd, LaRue Green Camp Rd between SR 37 and Guthery Rd, Fairchild Rd at SR 746|Flooding in Waldo (Marion County) on the Brondige Run (tributary) on Gearhiser Road and Mt. Vernon Rd East( RT 86).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lone storm brought hail to Conway in Faulkner County the 19th.
Severe thunderstorms caused some damage on the 27th. Copious amounts of moisture brought heavy rain to parts of Arkansas on the 27th and 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The trained spotter measured 3.25 inches of rain as of 1224 CST on the 28th, since the evening of the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms caused some damage on the 27th. Copious amounts of moisture brought heavy rain to parts of Arkansas on the 27th and 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down. An outbuilding was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex and potent winter storm crossed western and central Wyoming and brought heavy snow and high wind to many locations. Strong winds occurred ahead of the storm in portions of central Wyoming, with some of the strongest gusts were 78 mph at Fales Rock and 75 mph along Wyoming Boulevard on the south side of Casper. Following that, heavy snow fell. Over a foot of new snow fell in portions of the Tetons, Absarokas and Casper Mountain as well as in Yellowstone Park. In the lower elevations, the heaviest snow fell around Casper where up to 15 inches was measured. Other areas with over 6 inches included around Rock Springs, northern Big Horn County and around Bondurant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell throughout Natrona County, ranging from 6 inches at Midwest to 15 inches in Evansville. At the Natrona County airport, 14.7 inches of snow was measured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a strong pressure gradient and strong low level winds mixing to the surface brought high winds to wind prone areas of northern and central Wyoming. The strongest winds occurred in the vicinity of Clark where gusts as high as 93 mph were recorded. In central Wyoming, some of the highest wind gusts included 83 mph at the Fales Rock RAWS site in the Green Mountains and 68 mph along Wyoming Boulevard south of Casper.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred in much of Natrona County. The strongest gust was 68 mph along Wyoming Boulevard. Other notable gusts included 62 mph at the Casper airport and 60 mph at 20 mile hill along Interstate 25.

CZ_NAME: ALTAMAHA SD TO FERNANDINA BEACH FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough and pre-frontal trough over a moist and unstable environment triggered severe thunderstorm that produced large hail and gusty winds. Strong deep layer shear and most unstable CAPEs where near 2500 J/kg with steep mid level lapse rates (over 8C/km). The Storm Prediction Center highlighted an Enhanced Risk of Severe Storms across the local area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong mid level winds mixed to the surface ahead of an advancing cold front and brought high winds to the wind prone areas across central Wyoming. The strongest winds were near Clark where winds gusted as high as 96 mph. Elsewhere, winds gusted to 81 mph along Wyoming Boulevard south of Casper and a gust of 79 mph was recorded at Fales Rock in the Green Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred in portions of the Cody Foothills. The strongest winds were in the vicinity of Clark where winds gusted as high as 96 mph. High winds even made it into the west side of Cody where a gust of 58 mph was recorded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The RAWS site at Fales Rock had several hours of high wind gusts, including a maximum of 79 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong gusty winds occurred ahead of a cold front that trailed southwest from a surface low pressure center over lower Michigan. From Poplar Bluff north and northeast to Cape Girardeau and Perryville, south to southwest winds gusted up to near 45 mph. The peak wind gusts were measured at 47 mph at the Cape Girardeau airport and 44 mph at Poplar Bluff.

CZ_NAME: ST AUGUSTINE TO FLAGLER BEACH FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low across the NE Gulf of Mexico began to lift NE with a lobe of strong mid level energy overspreading the area from west to east. This energy enhanced thunderstorms that developed along the west coast sea breeze and east coast sea breeze mergers in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter measured a gust to 43 mph in western Palm Coast. The gust damaged a HAM radio antenna.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rain band formed across the area on the west side of TS Alberto. This band interacted with diurnal instability and upper level lift which combined to produce isolated severe storms as the band lifting NNE across the local area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down across Highway 135. One tree blocked the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture combined with sea breeze forcing and diurnal heating produced localized heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer measured 2.31 inches of rainfall in 55 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture combined with sea breeze forcing and diurnal heating produced localized heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer measured 1.25 inches within 45 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low over the NE Gulf of Mexico increased diurnal instability with enhanced a few storms that developed along the sea breezes as they drifted inland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree branch fell on a home in Ocala. Extent of damage unknown, but estimated cost of damage so event could be included in Storm Data.

CZ_NAME: FERNANDINA BEACH TO ST AUGUSTINE FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level short wave trough moving over the area enhanced afternoon sea breeze storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The gust was measured by the WeatherFlow site at Huguenot Park.

CZ_NAME: ST AUGUSTINE TO FLAGLER BEACH FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent upper level low across the NE Gulf of Mexico began to lift NE with a lobe of strong mid level energy overspreading the area from west to east. This energy enhanced thunderstorms that developed along the west coast sea breeze and east coast sea breeze mergers in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a wind gust to 50 mph along U.S. Highway 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Onshore winds of 10-15 mph and surf of 1-2 feet with a south to north long-shore current were observed during the afternoon of the rip current fatality. St. Johns County Ocean Rescue reported that two others were caught in rip currents that day as well. The body of the fatality was bound about 400 yards north of where he entered the water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ocean rescue and local media reported an 18 yr old male from Lowdes county GA drowned due to a rip current in St. Augustine Beach. The time of the fatality was unknown, but it occurred that afternoon per media reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A man tried to save a woman and toddler from drowning offshore of Massengale Park in St. Simons Island during the evening. The woman and child were pulled back to shore, the man never returned. The woman later died in the hospital, the child survived. A moderate risk of rip currents was in effect.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man died due to a rip current after trying to rescue a woman and child from the surf.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A boundary lifting northward over Florida under a mid level trough lingering across the eastern Gulf of Mexico resulted in waves of heavy rainfall, which produced daily rainfall amounts over 4 inches in southern Marion county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near Lake Weir measured 3.75 inches of rainfall between 5 am and 6:48 am. The 24-hr rainfall was 4.29 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking north over AL and northern GA streamed a plume of tropical moisture over the local area.  Waves of showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over a two hour period, 4.5 inches was measured in Mandarin. Ditches were overflowed with water, some spreading onto roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rain band formed across the area on the west side of TS Alberto. This band interacted with diurnal instability and upper level lift which combined to produce isolated severe storms as the band lifting NNE across the local area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A former NWS employee estimated wind gusts of 70 mph near Lake Brooklyn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: East coast sea breeze storms moved inland an converged with high instability and inflow which cause a brief, weak EF0 landspout to form NW of Screven.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EM did a storm survey and confirmed EF0 tornado damage near Burch Farms and Dixie Road in Screven. Several videos of tornado via Wayne County EM Facebook page. A couple of homes had damage, no injuries reported.  The path length and width were unknown but estimated for inclusion of the event in Storm Data.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Diurnal convection was being supported by the passage of an upper level shortwave on the evening of May 26th.  The environment was favorable for heavy rain with high moisture content in the airmass. Flooding occurred over portions of Holmes County Ohio as storms merged and stalled over the central part of the county while producing torrential rainfall rates.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall moved into Holmes County between 700 and 800 pm on the evening of the 26th. A line of thunderstorms over Wayne County moved south into Holmes County where there was a cell merger. This cause a brief period of storm back building and training over north central Holmes County. During this period the rainfall rates were estimated around 5 inches per hour. The storm motions were from north to south, paralleling the extent of the Killbuck Creek river basin starting in the headwaters. This confined the majority of the runoff to that single basin. The result was flash flooding in several areas across Holmes County. One home in Monroe and Prairie Township was flooded on County Road 320 from Paint Creek. Prairie Township Fire Department rescued people from a car in high water. One unofficial rainfall report of 3.00 came from Berlin in eastern Holmes County. An official reading in Holmesville of 2.72 was measured between 7 pm and 8 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front marched across northwestern Pennsylvania during the afternoon of May 4th. A line of thunderstorms developed in advance of the front and caused some damage. A severe thunderstorm watch box was in effect during the time of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a tree on the railroad tracks near the intersection of Norcross and Martin Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved north across the area causing a few thunderstorms to develop.  One of the storms produced hail in Lucas County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel sized hail was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a tree.

Strong southwest winds occurred ahead of a cold front that was dropping southward across Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana. Peak wind gusts were mostly from 40 to 50 mph. The highest gust at the Evansville airport was 45 mph.

Extreme drought (D3 category), which began in January, continued throughout March across the same sections of southeast Arizona and expanded westward from the White Mountains in northern Graham and Greenlee Counties across the San Carlos Apache Tribe lands of northwestern Graham County due to below normal rainfall for the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought (D3 category), which began in January, continued throughout March across the same sections of southeast Pima County, Santa Cruz County and far southwest Cochise County including portions of the Tohono O'odham Nation and the Baboquivari, Santa Rita and Huachuca Mountains, but expanded westward from the White Mountains in northern Graham and Greenlee Counties across the San Carlos Apache Tribe lands of northwestern Graham County.||While some rain did fall in the extreme drought area, amounts were light, ranging from 10 to 50 percent of normal for March in northern areas and less than 25 percent of normal in southern areas. Overall soil moisture readings generally remained ranked below the 20th percentile, but wildfire activity was suppressed as a result of the widespread precipitation event that occurred in mid February. Levels in the San Carlos Reservoir, which had been hovering between 7 and 8 percent of capacity through the winter, dropped to near 6 percent by the end of March.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extreme drought (D3 category), which began in January, continued throughout March across the same sections of southeast Pima County, Santa Cruz County and far southwest Cochise County including portions of the Tohono O'odham Nation and the Baboquivari, Santa Rita and Huachuca Mountains, but expanded westward from the White Mountains in northern Graham and Greenlee Counties across the San Carlos Apache Tribe lands of northwestern Graham County.||While some rain did fall in the extreme drought area, amounts were light, ranging from 10 to 50 percent of normal for March in northern areas and less than 25 percent of normal in southern areas. Overall soil moisture readings generally remained ranked below the 20th percentile, but wildfire activity was suppressed as a result of the widespread precipitation event that occurred in mid February. Levels in the San Carlos Reservoir, which had been hovering between 7 and 8 percent of capacity through the winter, dropped to near 6 percent by the end of March.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper low was moving onshore into the Pacific Northwest with an 80-90 knot jet over the Borderland.  A surface low was located over eastern Colorado with an associated cold front moving through the region bringing wind gusts up to 90 mph to south central New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northrup Strip mesonet site recorded a peak gust of 70 mph.

A wave of low pressure moving across northern IL spread multiple bands of moderate to heavy snow across southern WI from the evening into the morning hours. Three to eight inches of snow fell with many schools closed from Madison to Milwaukee and south to the IL border. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to seven inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong gusty winds occurred ahead of a cold front that trailed southwest from a surface low pressure center over lower Michigan. From Poplar Bluff north and northeast to Cape Girardeau and Perryville, south to southwest winds gusted up to near 45 mph. The peak wind gusts were measured at 47 mph at the Cape Girardeau airport and 44 mph at Poplar Bluff.

Several inches of powdery snow fell over southeast Wisconsin during the morning hours. Snow covered roads caused some vehicle slide-offs and accidents. An upper trough and mid level front brought the snow to the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of powdery snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The FAA Contract Observer at Newark-Liberty International Airport reported 4.6 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms moved through the region. One tornado and isolated wind damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very weak tornado developed west of the intersection of Decker Road and Dusty Road north of Gray Summit snapping several trees and crossing an open corn field before lifting. It was only on the ground for a total of one minute and less than two tenths of a mile, but the debris from the harvested corn field was lofted nearly 4300 feet in the air and was detected by radar for 15 minutes after the tornado dissipated. The tornado was rated EF0. Path length was 0.18 miles with a max path width of 25 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure tracked well offshore of the eastern seaboard, but tracked   close enough to eastern Long Island to bring heavy snow bands during the morning and early afternoon on Tuesday, March 13, 2018.  Snowfall rates were 1 to 2 inches per hour at times in the morning across eastern Long Island. A deep upper level trough over the northeast also aided in bringing lighter snow over the Lower Hudson Valley and portions of New York City, despite the low pressure tracking several hundred miles off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS Employee in Stony Brook reported 8.3 inches of snow. Trained spotters,  CoCoRaHS observers, and the public reported 6 to 11 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and the public reported 1 to 2 feet of snow. 23.0 inches was reported in North Caldwell and 19.7 inches in Roseland. The heavy wet snow and strong winds also brought down trees and some power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system developed along the Middle Atlantic coast during the morning of Wednesday, March 7, 2018. The low tracked along the coast through the early morning hours on Thursday, March 8, 2018. The storm brought heavy wet snow, strong gusty winds, and even some thundersnow across northeast New Jersey. Snowfall rates ranged from 1 to 3 inches per hour at times in the heaviest snow bands.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters and CoCoRaHS observers reported 7 to 9 inches of snowfall. Numerous downed trees and power lines occurred in Fanwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Diurnal convection was being supported by the passage of an upper level shortwave on the evening of May 26th.  The environment was favorable for heavy rain with high moisture content in the airmass. Flooding occurred over portions of Holmes County Ohio as storms merged and stalled over the central part of the county while producing torrential rainfall rates.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lift north across Ohio during the afternoon May 30th causing a broken line of showers and thunderstorms to develop.  A couple segments of the line became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a couple trees in the Upper Sandusky area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lift north across Ohio during the afternoon May 30th causing a broken line of showers and thunderstorms to develop.  A couple segments of the line became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed several trees in the Millersburg area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lift north across Ohio during the afternoon May 30th causing a broken line of showers and thunderstorms to develop.  A couple segments of the line became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a tree and large tree limb.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lift north across Ohio during the afternoon May 30th causing a broken line of showers and thunderstorms to develop.  A couple segments of the line became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts were estimated at 60 mph.

CZ_NAME: JUNEAU BOROUGH AND NORTHERN ADMIRALTY ISLAND
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Taku wind affecting Downtown Juneau and Douglas occurred on 3/22 as a result of 1037 MB high pressure over the Yukon and a 993 MB low over the Hecate Strait. ||Strong gusty winds  with several gusts above 60 kt from early morning into the afternoon hours.  Bursts of winds from downbursts and lighter gusts to 50 mph through the day. Occasional peaks to 60mph into the evening after the warning ended.  Lenticular clouds in evidence for the sky cover.  Northern inside channels had peak gusts of 60-90mph. Tenakee Springs had occasional gusts hitting high wind criteria and waterspout observed by the mayor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This Taku wind caused some shingle damage in West Juneau on 3/22 with fence damage, roof of chicken coop blown off, and back door damage reported at Douglas residence.	Douglas Boat harbor  84 mph (twitter post), Peak gust of 91 mph at 944 AKST.  Lots of gusts in the 70s mph.  Power outage Downtown Juneau at 0245 AKST.  Tenakee Springs Mayor observed a waterspout on 3/22.

CZ_NAME: CAPE FAIRWEATHER TO CAPE SUCKLING COASTAL AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak low tracked ESE across the northern gulf into the eastern gulf.  Warm moist air  overrunning cold air at the surface caused measurable snow to much of the northern and central Panhandle. Amounts were highly variable. No damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snow measured at the Yakutat Airport and Downtown was 7.0 inches in 12 hours. Impact was snow removal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind a cold front, high winds on the backside of a weak upper level disturbance reached the ground in a few counties. In Sherman County, the peak gust was 61 MPH at Goodland. Wallace and Gove counties also experienced high winds.||To the east ahead of the cold front, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms was moving east across Decatur, Norton, and Graham counties.  These storms produced large hail and severe wind gusts.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball at Norton, and the highest wind gust was 63 MPH at Hill City.
