Numerous supercell thunderstorms moved across Arkansas from the evening of the 13th into the early morning hours of the 14th. These storms produced multiple weak tornadoes and damaging wind gusts across the state. The tornadoes and damaging wind gusts produced primarily light structural damage, and one of the hardest hit areas was a nursing home near Mountain Home that was heavily damaged by 85 mph straight line winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Arkansas Hwy 189 was closed to due flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds up to 40 mph ahead of a cold front moving across Middle Tennessee caused some minor wind damage in Davidson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Twitter report indicated a large tree and power lines were blown down on Estes Road in the Green Hills area of Nashville, closing the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level storm system moved across the Tennessee Valley from November 14 into November 15. Rain spreading across the region became a wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow across the far western and northwest counties of Middle Tennessee from the afternoon hours on November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Up to 1.5 inches of snow and 0.2 inches of ice were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow affected Stewart County from the afternoon of November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Stewart County Emergency Management reported a total of 1.5 inches of snow in Dover.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level storm system moved across the Tennessee Valley from November 14 into November 15. Rain spreading across the region became a wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow across the far western and northwest counties of Middle Tennessee from the afternoon hours on November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Up to 1.5 inches of snow and 0.2 inches of ice were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow affected Montgomery County from the afternoon of November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. The Clarksville Outlaw Field ASOS measured a total of 0.12 inches ice accretion from freezing rain at 600 PM CST on November 14. The Clarksville COOP Observer measured a total snowfall of 1.0 inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level storm system moved across the Tennessee Valley from November 14 into November 15. Rain spreading across the region became a wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow across the far western and northwest counties of Middle Tennessee from the afternoon hours on November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Up to 1.5 inches of snow and 0.2 inches of ice were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow affected Montgomery County from the afternoon of November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Robertson County Fire Department Officials reported several trees and power lines were down across northwest and northern Robertson County due to ice accumulation around 0.20 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level storm system moved across the Tennessee Valley from November 14 into November 15. Rain spreading across the region became a wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow across the far western and northwest counties of Middle Tennessee from the afternoon hours on November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Up to 1.5 inches of snow and 0.2 inches of ice were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow affected Dickson County from the afternoon of November 14 into the early morning hours on November 15. Dickson County Emergency Management reported around 0.13 inches of ice accumulation from freezing rain on elevated surfaces in Dickson and Charlotte.

A hybrid surface low pressure system tracked across South Dakota on Friday evening (March 30th), before shifting into southern Minnesota by the early morning hours of Saturday the 31st. This storm produced four to ten inches of snow along with 35 mph wind gusts.

Low pressure deepening off the North Carolina coast produced significant snowfall over most of eastern North Carolina during the late evening of January 17th through the early morning of January 18th. Snowfall over the region ranged from less than 1 inch over the southwest tier to 8 inches or more over the north coast. There was one weather related traffic fatality reported in Washington county on the morning of January 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snow developed during the evening of January 17th and continued through the early morning of January 18th. Snowfall across the county ranged from 3 to 6 inches with the highest amounts over the eastern sections. Roads were snow and ice covered with hazardous travel conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approached Eastern NC late on January 12th, 2018. A shortwave trough moved through the area prior to the cold front, with high-shear and limited instability, leading to several marine thunderstorm wind gusts across the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: WeatherFlow sensor near the Ocracoke Ferry Terminal reported a 52 knot marine thunderstorm wind gust.

CZ_NAME: VOLUSIA-BREVARD COUNTY LINE TO SEBASTIAN INLET 0-20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and a few thunderstorms developed within a moist and unstable environment well ahead of a cold front. A few of the showers produced strong wind gusts over the Indian River and adjacent Kennedy Space Center as they moved rapidly northeast at 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: USAF wind tower 1007 over the Indian River, along the NASA Causeway, measured a peak wind of 34 knots from the southwest as a heavy shower moved rapidly off the mainland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure rebuilt over Central California during the morning of the 17th. With low clouds having dissipated the day before, dense fog reformed across portions of the San Joaquin Valley from Fresno southward during the evening hours on the 16th and continued through the morning of the 17th before lifting into a low cloud deck.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Fresno.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Lemoore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: President's Day weekend got off to a warm and dry start across the area, but the weekend ended on the chilly side as a strong cold front pushed across Central California on the evening of February 18. Gusty winds accompanied the front and continued behind the cold front overnight and well into the President's Day holiday before diminishing by afternoon. Several locations in the San Joaquin Valley measured wind gusts between 35 and 45 mph while several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported wind gusts between 45 and 55 mph with a few low impact indicator locations reporting stronger gusts. In addition to the strong winds, light snow fell across portions of the Kern County Mountains in post frontal showers and several locations picked up between a dusting to an inch of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 81 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled across South Central Texas and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of this boundary. Some of these storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
A cold front stalled across South Central Texas and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of this boundary. Some of these storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
A cold front stalled across South Central Texas and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of this boundary. Some of these storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced one inch hail near Cestohowa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled across South Central Texas and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of this boundary. Some of these storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew over a grain bin and some yard fixtures near Falls City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled across South Central Texas and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of this boundary. Some of these storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced wind gusts estimated at 60 mph that blew down some power lines near Panna Maria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain event on the 20-21 dropped one to four inches of rain over Llano and Burnet Counties and this was enough to move them out of severe drought category.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain event on the 20-21 dropped one to four inches of rain over Llano and Burnet Counties and this was enough to move them out of severe drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous accidents due to ice covered roads with minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain event on the 20-21 dropped one to four inches of rain over Llano and Burnet Counties and this was enough to move them out of severe drought category.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A heavy rain event on the 20-21 dropped one to four inches of rain over Llano and Burnet Counties and this was enough to move them out of severe drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: At 500 MB, a strong western Atlantic high pressure ridge and a deep low pressure trough over the High Plains were denoted at the surface by a slow-moving cold front over the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys. This resulted in unseasonably warm and humid conditions across east Tennessee and southwest Virginia, and widespread heavy rains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several road closures around the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface low pressure tracked across South Dakota on the morning of February 18th, then moved to just north of the Twin Cities in Minnesota by the early evening. An area of snow over north central South Dakota in the early morning hours spread east-northeast, eventually setting up in an east-west band from New Rockford to Hillsboro to Bemidji. There were intense snow rates within this band through the remainder of the morning into the afternoon. Snow totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches along this corridor.

An area of snow over north central South Dakota in the early morning hours spread east-northeast, eventually setting up in an east-west band from New Rockford to Hillsboro to Bemidji. There were intense snow rates within this band through the remainder of the morning into the afternoon. Snow totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches along this corridor.

A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous accidents due to ice covered roads. A moderate injury was reported on highway 65 one half mile south of Ridgedale when vehicle slid off the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several accidents were reported with minor to moderate injuries as vehicles slid off roadways.

CZ_NAME: MANITOU ISLAND TO MARQUETTE MI AND W OF GRAND MARAIS MI TO US/CANADIAN BORDER BEYOND 5NM OF SHORE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storm force west winds developed at Stannard Rock on the 25th in the wake of a strong winter storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The peak wind gust at Stannard Rock Light during a several hour period of storm force west winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous accidents across the county due to icy roads. A vehicle on Old Mill Road 2.5 miles west of Marshfield slid off the road and hit a tree with minor injuries to the driver.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous accidents were reported around the county, several with minor to moderate injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An accident occurred on MO 137, 3 miles south OF Raymondville when a vehicle slid off the roadway due to ice conditions and overturned. Occupant sustained minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable warm and moist conditions prevailed east of a frontal boundary located over the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys. Convection produced localized flooding mainly south of I-40.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two roads closed by flooding near Jasper.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow fell over much of northern Houghton County from the 2nd into the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across northern Houghton County generally measured between four and seven inches of lake effect snow over 24 hours.  There was an isolated report of 14 inches of fluffy snow in 24 hours near Atlantic Mine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate to briefly heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into early morning on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Norway and near Iron Mountain measured between three and four inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate to briefly heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into early morning on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Kearsarge measured four inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate to briefly heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into early morning on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from just south of Trenary and near Escanaba measured between four and five inches of snow in 14 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate to briefly heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into early morning on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Trenary and ten miles south of Grand Marais measured between four and five inches of snow in 12 hours.  The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais reported strong winds and near-zero visibility as a mesolow moved onshore from Lake Superior during the early morning of the 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 6 to 9 inches of snow to Spring Creek and Lamoille.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to seven inches of snow was reported in Spring Creek and nine inches in Lamoille.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought 8 to 16 inches of snow to the Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range.
A winter storm brought 6 to 7 inches of snow to southern Lander and southern Eureka counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to seven inches of snow was reported in Eureka and 6 inches in Austin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread heavy rainfall impacted the area from February 28th through the 1st of March, with lingering flooding conditions lasting the better part of 7 days. Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches fell across much of the area, leading to areal and river flooding. All of the WFO Huntsville HSA river forecast points had some type of product out for them during this event. To date, that's only happened one or two other times in the office's history.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over a foot of water covering CR53 in the Rash Community.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate to briefly heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 3rd into early morning on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow reports from social media included three to four inches of snow in Marquette in four hours and five inches of snow in Harvey in four hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The observer at Munising reported moderate snowfall from the 12th into the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Munising measured seven inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system passing south of Upper Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd into the morning of the  23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Chassel and Painesdale through Houghton to Laurium measured between seven and nine inches of snow in nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system passing south of Upper Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd into the morning of the  23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of seven inches of snow in ten hours at Iron River.   Amasa and Stambaugh received four to five inches over the same time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system passing south of Upper Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd into the morning of the  23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of three inches of snow in eight hours at McMillan.  A glaze of ice was also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought a prolonged period of unseasonably warm temperatures to begin February as temperatures were 10 degrees or more above seasonal normals across much of the are for the first 10 days of the month. A low pressure system dropping into the Great Basin on the 10th brought a period of increased winds to the Kern County Mountains and Deserts during the late morning and early afternoon as strong mid level winds mixed down to the surface where there were numerous reports of gusts between 45 and 50 mph. Another trough pushed through the Great Basin on the evening of the 11th through the morning of the 12th which pushed a cold front through Central California and brought another period of increased winds to the area and there were several reports of wind gusts between 50 and 55 mp in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. this system also brought some light precipitation to the area with amounts generally less than a tenth of an inch of liquid precipitation in post-frontal showers on the 12th. A weak tornado briefly touched down in rural farmland near Sanger during the late morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Bear Peak RAWS on an exposed ridge top reported a peak wind gust of 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread heavy rainfall impacted the area from February 28th through the 1st of March, with lingering flooding conditions lasting the better part of 7 days. Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches fell across much of the area, leading to areal and river flooding. All of the WFO Huntsville HSA river forecast points had some type of product out for them during this event. To date, that's only happened one or two other times in the office's history.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CR 112 closed at this location due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system originating over the Southern Rockies lifted across the Upper Great Lakes and brought moderate to heavy snow to the west half of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 24th into the 25th.  Some light freezing rain was also reported over mainly south central and eastern portions of the U.P.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Houghton County Sheriff reported an estimated six inches of snow in two and half hours at Calumet early on the 25th.  There was another report of five inches of snow in five hours at Chassell.  The Redridge observer measured six inches of snow in 18 hours although most of that snow fell during the early morning of the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system originating over the Southern Rockies lifted across the Upper Great Lakes and brought moderate to heavy snow to the west half of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 24th into the 25th.  Some light freezing rain was also reported over mainly south central and eastern portions of the U.P.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Watersmeet measured six inches of wet snow in approximately nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: President's Day weekend got off to a warm and dry start across the area, but the weekend ended on the chilly side as a strong cold front pushed across Central California on the evening of February 18. Gusty winds accompanied the front and continued behind the cold front overnight and well into the President's Day holiday before diminishing by afternoon. Several locations in the San Joaquin Valley measured wind gusts between 35 and 45 mph while several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported wind gusts between 45 and 55 mph with a few low impact indicator locations reporting stronger gusts. In addition to the strong winds, light snow fell across portions of the Kern County Mountains in post frontal showers and several locations picked up between a dusting to an inch of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a downed telephone pole and a downed tree blocking both lanes on E. Houston Ave. East of McAuliff St. in Visalia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Through the day on February 20, 2018 numerous accidents occurred as a result of widespread accumulating ice. Patchy freezing drizzle started as early as midnight on the morning of February 20, but the heavier rain fell through the morning and early afternoon hours. Numerous powerlines and trees sustained some damage from the accumulation of 1/8 to 1/3 inch of ice across a widespread area, including the Kansas City metro area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper low was moving onshore into the Pacific Northwest with an 80-90 knot jet over the Borderland.  A surface low was located over eastern Colorado with an associated cold front moving through the region bringing wind gusts up to 90 mph to south central New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Augustin Pass recorded a peak gust of 90 mph.  Other peak gusts included 64 mph 1 mile southeast of the White Sands Missile Range Main Post, 59 mph at Orogrande and 58 mph 5 miles southeast of San Augustin Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a warm front lifted slowly north across the Tennessee Valley and the Carolinas, an area of light to moderate snow developed across Avery County around daybreak on the 24th, and continued off and on through the day, except across western portions of the county, where snow changes to rain as temperatures warmed above freezing. Temperatures warming above the surface forced a transition to sleet and freezing rain across the southern and eastern part of the county during the afternoon and early evening, but not before 2-4 inches of snow had accumulated. Sleet and freezing rain continued across much of the southern and eastern part of the county through the evening. Ice accretion of around a quarter inch was reported across much of these areas by the time the precipitation tapered off during the early morning hours of the 25th. The weight of the ice downed trees and power lines, with scattered outages reported.

As a warm front lifted slowly north across the Tennessee Valley and the Carolinas, an area of light to moderate snow developed across the northern mountains around daybreak on the 24th. Warmer air gradually overspread the area from the southwest, allowing many areas to change to rain. The exception was along the Blue Ridge, mainly along and east of the continental divide, where a narrow corridor of near-freezing surface temperatures locked in for much of the day. By late afternoon, temperatures warming above the surface forced a transition to sleet and freezing rain in these areas. Ice accumulation of up to one half inch was reported on top of up to an inch of sleet and snow. Pockets of significant tree damage were reported in locations that received the higher ice accumulations.

Multiple days of rain produced flooding in Southeast Texas on 2 separate occasions as upper level disturbances kept affecting the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused water to flow across FM 1003 in several locations closing the roadway for a period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report was received of near 12 inches of flowing water across Highway 509 northwest of Kirbyville after heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong north winds behind a cold front pushed tides below normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tide at Cameron fell below -1 foot MLLW for multiple hours. The tide reached a minimum of -1.72 feet MLLW.

Some light freezing rain was also reported over mainly south central and eastern portions of the U.P.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: President's Day weekend got off to a warm and dry start across the area, but the weekend ended on the chilly side as a strong cold front pushed across Central California on the evening of February 18. Gusty winds accompanied the front and continued behind the cold front overnight and well into the President's Day holiday before diminishing by afternoon. Several locations in the San Joaquin Valley measured wind gusts between 35 and 45 mph while several stations in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts reported wind gusts between 45 and 55 mph with a few low impact indicator locations reporting stronger gusts. In addition to the strong winds, light snow fell across portions of the Kern County Mountains in post frontal showers and several locations picked up between a dusting to an inch of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jawbone Canyon RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Indian Wells Canyon RAWS measured a peak wind gust of 82 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread heavy rainfall impacted the area from February 28th through the 1st of March, with lingering flooding conditions lasting the better part of 7 days. Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches fell across much of the area, leading to areal and river flooding. All of the WFO Huntsville HSA river forecast points had some type of product out for them during this event. To date, that's only happened one or two other times in the office's history.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Road 139 was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of freezing drizzle occurred over southern Missouri on February 10-11, 2018. Ice accretions of 0.10 to 0.20 were common across must of southwest Missouri. The precipitation initially began as patchy freezing drizzle during the early morning hours of February 10 and then became more widespread by midday, continuing into Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous vehicles slid off roadways due to icy conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a quasi-stationary front that was draped across the area. One long-lived supercell produced a brief tornado northwest of Ark City before exiting into Oklahoma and becoming stationary. The supercell then moved north and produced multiple tornadoes as a large bow echo thunderstorm merged with the supercell in central Cowley County. This was quickly followed by several shorter-lived Quasi-Linear Convective System (QLCS) tornadoes north and east of Winfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very brief touchdown in open country.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved across the region producing an isolated tornado at Pitkin in Vernon Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado started west of Webster Marcile Road near the community of Cravens snapping several pine trees. It crossed Highway 10 north of Pitkin traveling east to Highway 458 and H Spears road where the most intense damage occurred. At this location numerous fallen trees were noted with one house receieving significant damage from trees. The last visible damage was noted along Fullerton Blacktop Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick 2 to 5 inches of rain fell over Harding County during the morning of the 10th. This flooded some roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inches of rain during the morning of the 10th flooded some roadways north of Silsbee including Craven Camp Road and Turtle Drive.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: About a foot of water over Tupelo Pike near Center Point Baptist Church.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface low pressure tracked across South Dakota on the morning of February 18th, then moved to just north of the Twin Cities in Minnesota by the early evening. An area of snow over north central South Dakota in the early morning hours spread east-northeast, eventually setting up in an east-west band from New Rockford to Hillsboro to Bemidji. There were intense snow rates within this band through the remainder of the morning into the afternoon. Snow totals ranged from 6 to 15 inches along this corridor.

Severe drought conditions developed from Victoria to Refugio during the early part of the  month. Rainfall across the area on the 20th alleviated the drought conditions to moderate levels.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire burned at least one structure and forced evacuations in the Mark Twain National Forest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rozelle Wildfire burned in an area near Highway 160 and State Route 125 southeast of Reuter in Taney County. The area has experienced a severe drought. One home was destroyed and the wildfire burned at least 1500 acres of forest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold and moist air flowed over the mountains, resulting in snow for locations along and west of the Allegheny Front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 5.0 inches in Hightown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy precipitation developed along a stalled front during the overnight hours of February 10th into February 11th, causing flooding in southern Maryland. Stream flooding persisted into February 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS stream gauge on the Western Branch Patuxent River at Upper Marlboro exceeded flood stage between 1132 AM on the 11th and 121 PM on the 12th.  While the gauge was above flood stage, Water Street in Upper Marlboro was flooded. For most of that timeframe it was also closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the Appalachians. Warm and moist air overran the colder air in place, resulting in precipitation. There was a cold layer near the surface that caused freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trace of ice was reported at Andrews Air Force Base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the Appalachians. Warm and moist air overran the colder air in place, resulting in precipitation. There was a cold layer near the surface that caused freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trace of ice was reported at BWI Airport and ice totaled up to a hundredth of an inch at Ross cove.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the Appalachians. Warm and moist air overran the colder air in place, resulting in precipitation. There was a cold layer near the surface that caused freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tenth of an inch of ice was reported in Clarksburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the Appalachians. Warm and moist air overran the colder air in place, resulting in precipitation. There was a cold layer near the surface that caused freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trace of ice was reported at Woodside Park. Ice accumulations from a trace up to five hundredths of an inch were reported across southeastern Montgomery County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level trough moving quickly southeast through the southern Rockies forced strong northwest winds across New Mexico. Most areas experienced wind gusts between 30 and 40 mph along with very low humidity and above normal temperatures. Clines Corners reported a one hour period of sustained winds of 40 mph during the early afternoon. The main focus with for the day was critical fire weather conditions that spread across much of east-central and southeastern New Mexico.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak sustained winds of 40 mph at Clines Corners.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving upper level wave over southern California spread a deep tap of sub-tropical moisture northeastward into the southwest United States. This system delivered the most significant precipitation to New Mexico in over four months. Rain developed quickly over southeastern Arizona early on the 14th then spread into much of central and western New Mexico through the 14th and 15th. Temperatures were warm ahead of this system forcing snow levels above 7,000 feet. Widespread precipitation amounts between one half inch and one inch were reported along and west of the Central Mountain Chain. Snowfall totals between six and 10 inches were common across the higher terrain. This event was significant enough to knock the driest start to a water year to fifth place at the Albuquerque Sunport. Strong winds also accompanied this system across the south central high terrain. Ruidoso reported a peak wind gust to 66 mph and the Dunken area hit 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sierra Blanca Regional Airport reported sustained wind speeds between 40 mph and 47 mph for nearly ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front that raced southeast across New Mexico during the predawn hours forced strong winds in its wake. The strongest winds occurred from near Clines Corners southward toward Capitan where sustained winds over 40 mph and gusts near 60 mph were reported. The remainder of the region saw winds gusting between 40 and 50 mph. Temperatures were 10 to 20 degrees below normal over the entire area with low humidity behind the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clines Corners reported sustained winds of 40 mph.

For the first time since January 2017, an event including both flooding and tornadoes impacted our area starting on February 11, 2018. Two tornadoes touched down across inland portions of the Florida Panhandle before sunrise, followed by persistent heavy rainfall that resulted in flooding at several river sites.  One of the tornadoes clipped far southern Houston county.  As an upper level trough dug southward across the western and central U.S., southerly flow drew moisture from the Gulf of Mexico northward into the tri-state area over the weekend. Upper air soundings measured this increased moisture with precipitable water values around 1.5 inches on Sunday, well above the 90th percentile and a record for the 12z February 11 sounding, although the record for that date and time are below the average max for this time of year. With a cold front and upper level trough west of the area, the persistent deep layer moisture helped to create a favorable set-up for high rainfall amounts.  This wet pattern resulted in copious amounts of rainfall across the tri-state region. The highest rainfall amounts were across the Florida Panhandle where 8 to 10 inches fell with localized areas receiving more than 10 inches across coastal Walton and Bay counties. The highest observed rainfall total was in Walton County, where a 48-hour rainfall total of 11.45 inches was recorded. Across southeast Alabama and portions of southwest Georgia, widespread 6 to 8 inches of rain fell. While one Flash Flood Warning was issued, the majority of the impacts from this event were from moderate rainfall rates over a prolonged period of time as convection trained across the tri-state area. These high rainfall totals resulted in numerous road closures across the Florida Panhandle from water covered roads and washed out roadways. In addition, a few roads were closed across southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor shingle damage was reported in the Pansey area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Haven Dr at Ross Clark Circle was covered in water due to a long duration of moderate to occasionally heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy precipitation developed along a stalled front during the overnight hours of February 10th into February 11th, causing flooding in southern Maryland. Stream flooding persisted into February 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS stream gauge on Mattawoman Creek near Pomonkey exceeded flood stage between 256 PM on the 11th and 1030 AM on the 12th. Several roads, including Maryland Route 227, were flooded and closed while the gauge was over flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain ended the D2 drought for the remainder of southwest Georgia by 2/13/18.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of dry weather allowed for numerous wildfires to develop in and around Manatee County, burning 13 vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Myakka River Fire District reported numerous wildfires in and around Manatee County throughout the weekend. Although no homes were damaged, a total of 13 vehicles were reported to be destroyed by the fires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the Appalachians. Warm and moist air overran the colder air in place, resulting in precipitation. There was a cold layer near the surface that caused freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulation was around fifteen hundredths of an inch at Distant View and near New Market. Ice accumulations around one to two tenths were reported across the county, but one-half inch of ice did fall in the higher elevations near Thurmont.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulations from a trace to around one-tenth of an inch were reported across the county.

Rain developed quickly over southeastern Arizona early on the 14th then spread into much of central and western New Mexico through the 14th and 15th. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front that raced southeast across New Mexico during the predawn hours forced strong winds in its wake. The strongest winds occurred from near Clines Corners southward toward Capitan where sustained winds over 40 mph and gusts near 60 mph were reported. The remainder of the region saw winds gusting between 40 and 50 mph. Temperatures were 10 to 20 degrees below normal over the entire area with low humidity behind the front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clines Corners reported peak wind gusts between 58 mph and 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of southwest winds, extremely low humidity, and very dry fuels set the stage for elevated fire danger across much of New Mexico. Emergency management in Lincoln County reported that a wildfire started shortly after the noon hour near Capitan. The fire spread very quickly through grassy fuels to a size of 30 acres. One home and an outbuilding were destroyed. The Red Cross was working with the family and emergency management to assist the family with their losses. No injuries or fatalities occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grass fire spread quickly to 30 acres and destroyed one home and an outbuilding in Capitan.

One person was killed in a two vehicle accident near Westby (Vernon County) on February 3rd. Roads at the time were snow covered from light snow that had been falling for most of the afternoon. The driver of one of the vehicles lost control in the slippery conditions, crossed the center line and collided head on with the second vehicle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person was killed in a two vehicle accident north of Westby. Roads were snow-covered and slippery from light snow that had been falling most of the afternoon. The driver of one of the vehicles lost control in the slippery conditions, crossed the center line and collided head on with the second vehicle. The driver of the first vehicle died from injuries sustained in the accident while being transported to the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure tracked up the Mid-Atlantic Coast. A cold air mass in place caused precipitation with this low to fall in the form of snow and ice.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A glaze of ice was estimated based on observations nearby.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The northern third of the zone was placed into D2(severe) drought conditions on February 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Even though precipitation across the area was above normal, most of it fell with one storm during the middle of the month.  As a result, drought conditions increased in coverage across Southern New Mexico during the month of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The month started out with the northern half of the zone in D2(severe) drought and on February 13th, the entire zone was placed into the severe drought category. The cooperative observer at Hillsboro reported 0.84 inches of precipitation which was .36 inches above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Even though precipitation across the area was above normal, most of it fell with one storm during the middle of the month.  As a result, drought conditions increased in coverage across Southern New Mexico during the month of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The northern half of the zone started the month in D2(severe) drought and on February 13th, the remainder of the zone was places into severe drought. The Truth or Consequences airport reported 0.87 inches of precipitation which was 0.45 inches above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Even though precipitation across the area was above normal, most of it fell with one storm during the middle of the month.  As a result, drought conditions increased in coverage across Southern New Mexico during the month of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The northern half of the zone started the month of February in D2(severe) drought, and on February 13th was expanded south to include about the northern three-fourths of the zone.  The cooperative observer at White Sands National Monument reported 1.04 inches of precipitation which was 0.59 inches above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell on parts of northeast Iowa from February 8th into the 9th as a storm system moved across the Midwest. The snow created hazardous driving conditions that prompted most schools to close on the 9th. Snowfall totals were generally in the 5 to 6 inch range with the highest reported total being 6.5 inches near Volga (Clayton County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP and volunteer snow observers reported 5 to 6 inches of snow fell across Fayette County. The highest reported total was 6 inches in Oelwein.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad upper level trough with a slow-moving frontal boundary extending from Texas to upstate New York brought an extended period of mainly light to moderate rainfall that began on the afternoon of the 10th and persisted well into the evening of the 11th. Storm total rainfall amounts ranged from 1.5 to 3 inches across parts of northwest North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP observer at Mt. Airy had a 24-hour total of 2.67 inches for the 24-hour period ending at 7 AM on the 11th. This was the 2nd highest daily rainfall total during the month of February at this location since records began in 1893.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system tracked east across the eastern Great Plains into northern Missouri and Illinois on from Feb. 8-9, 2018, bringing widespread snow to portions of eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois. The heaviest snowfall fell along the Highway 20 corridor, where amounts of 6 to 8 inches were reported in Independence, Dubuque, and Freeport. To the south, around 2 to 5 inches fell from the Interstate 80 corridor to Highway 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported heavy snow across much of northern Stephenson county, with 8 inches reported 1 mile east of Freeport, and 6.5 inches reported in the city of Freeport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper low was moving through the Great Basin with southwest flow ahead of it with close to a 100 knot jet.  A deep surface low was located over eastern Colorado with a tight pressure gradient across the region helped to produce wind gusts up to 82 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter 5 miles southeast of East Mesa recorded a peak wind gust of 82 mph at 649 AM on the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A glaze of ice was reported at Winchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper low was moving through the Great Basin with southwest flow ahead of it with close to a 100 knot jet.  A deep surface low was located over eastern Colorado with a tight pressure gradient across the region helped to produce wind gusts up to 82 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet site 11 miles southwest of Northrup Strip recorded a peak gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper low was moving through the Great Basin with southwest flow ahead of it with close to a 100 knot jet.  A deep surface low was located over eastern Colorado with a tight pressure gradient across the region helped to produce wind gusts up to 82 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak gust of 75 mph was recorded at San Augustin Pass.  Other gusts in the zone included 73 mph 5 miles southeast of San Augustin Pass and 71 mph 1 mile southeast of the White Sands Missile Range Main Post.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Even though precipitation across the area was above normal, most of it fell with one storm during the middle of the month.  As a result, drought conditions increased in coverage across Southern New Mexico during the month of February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The month started out with the northern half of the zone in D2(severe) drought and on February 13th the entire zone was put into the D2 category. The cooperative observer at Cliff reported 2.49 inches of precipitation which was 1.37 inches above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the first time since January 2017, an event including both flooding and tornadoes impacted our area starting on February 11, 2018. Two tornadoes touched down across inland portions of the Florida Panhandle before sunrise, followed by persistent heavy rainfall that resulted in flooding at several river sites.  One of the tornadoes clipped far southern Houston county.  As an upper level trough dug southward across the western and central U.S., southerly flow drew moisture from the Gulf of Mexico northward into the tri-state area over the weekend. Upper air soundings measured this increased moisture with precipitable water values around 1.5 inches on Sunday, well above the 90th percentile and a record for the 12z February 11 sounding, although the record for that date and time are below the average max for this time of year. With a cold front and upper level trough west of the area, the persistent deep layer moisture helped to create a favorable set-up for high rainfall amounts.  This wet pattern resulted in copious amounts of rainfall across the tri-state region. The highest rainfall amounts were across the Florida Panhandle where 8 to 10 inches fell with localized areas receiving more than 10 inches across coastal Walton and Bay counties. The highest observed rainfall total was in Walton County, where a 48-hour rainfall total of 11.45 inches was recorded. Across southeast Alabama and portions of southwest Georgia, widespread 6 to 8 inches of rain fell. While one Flash Flood Warning was issued, the majority of the impacts from this event were from moderate rainfall rates over a prolonged period of time as convection trained across the tri-state area. These high rainfall totals resulted in numerous road closures across the Florida Panhandle from water covered roads and washed out roadways. In addition, a few roads were closed across southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rosewood Road was closed due to flooding from a long duration of moderate to occasionally heavy rain.  This road intersects with a small stream that likely overflowed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure passed by to the south on the 20th. At the same time, high pressure was building to the north and this caused cold air to filter in from New England. Rain changed to a wintry mix on the 20th. There was enough cold air for a period of heavier snow across northern Maryland with snow, sleet and freezing rain elsewhere.  A light wintry mix continued for all areas on the night of the 20th. Coastal low pressure developed along the Mid-Atlantic Coast on the morning of the 21st. This caused a round of heavier precipitation to fall mainly in the form of snow. The snow tapered off later in the day as the low moved off to the north and east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A round of heavy snow on March 20th totaled up to 8.5 inches at Ridgeley and 8.0 inches near Frostburg. Another round of snow occurred on the 21st and storm total snowfalls were 11 inches in both Ridgeley and Frosburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread snow event took place over Iowa and Illinois during the day through evening on the February, 5th, 2018.  In most locations, this event produced a widespread 3 to 6 inch accumulation in about 12 hours, which combined with very light winds, to produce moderate impacts corresponding to a Winter Weather Advisory. A band of much heavier snow fell on the south edge of the widespread snow event, and was only 20 to 30 miles wide, but generally stretched across Iowa and Illinois along a line from near Grinnell, Iowa, to near Wapello, Iowa, to just north of Galesburg, Illinois.  In that narrow axis, 7 to 10 inches of snow was observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather spotters reported 8 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system tracked east across the eastern Great Plains into northern Missouri and Illinois on from Feb. 8-9, 2018, bringing widespread snow to portions of eastern Iowa and northwest Illinois. The heaviest snowfall fell along the Highway 20 corridor, where amounts of 6 to 8 inches were reported in Independence, Dubuque, and Freeport. To the south, around 2 to 5 inches fell from the Interstate 80 corridor to Highway 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported 6.0 inches of snow in Asbury, Iowa. Amounts at the Dubuque Regional Airport totals up to 4.3 inches with this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry cold front pushed across the area in the morning trailed by gusty NW winds of 15-20 mph and minimum RHs falling to near 20%. A red flag warning was in effect. A wildfire developed in Nassau County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brush fire was near Yulee between State Road 200 and Pages Dairy Road. It burned about 8 acres and was 75% contained by 5:15 pm per local media. An evacuation order was lifted at 4:40 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the first time since January 2017, an event including both flooding and tornadoes impacted our area starting on February 11, 2018. Two tornadoes touched down across inland portions of the Florida Panhandle before sunrise, followed by persistent heavy rainfall that resulted in flooding at several river sites.  One of the tornadoes clipped far southern Houston county.  As an upper level trough dug southward across the western and central U.S., southerly flow drew moisture from the Gulf of Mexico northward into the tri-state area over the weekend. Upper air soundings measured this increased moisture with precipitable water values around 1.5 inches on Sunday, well above the 90th percentile and a record for the 12z February 11 sounding, although the record for that date and time are below the average max for this time of year. With a cold front and upper level trough west of the area, the persistent deep layer moisture helped to create a favorable set-up for high rainfall amounts.  This wet pattern resulted in copious amounts of rainfall across the tri-state region. The highest rainfall amounts were across the Florida Panhandle where 8 to 10 inches fell with localized areas receiving more than 10 inches across coastal Walton and Bay counties. The highest observed rainfall total was in Walton County, where a 48-hour rainfall total of 11.45 inches was recorded. Across southeast Alabama and portions of southwest Georgia, widespread 6 to 8 inches of rain fell. While one Flash Flood Warning was issued, the majority of the impacts from this event were from moderate rainfall rates over a prolonged period of time as convection trained across the tri-state area. These high rainfall totals resulted in numerous road closures across the Florida Panhandle from water covered roads and washed out roadways. In addition, a few roads were closed across southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down in northwest Jackson county and briefly moved into far southern Houston county. Structural damage was minimal with minor roof damage in Graceville in Jackson county. There was no reported structural damage in Houston county as the tornado tracked through a forested area.  Trees were also blown down along the track with a dual-pol tornadic debris signature observed on radar in far southern Houston county due to tree debris.  This tornado was rated EF0 with max winds estimated at 65 mph based on the observed damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved southeast across Northeast Texas, Southwest Arkansas, and Northern Louisiana during early morning hours of February 6th. Meanwhile, overrunning increased during the daytime hours which led to the development of scattered showers behind the front, which developed into embedded thunderstorms as upper level disturbances shifted northeast across the area enhancing large scale lift, ahead of an upper level shortwave trough which moved into the Southern Plains during the afternoon from the Four Corners region. Steep lapse rates ahead of this shortwave trough contributed to elevated instability aloft, with deep layer shear also adequate enough for some organized post-frontal thunderstorms within a cool air mass with surface temperatures in the lower 50s. As a result, a few of these storms became severe, producing numerous reports of small and large hail across portions of Northeast Texas and Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours. The strong to severe thunderstorms diminished by early evening as the post-frontal rains became more widespread across the area, thus diminishing the elevated instability.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail fell on I-49 southeast of Texarkana. Report from Arkansas State Police.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure passed by to the south on the 20th. At the same time, high pressure was building to the north and this caused cold air to filter in from New England. Rain changed to a wintry mix on the 20th and a light wintry mix continued through the night of the 20th. Coastal low pressure developed along the Mid-Atlantic Coast on the morning of the 21st. This caused a period of heavier precipitation to fall mainly in the form of snow. The snow tapered off later in the day as the low moved off to the north and east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix occurred on the 20th before a round of heavier snowfall developed during the morning of the 21st. Snowfall totaled up to 4.1 inches at the National Zoo and 2.0 inches at Anacostia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell on parts of northeast Iowa from February 8th into the 9th as a storm system moved across the Midwest. The snow created hazardous driving conditions that prompted most schools to close on the 9th. Snowfall totals were generally in the 5 to 6 inch range with the highest reported total being 6.5 inches near Volga (Clayton County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP and volunteer snow observers reported 5 to 6 inches of snow fell across Clayton County. The highest reported total was 6.5 inches near Volga.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure passed by to the south on the 20th. At the same time, high pressure was building to the north and this caused cold air to filter in from New England. Rain changed to a wintry mix on the 20th. A light wintry mix continued for all areas on the night of the 20th. Coastal low pressure developed along the Mid-Atlantic Coast on the morning of the 21st. This caused a round of heavier precipitation to fall mainly in the form of snow. The snow tapered off later in the day as the low moved off to the north and east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wintry mix occurred on the 20th before a round of heavier snowfall developed during the morning of the 21st. Snowfall totaled up to 4.0 inches at Reagan National and 3.0 inches near Barcroft.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another in a series of Alberta clipper systems moving across the plains left behind a swath of light to moderate snow accumulations across southeast South Dakota. Much of the area received from 3 to 6 inches snowfall, while wind chills dropped below zero by the end of the time of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, producing hazardous travel conditions with snowfall totaling as much as 5.0 inches at Canton, 4.8 inches near Hurley, 4.6 inches near Hartford, 4.2 inches at Mitchell, 4.0 inches at Wessington Springs, Bridgewater, Wall Lake, 5 miles NE of Salem and 4 miles NNE of Forestburg, 3.0 inches at Howard, 2.8 inches at Huron, 2.2 inches at Flandreau and 2 inches at Alexandria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of snowfall across northwest Iowa.  Intensity waned for a short time in the afternoon and early evening, allowing a brief change to light freezing drizzle. Snowfall varied from 1 to 5 inches, with greatest amounts closer to the Minnesota border.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle occurred at times between 1300CST and 1800CST, but mainly snowfall occurred resulting in accumulations of 4.0 inches at Primghar and 3.3 inches at Sheldon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ejection of the main upper level wave (which had already steered a pair of snow producing systems across the area during the prior week) brought yet another light to moderate snowfall over northwest Iowa, southeast South Dakota, northeast Nebraska and southwest Minnesota. While it generally snowed for five to eight hours at most across southeast South Dakota, a majority of that time found visibility of a mile or less. Snowfall amounts were mainly 1 to 2 inches across far east and southeast South Dakota, and 3 to 5 inches from south central South Dakota into east central South Dakota. As a result of the snowfall rate, roads rapidly became snow-covered and hazardous.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate snowfall pushed across southeast South Dakota, with four to six hours of moderate snowfall during the 0800CST to 1700CST window. Representative snowfall amounts were 1.2 inches of snow at Vermillion and near Elk Point, 1.6 inches at Sioux Falls, 3.0 inches near Brookings, 4.5 inches near Bruce and Huron, 2.0 inches at Mitchell, 4.0 inches at Platte and 2 miles northeast of Academy, 5.0 inches at White Lake, and 5.5 inches 8 miles south southwest of Herrick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed by to the south and high pressure filtered in cold air from the north. A tight gradient developed with the precipitation, but it was far enough to the north for snow to develop over central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 11.8 near Mustoe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed by to the south and high pressure filtered in cold air from the north. A tight gradient developed with the precipitation, but it was far enough to the north for snow to develop over central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 9.0 inches near Mill Gap and 6.5 inches in Monterey.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked up the Appalachians. Warm and moist air overran the colder air in place, resulting in precipitation. There was a cold layer near the surface that caused freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice totaled up to four tenths of an inch near Long Meadow. A quarter inch of ice was reported at Hagerstown and Maugansville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across southeast South Dakota. A couple periods of snowfall occurred over the two days, with briefly heavier snowfall later on February 19th and into the early morning of February 20 contributing to 2 to 5 inches accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snowfall resulted in accumulations of 5.1 inches 7 miles south-southwest of Chamberlain, 5.0 inches 2 miles southeast of Wessington, 4.5 inches 5 miles south of Chamberlain, 4.0 inches at Menno, 3.1 inches 5 miles northeast of Salem and Tyndall, 3.0 inches at Brookings, White, 4 miles north-northeast of Forestburg, Wessington Springs and Bridgewater, 2.9 inches at White Lake and 2.8 inches at De Smet, 2 miles southeast of Madison and near Bonesteel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure areas tracking northeast along a slow moving frontal boundary produced heavy rain and minor flooding across portions of central Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals generally ranged between 1.5 inches and 4.0 inches across the county. Tabscott reported 4.01 inches of rain. Crozier reported 2.29 inches of rain. Oilville (1 W) reported 2.09 inches of rain. This heavy rain caused some minor street flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure areas tracking northeast along a slow moving frontal boundary produced heavy rain and minor flooding across portions of central Virginia.

Beaverdam (1 E) reported 2.27 inches of rain. Hanover County Municipal Airport reported 1.54 inches of rain. This heavy rain caused some minor street flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure areas tracking northeast along a slow moving frontal boundary produced heavy rain and minor flooding across portions of central Virginia.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Middle- to upper-air flow strengthened once again over Mauna Kea and Mauna Loa on the Big Island of Hawaii.  No significant property damage or injuries were reported.

A large swell from the northwest produced surf of 15 to 25 feet along the north- and west-facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, and along the north-facing shores of Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 10 to 20 feet along the west-facing shores of Oahu and Molokai; and 6 to 10 feet along the west-facing shores of the Big Island of Hawaii.  There were no reports of serious property damage or injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moved slowly north into portions of northern Indiana as low pressure tracked across northwestern Indiana. Steep lapse rates and up to 1000 J/KG flowed into the area allowing for a few storms to become locally severe. Storms struggled to maintain their updrafts, resulting in mainly reports of small hail. One or two storms were able to produce marginally severe hail.

Steep lapse rates and up to 1000 J/KG flowed into the area allowing for a few storms to become locally severe. Storms struggled to maintain their updrafts, resulting in mainly reports of small hail. One or two storms were able to produce marginally severe hail.

A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of widespread light to moderate snowfall across southeast South Dakota.  Outside a narrow band of heavier snowfall from near Wagner to Salem to Brookings, amounts generally varied from 3 to 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, briefly moderate from 1500CST to 1800CST, totaled 2.5 inches 4 miles north northeast of Forestburg.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail occurred in Mission Bend.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving, strong cold front moved through eastern Oklahoma on the 20th and 21st. Very moist air resided across the region ahead of the front. Widespread showers and thunderstorms developed over the area as the front moved into eastern Oklahoma, and the unseasonably moist air supported heavy rainfall with this activity.  Additional heavy rainfall occurred on the 23rd. Much of eastern Oklahoma received between six and ten inches of rain over a 7-day period during this active weather pattern. This excessive rainfall resulted in moderate to major river flooding in the Lower Arkansas River Basin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Illinois River near Tahlequah rose above its flood stage of 11 feet at 8:00 am CST on February 24th. The river crested at 19.58 feet at 12:00 pm CST on the 25th, resulting in major flooding. Severe flooding occurred from near Hanging Rock to near Tahlequah where cabins and parks were severely flooded and portions of Highway 10 were impassable. The river fell below flood stage at 10:45 am CST on the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving, strong cold front moved through eastern Oklahoma on the 20th and 21st. Very moist air resided across the region ahead of the front. Widespread showers and thunderstorms developed over the area as the front moved into eastern Oklahoma, and the unseasonably moist air supported heavy rainfall with this activity.  Additional heavy rainfall occurred on the 23rd. Much of eastern Oklahoma received between six and ten inches of rain over a 7-day period during this active weather pattern. This excessive rainfall resulted in moderate to major river flooding in the Lower Arkansas River Basin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Poteau River near Panama rose above its flood stage of 29 feet at 7:30 pm CST on February 23rd. The river crested at 35.50 feet at 11:30 am CST on the 25th, resulting in moderate flooding. Some agricultural land was flooded and portions of county roads were impassable. The river fell below flood stage at 7:45 pm CST on the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm temperatures, strong gusty wind, low relative humidity, and drought-stricken, dormant vegetation promoted the rapid spread of several wildfires in eastern Oklahoma during early February. Wildfires burned over 8000 acres in Osage County and over 600 acres in Pushmataha County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across northwest Iowa. Most precipitation was in the form of snowfall, which totaled from 2 to 4 inches. Greatest accumulations were measured at Pipestone, Tracy and Marshall (4.0 inches).

With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across northeast Nebraska. While most precipitation was in the form of light freezing rain and freezing drizzle on February 19 which resulted in a 0.05 to 0.10 inch ice accumulation, a second round of precipitation early on February 20 brought a dusting of less than an inch of snow which coated the ice and produced hazardous travel conditions. For the two day period, school delays were common for those not already out for the Washington's Birthday holiday.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across southeast South Dakota. While precipitation was a mix of light snow and light freezing drizzle on February 19 which resulted in a light glaze of ice accumulation, a second round of precipitation late on February 19 and early on February 20 brought a dusting of one to three inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled 1.3 inches near Elk Point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ejection of the main upper level wave (which had already steered a pair of snow producing systems across the area during the prior week) brought yet another light to moderate snowfall over northwest Iowa, southeast South Dakota, northeast Nebraska and southwest Minnesota. While it generally snowed for five to eight hours at most across southwest Minnesota, a majority of that time found visibility of a mile or less. Snowfall amounts 3 to 5 inches were common, and as a result of the snowfall rate, roads rapidly became snow-covered and hazardous.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate snowfall pushed across southwest Minnesota, with four to six hours of moderate snowfall during the 1000CST to 1800CST window.  Representative snowfall amounts were 3.5 inches at Marshall, 4.0 inches at Worthington and Minneota, 4.8 inches at Tracy, 3.8 inches 2 miles northeast of Lakefield, 3.6 inches at Windom, and 3.0 inches at Pipestone.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, briefly moderate from 1500CST to 1800CST, totaled 4.0 inches 2 miles southeast of Vermillion and 2.5 inches 6 miles southeast of Centerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ejection of the main upper level wave (which had already steered a pair of snow producing systems across the area during the prior week) brought yet another light to moderate snowfall over northwest Iowa, southeast South Dakota, northeast Nebraska and southwest Minnesota. It generally snowed for three to five hours at most across northeast Nebraska, briefly with visibility of a mile or less. Snowfall amounts were less than 2 inches, but road conditions quickly became hazardous due to the rate of snowfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of light to briefly moderate snowfall pushed across northeast Nebraska through early afternoon. Snowfall amounts were generally light, with 0.7 inch at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large swell from the northwest produced surf of 15 to 25 feet along the north- and west-facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, and along the north-facing shores of Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 10 to 20 feet along the west-facing shores of Oahu and Molokai; and 6 to 10 feet along the west-facing shores of the Big Island of Hawaii.  There were no reports of serious property damage or injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With an upper trough west of the islands and a surface trough over the state, heavy showers, including thunderstorms, formed across the local area.  Heavy snow also fell over the summits of Mauna Loa and Mauna Kea on the Big Island of Hawaii.  The cost of any damages was not available.  There were no reports of serious injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kamehameha Highway was closed near Waikane as the Waikane and Waiahole streams overflowed after heavy rain in windward Oahu.  Elsewhere on Oahu, Waiahole Valley Road and Kapaa Quarry Road were closed because of flooding conditions.

A disturbance rotating around a large Canadian upper vortex brought a period of enhanced frontogenetic forcing through the Missouri River valley and eastward across northwest Iowa and far southern Minnesota.  Snowfall averaged from 2 to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow over a period of several hours brought from 2 to 4 inches of snowfall across portions of southwest Minnesota near the Iowa Border.  Higher amounts were measured near Worthington (3.5 inches) and near Lakefield (1.8 inches).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance rotating around a large Canadian upper vortex brought a period of enhanced frontogenetic forcing through the Missouri River valley and eastward across northwest Iowa and far southern Minnesota.  Snowfall averaged from 2 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With shallow cold air in place, warm advection associated with a weak wave of low pressure moving northeast from Kansas to Wisconsin produced a shield of light precipitation across southeast South Dakota. A couple periods of snowfall occurred over the two days, with briefly heavier snowfall later on February 19th and into the early morning of February 20 contributing to 2 to 5 inches accumulation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snowfall resulted in accumulations of 5.1 inches 7 miles south-southwest of Chamberlain, 5.0 inches 2 miles southeast of Wessington, 4.5 inches 5 miles south of Chamberlain, 4.0 inches at Menno, 3.1 inches 5 miles northeast of Salem and Tyndall, 3.0 inches at Brookings, White, 4 miles north-northeast of Forestburg, Wessington Springs and Bridgewater, 2.9 inches at White Lake and 2.8 inches at De Smet, 2 miles southeast of Madison and near Bonesteel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of snowfall across northwest Iowa.  Intensity waned for a short time in the afternoon and early evening, allowing a brief change to light freezing drizzle. Snowfall varied from 1 to 5 inches, with greatest amounts closer to the Minnesota border.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing drizzle occurred at times between 1300CST and 1900CST, but mainly snowfall occurred resulting in accumulations of 2.3 inches at Cherokee and 1.5 inches in Washta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving squall line pushed south through the eastern Gulf of Mexico on the 10th, producing thunderstorm wind gusts along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The PORTS site at Old Port Tampa (OPTF1) recorded a 41 knot thunderstorm wind gust.

CZ_NAME: TARPON SPRINGS TO SUWANNEE RIVER FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved southeast through the eastern Gulf of Mexico ahead of a fast moving cold front. A few of the storms in this line produced waterspouts and strong winds along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NOS NWLON station at Cedar Key (CKYF1) recorded a 41 knot thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of widespread light to moderate snowfall across southeast South Dakota.  Outside a narrow band of heavier snowfall from near Wagner to Salem to Brookings, amounts generally varied from 3 to 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, briefly moderate from 1400CST to 1700CST, totaled 3.7 inches at Tyndall and 3.5 inches 8 miles west northwest of Springfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A second disturbance in three days traversed the deep western trough, and the associated jet streak produced another area of widespread light to moderate snowfall across southeast South Dakota.  Outside a narrow band of heavier snowfall from near Wagner to Salem to Brookings, amounts generally varied from 3 to 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, briefly moderate from 1400CST to 1700CST, totaled 2.5 inches near Gayville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ejection of the main upper level wave (which had already steered a pair of snow producing systems across the area during the prior week) brought yet another light to moderate snowfall over northwest Iowa, southeast South Dakota, northeast Nebraska and southwest Minnesota. While it generally snowed for five to eight hours at most across southeast South Dakota, a majority of that time found visibility of a mile or less. Snowfall amounts were mainly 1 to 2 inches across far east and southeast South Dakota, and 3 to 5 inches from south central South Dakota into east central South Dakota. As a result of the snowfall rate, roads rapidly became snow-covered and hazardous.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of moderate snowfall pushed across southeast South Dakota, with four to six hours of moderate snowfall during the 0800CST to 1700CST window. Representative snowfall amounts were 1.2 inches of snow at Vermillion and near Elk Point, 1.6 inches at Sioux Falls, 3.0 inches near Brookings, 4.5 inches near Bruce and Huron, 2.0 inches at Mitchell, 4.0 inches at Platte and 2 miles northeast of Academy, 5.0 inches at White Lake, and 5.5 inches 8 miles south southwest of Herrick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Members of the public reported waterspouts off Oahu and Maui.  There were no reports of significant property damage or injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The waterspout was spotted south of Ewa Beach on Oahu.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a trade swell developing and ongoing moderate to large east swells moving through the area, surf on east-facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Maui, and the Big Island of Hawaii reached levels of 10 to 16 feet, with occasional higher sets.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably warm temperatures, strong gusty wind, low relative humidity, and drought-stricken, dormant vegetation promoted the rapid spread of several wildfires in eastern Oklahoma during early February. Wildfires burned over 8000 acres in Osage County and over 600 acres in Pushmataha County.

Widespread showers and thunderstorms developed across much of northwestern Arkansas on the 20th as a cold front moved through the region. A very moist air mass in place ahead of the cold front promoted the development of heavy rainfall from some of this activity. Widespread two to four inches of rain fell across much of northwestern Arkansas through the morning hours of the 21st, with nearly four inches occurring across portions of Sebastian, Franklin, and Madison Counties. This heavy rainfall resulted in some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Highway 252 were flooded and closed at Onion Creek.

This heavy rainfall resulted in some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rainfall resulted in flooding that damaged portions of county roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following snowfall on the 9th, another center of arctic high pressure built into the northern Plains.  Wind chills from -20 to -30 occurred during the early- to mid-morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Westerly winds around 10 mph and temperatures from -5 to -10 produced wind chills as low as -29 at Huron, -27 at Madison, -26 at Brookings, -24 at Parkston, and -23 at Mitchell, Chamberlain and White Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large swell from the northwest produced surf of 15 to 25 feet along the north- and west-facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, and along the north-facing shores of Oahu, Molokai, and Maui; 10 to 20 feet along the west-facing shores of Oahu and Molokai; and 6 to 10 feet along the west-facing shores of the Big Island of Hawaii.  There were no reports of serious property damage or injuries.

Arctic air surged southward early on February 4th on gusty northerly winds of 20 to 35 mph.  Dangerous wind chills reached -25 to -30.

CZ_NAME: JUPITER INLET TO DEERFIELD BEACH FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak frontal boundary lingering across South Florida lead to shower development over the local Atlantic during the morning and early afternoon hours. A suspected waterspout was spotted with a shower offshore West Palm Beach.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Video received via Twitter of funnel cloud associated with shower offshore West Palm Beach. Observer was unable to see clearly if funnel reached the water surface.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A teenager swimming along the beach was pulled under by a rip current while swimming with family and friends and later rescued. Numerous rip currents and rescues were reported along other Atlantic beaches during the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 13 year old was swimming with family and friends near Coral Cove Park in Tequesta when he was reported to have been caught in a rip current and pulled under the surf. A good samaritan who witnessed the incident was able to pull the teenager from the water and begin CPR. The teenager was transported to a nearby hospital in critical condition. Report received via WPTV on Twitter.
