EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bitterly cold air and wind chill temperatures prevailed over southern WI from Christmas Day through January 6th. Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero occurred at times with low temperatures below zero for most nights. There are eight known deaths related to hypothermia.  Water main breaks and frozen pipes in homes and businesses were a common occurrence across southern WI. Some water damage occurred indoors due to pipes bursting. The cold conditions also caused pavement to buckle on the Beltline Highway in Madison on two separate occasions with one causing a 12 vehicle accident. Some public and private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero, and low temperatures below zero occurred at times during this period of prolonged arctic air. The Dane County Medical Examiner confirmed four deaths due to hypothermia. Four businesses and two apartments suffered water damage from burst pipes, but more instances of frozen and burst pipes likely occurred. On January 4th, buckling pavement on the Beltline Highway caused a 12 car accident in the morning with another occurrence of buckling in the evening. Both resulted in closed lanes for clean-up and repair. Over a dozen water main breaks occurred in the city of Madison and likely more across Dane County. Some public and private events were cancelled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Patchy light freezing drizzle resulted in patches of ice on roadways. A single vehicle accident claimed the life of the driver in Waukesha. Icy roads were a contributing factor in the accident.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Icy roads contributed to a single vehicle accident that claimed the life of the driver.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours on Sunday 1/21, a line of severe thunderstorms in the form of a quasi linear convective system (QLCS) moved through the state of Arkansas. Damaging wind was recorded from western Arkansas to Pine Bluff, with a single EF1 tornado in the LZK warning area. Additionally, there was a single report of hail in far western Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a 2 mile swath of damage that started at Arkla Valley and Highway 287. Multiple structures were destroyed, roofs were tore off, and trees and power lines were down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours on Sunday 1/21, a line of severe thunderstorms in the form of a quasi linear convective system (QLCS) moved through the state of Arkansas. Damaging wind was recorded from western Arkansas to Pine Bluff, with a single EF1 tornado in the LZK warning area. Additionally, there was a single report of hail in far western Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The most extensive damage occurred to the Needs Creek Church and adjacent neighborhood.  The church suffered extensive roof damage, as did a few homes in the neighborhood.  Other damage includes the destruction of outbuildings and minor roof damage to other buildings along the path.  Winds in the Needs Creek area were estimated to have been near 100 mph (EF1), the highest estimated for this tornado. Trees and power lines were reported down in the area as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Not a lot of rain fell in Arkansas in January 2018.  It was a cold month overall with a couple of winter precipitation events.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding continued from December.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm system created blizzard conditions across northern Montana, with extreme winds across higher terrain causing significant impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Browning mesonet station reported a wind gust of 73 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the 7th through 9th, North-Central and Southwest Montana resided underneath northwesterly flow aloft associated with the polar front jet stream. In addition, multiple disturbances embedded within this flow interacted with a frontal boundary that wavered over the area from southwest to northeast and vice versa. The resulting lift, combined with abundant moisture in the low- to mid-level atmosphere, contributed to the formation of periods of snow over North-Central and Southwest Montana. In addition, it is believed mesoscale bands of heavy snow that affected portions of North-Central Montana on the 8th into early morning of the 9th were tied to frontogenesis in the 850 mb to 700 mb layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US-191 closed from Eddie's Corner to junction with US-12 just east of Harlowton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds developed ahead of a cold front across eastern Nebraska. Many locations gusted to over 40 mph.  Omaha, Norfolk, and Lincoln ASOS sites all gusted to over 50 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 51 mph gust was measured at Omaha Eppley Airport ASOS site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal system was draped across the central Appalachians on the 10th and 11th. As waves moved along the front, periods of heavy rainfall moved across southern West Virginia. Rainfall started during the morning of the 10th, with the heaviest rain from late afternoon overnight into the 11th. The most rain fell across portions of Mingo, McDowell, Wyoming, Logan and Raleigh Counties, where 2-3 inches of rain fell with many roads closed due to flooding. The cooperative observer at Oceana in Wyoming County measured 2.56 inches of rain, and at R.D. Bailey Lake on the Wyoming/Mingo border, 2.37 inches was measured. The cooperative observer at Man in Logan County measured 2.2, while the VA Hospital in Beckley got 2.09 inches of rain. Farther north generally 1-2 inches of rain fell, which still caused some minor problems due to saturated ground. ||As the water drained through the creeks and streams, several rivers also flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Gum Road and Laurel Mountain Road were closed due to high water from Claylick Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An oscillating surface boundary with multiple waves of low pressure brought periods of moderate to heavy rainfall from the 22nd into the 25th. This caused another round of flooding on small creeks and streams across the middle Ohio River Valley, and eventually lead to minor flooding on the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred in low lying areas around Point Pleasant, and amphitheater at the lower pier had water halfway up its steps due to flooding along the Ohio River.||The river gage at Point Pleasant rose above its 40 foot flood stage around 10 AM on the 25th. The river crested at 40.3 feet around 3 PM on the 26th, and fell below flood stage early afternoon on the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another upper level weather system produced light to moderate snowfall in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  Snowfall amounts with this storm were generally 1-3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer reported 3 inches of snow at Lincoln.  Throughout the metro Lincoln area there was 2-3 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another upper level weather system produced light to moderate snowfall in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  Snowfall amounts with this storm were generally 1-3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS observer measured 2.5 inches of snow at Gretna.  Snowfall amounts across Sarpy County ranged from 1.5 inches to 2.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another upper level weather system produced light to moderate snowfall in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  Snowfall amounts with this storm were generally 1-3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowall 2 miles southeast of Boys Town amounted to 3 inches.  Throughout Douglas County snowfall ranged from 0.7 inch at Eppley Airfield to 2 to 3 inches across western Douglas County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another upper level weather system produced light to moderate snowfall in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  Snowfall amounts with this storm were generally 1-3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer reported 1.5 inches of snow in Blair.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another upper level weather system produced light to moderate snowfall in eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa.  Snowfall amounts with this storm were generally 1-3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 2 miles south of Wahoo, 1.6 inches of snow fell.  There was 1 to 2 inches of snow that fell over the remaining parts of Saunders County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rounds of cold air continued surging toward Arkansas to begin February. On the 6th, readings were at or below freezing in northwest sections of the state, and subfreezing air spread slowly to the southeast. A storm system over the middle of the country provided moisture, and there was a potential for wintry precipitation.  The incoming cold air was shallow, with warmer conditions (above freezing) overhead. Any snow or sleet would surely melt aloft, but would likely turn to ice (freezing rain) upon reaching the ground. During the nighttime hours of the 6th and early on the 7th, a Winter Weather Advisory was posted across northern Arkansas, with an Ice Storm Warning and up to a quarter inch of ice in the northeast.  For the most part, moisture tended to build over the southern and eastern counties, and stayed out of the north. Any ice in the north was minor and spotty. In the northeast, while there was some ice on trees and power lines (leading to spotty power outages), temperatures did not go much below 32 degrees and roads were generally wet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light ice accumulations were reported at Swifton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving storm system delivered widespread winter weather, and strong gusty winds due to intense low-level winds aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cut Bank ASOS measured a 58 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving storm system delivered widespread winter weather, and strong gusty winds due to intense low-level winds aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station MTSWT measured a peak wind gust of 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain developed over far southeast WI the evening of January 7th resulting in a light glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks. The precipitation was due to an upper level disturbance and relatively milder and moist air moving into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A light glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks after a brief period of freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain developed over far southeast WI the evening of January 7th resulting in a light glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks. The precipitation was due to an upper level disturbance and relatively milder and moist air moving into the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A light glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks after a brief period of freezing rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A light glaze of ice on roads and sidewalks after a brief period of freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours on Sunday 1/21, a line of severe thunderstorms in the form of a quasi linear convective system (QLCS) moved through the state of Arkansas. Damaging wind was recorded from western Arkansas to Pine Bluff, with a single EF1 tornado in the LZK warning area. Additionally, there was a single report of hail in far western Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several small sheds were destroyed along with some large trees blown over near Highway 103.

Damaging wind was recorded from western Arkansas to Pine Bluff, with a single EF1 tornado in the LZK warning area. Additionally, there was a single report of hail in far western Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An attached carport was destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The awning of a gas station at Highway 65 and 425 was destroyed. Power outages were reported on the east side of town near the airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking from Iowa across southeast WI and into Lower MI brought a long duration snow event to southern WI. Lake enhanced snow also contributed to the snow totals near Lake MI. Snow amounts ranged from 2-7 inches inland from Lake MI, to 6-14 inches near Lake MI. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred. Some private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of snow accumulation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms impacted portions of the eastern Catskills, Mid-Hudson Valley, and Taconics during the afternoon of May 15th. Several supercell thunderstorms developed, with the lead storm resulting in a EF1 tornado near Saugerties and a swath of hail of two inches diameter and greater. Later in the afternoon, an intense thunderstorm with winds up to 105 mph resulted in a widespread area of wind damage along the I-84 corridor in southern Dutchess County. ||Over 35,000 customers in Dutchess and Ulster Counties lost power as a result of the storms. Travel restrictions were issued for southern Dutchess County due to downed trees and malfunctioning traffic lights, and Amtrak and Metro North rail service was suspended in the county. The governor deployed 125 members of the National Guard to aid storm recovery efforts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail lasted three to four minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved through the central Appalachians on the 17th, driving a lot of low level moisture into the middle Ohio River Valley. While this system also pulled warmer air northward, it remained cold enough across southeastern Ohio for a period of snow during the early afternoon before changing over to rain by late afternoon. There was a narrow band that experienced a brief period of very heavy snow, with reports of 2 to 3 inches accumulating in an hour. This band was across portions of Jackson, Vinton, Athens, Meigs, and Washington Counties. Even across individual counties, snowfall accumulations varied drastically based on the location of the heaviest band. For example, in Meigs County, a member of the public measured just over 4 inches of snow near Tuppers Plains, while in Chester only 2 inches accumulated. In Washington County, 3 inches of snow was measured near Reno, with under an inch in Marietta. In Jackson County, the city of Jackson was hit hard where the cooperative observer measured 3 to 4 inches of snow in less than 2 hours, however the southern part of the county only got a couple inches.

Heavy rains over several days brought flooding to many rivers in Arkansas. Through 6 am CST on the 25th, four to more than ten inches of water was measured in a five day period. At many locations, this was two months of rain in just a few days. Amounts included 10.55 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 9.82 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County), and 8.83 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought flooding to the Fouche LaFave River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought flooding to the White River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the western side of the Appalachians Tuesday night, February 6th into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 7th. Initially the precipitation started as snow across the upper Ohio Valley. As the warm air surged north, precipitation type changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain. Locations in northern West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania changed over to rain with temperatures climbing into the upper 30s to lower 40s. Eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia Panhandle, and locations from central Beaver county, northeast into southern Jefferson county, Pennsylvania switched over to freezing rain. Ice accumulation was around a quarter of an inch for these places. Farther north along the I-80 corridor and parts of interior southeastern Ohio, cold air remained socked in, keeping the precipitation all snow. Several inches of snow fell with the highest amounts located across parts of northern Butler county northeast into Clarion, Jefferson, and Forest counties. For eastern Ohio, Columbiana, Carroll, southwest into Coshocton county around six inches of snow fell.

A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding reported at Brookside Rd and W Agua Caliente Rd.

The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bodega Highway at Salmon Creek closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold low pressure system brought snow levels down near sea level. Though temperatures at sea level were a bit too warm for much accumulating snow, up in the Cascade Foothills, snow accumulated quickly with amounts generally around 5 to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports on Twitter of 9 inches of snow on Mt Brynion, 3 miles east of Kelso, and 6 inches of snow near Yacolt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved through Arkansas on February 24th, bringing damaging winds, flash flooding, and a small tornado to Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators estimated wind gusts of 60 mph in Mena.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bitterly cold air and wind chill temperatures prevailed over southern WI from Christmas Day through January 6th. Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero occurred at times with low temperatures below zero for most nights. There are eight known deaths related to hypothermia.  Water main breaks and frozen pipes in homes and businesses were a common occurrence across southern WI. Some water damage occurred indoors due to pipes bursting. The cold conditions also caused pavement to buckle on the Beltline Highway in Madison on two separate occasions with one causing a 12 vehicle accident. Some public and private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 30 below zero, and low temperatures below zero occurred at times during this period of prolonged arctic air. Water main breaks and burst pipes occurred across the area. Some public and private events were cancelled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure over the Tennessee Valley on the morning of the 7th raced rapidly northeastward to the Canadian Maritimes by the morning of the 8th.  The storm brought heavy snow to much of western Maine.  Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 6 to 10 inches except for portions of York County where 4 to 6 inches fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very little rainfall fell during the winter months with very little snowfall as well.  This led to severe drought conditions creeping into portions of south central Kansas during the month of February 2018. The severe drought conditions worsened during the month, spreading north of Highway 50 and east to the Kansas Turnpike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions worsened during the month of February, 2018.  By the end of the month most of the county had climbed into the severe drought category.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 10 and 14 inches of snow across far northern Indiana on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration moderate to heavy snow event produced between 7 and 13 inches of snow on February 9th, heaviest across northern portions of Elkhart County. There was a report of 11.0 inches of total snow accumulation in Dunlap. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 10 and 14 inches of snow across far northern Indiana on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration moderate to heavy snow event produced between 6 and 11 inches of snow on February 9th, heaviest across northern portions of Steuben County. There was a report of 7.0 inches of total snow accumulation in Angola. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Before the month could end, there was another deluge on the horizon. An active southern stream of the jet drove a storm system toward the region on the 27th. The system triggered the next round of downpours. Rain and isolated thunderstorms arrived during the afternoon and evening of the 27th, and continued through much of the 28th. Two to more than four inches of rain was common in central and southern sections of the state.  Forty eight hour rainfall through 600 am CST on March 1st included 4.53 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County), 4.10 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 3.42 inches at Pine Bluff (Jefferson County), and 3.02 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Springfield Rd. was closed due to high water near the Conway and Faulkner County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 10 and 14 inches of snow across far northern Indiana on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow, heavy at times, produced between 2 and 6 inches of snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 9th. The heaviest snow was reported across far northern portions of the county. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 3 and 7 inches of snow across far northwest Ohio on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate to heavy snow produced between 2 and 5 inches of snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 9th. This created difficult travel, accidents, and school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, moderate at times, accompanied an upper level system that dropped 3 to 5 inches of snow on February 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow with temperatures falling through the 20s created difficult travel conditions on February 4th. Many locations received between 3 and 5 inches of total snow accumulation. There were reports of accidents and a few school closings the following day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains over several days brought flooding to many rivers in Arkansas. Through 6 am CST on the 25th, four to more than ten inches of water was measured in a five day period. At many locations, this was two months of rain in just a few days. Amounts included 10.55 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 9.82 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County), and 8.83 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought flooding to the Arkansas River at Morrilton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the western side of the Appalachians Tuesday night, February 6th into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 7th. Initially the precipitation started as snow across the upper Ohio Valley. As the warm air surged north, precipitation type changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain. Locations in northern West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania changed over to rain with temperatures climbing into the upper 30s to lower 40s. Eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia Panhandle, and locations from central Beaver county, northeast into southern Jefferson county, Pennsylvania switched over to freezing rain. Ice accumulation was around a quarter of an inch for these places. Farther north along the I-80 corridor and parts of interior southeastern Ohio, cold air remained socked in, keeping the precipitation all snow. Several inches of snow fell with the highest amounts located across parts of northern Butler county northeast into Clarion, Jefferson, and Forest counties. For eastern Ohio, Columbiana, Carroll, southwest into Coshocton county around six inches of snow fell.

A low pressure system moved through the central Appalachians on the 17th, driving a lot of low level moisture into the middle Ohio River Valley. While this system also pulled warmer air northward, it remained cold enough across southeastern Ohio for a period of snow during the early afternoon before changing over to rain by late afternoon. There was a narrow band that experienced a brief period of very heavy snow, with reports of 2 to 3 inches accumulating in an hour. This band was across portions of Jackson, Vinton, Athens, Meigs, and Washington Counties. Even across individual counties, snowfall accumulations varied drastically based on the location of the heaviest band. For example, in Meigs County, a member of the public measured just over 4 inches of snow near Tuppers Plains, while in Chester only 2 inches accumulated. In Washington County, 3 inches of snow was measured near Reno, with under an inch in Marietta. In Jackson County, the city of Jackson was hit hard where the cooperative observer measured 3 to 4 inches of snow in less than 2 hours, however the southern part of the county only got a couple inches.

A prolonged period of light to moderate rain led to flooding across portions of eastern Kentucky, particularly southeastern Kentucky, beginning during the overnight hours of Friday, February 9 into Saturday, February 10, 2018. This occurred along and ahead of a slow moving frontal boundary as generally between 1.5 and 4.5 inches of rain fell across eastern Kentucky. The hardest hit area was Harlan County, where flooding occurred across much of the county as up to 5.5 inches of rain fell. A state of emergency was declared as the Cumberland River at Baxter reached major flood stage, prompting the closure of all of the city of Harlan's floodgates. The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong but shallow cold front moved through East Texas during the afternoon hours of February 10th, with temperatures falling to or below freezing during the late evening hours. Weak overrunning atop this shallow arctic air mass resulted in patchy freezing drizzle developing around midnight throughout the early morning hours on February 11th across portions of Northeast Texas, resulting in icing of bridges across Lake Cypress Springs in Franklin County, as well as vehicles and elevated objects in Red River and Smith Counties. ||Temperatures remained at or below freezing across much of Northeast Texas during the daytime hours on February 11th, as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas, with light accumulations of sleet on grassy and road surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses throughout Smith, Wood, and Upshur Counties. Elsewhere across Northeast Texas, only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded, with very little if any impacts observed. ||In Smith County, 0.2 inches of sleet was recorded at Tyler, as well as areas from Lake Palestine near the Teaselville community to Flint, Whitehouse, and Bullard. In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.

A strong but shallow cold front moved through Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours on February 10th. Temperatures fell to freezing across much of Southwest Arkansas by daybreak on the 11th, and remained at or below freezing during the daytime hours as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas into Southwest Arkansas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas and Southwest Arkansas, but only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, Miller, and Lafayette Counties, with very little if any impacts observed.

An area of low pressure moved off the South Carolina coast on the morning of the 17th, then travelled rapidly northeast to the Gulf of Maine by the morning of the 18th.  The low then moved rapidly away from the area.  The low brought a heavy snowfall to the southwestern part of the State with snowfall amounts generally ranging from 6 to 9 inches.

An area of low pressure over the Tennessee Valley on the morning of the 7th raced rapidly northeastward to the Canadian Maritimes by the morning of the 8th.  The storm brought heavy snow to much of the State.  Snowfall amounts generally ranged from 6 to 10 inches across all but Rockingham and southern portions of Cheshire and Hillsborough Counties where 3 to 6 inches fell.

Bitterly cold air and wind chill temperatures prevailed over southern WI from Christmas Day through January 6th. Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero occurred at times with low temperatures below zero for most nights. There are eight known deaths related to hypothermia.  Water main breaks and frozen pipes in homes and businesses were a common occurrence across southern WI. Some water damage occurred indoors due to pipes bursting. The cold conditions also caused pavement to buckle on the Beltline Highway in Madison on two separate occasions with one causing a 12 vehicle accident. Some public and private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 30 below zero, and low temperatures below zero occurred at times during this period of prolonged arctic air. Water main breaks and burst pipes occurred across the area. Some public and private events were cancelled.

A frontal system was draped across the central Appalachians on the 10th and 11th. As waves moved along the front, periods of heavy rainfall moved across southern West Virginia. Rainfall started during the morning of the 10th, with the heaviest rain from late afternoon overnight into the 11th. The most rain fell across portions of Mingo, McDowell, Wyoming, Logan and Raleigh Counties, where 2-3 inches of rain fell with many roads closed due to flooding. The cooperative observer at Oceana in Wyoming County measured 2.56 inches of rain, and at R.D. Bailey Lake on the Wyoming/Mingo border, 2.37 inches was measured. The cooperative observer at Man in Logan County measured 2.2, while the VA Hospital in Beckley got 2.09 inches of rain. Farther north generally 1-2 inches of rain fell, which still caused some minor problems due to saturated ground. ||As the water drained through the creeks and streams, several rivers also flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along the Tug Fork near Kermit as the river rose just over 2 feet over flood stage of 38 feet.  Flooding first started around 6 PM on the 11th, and the river crested at 40.2 feet just before 3 AM on the 12th. The flooding subsided around 11 AM that morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal system was draped across the central Appalachians on the 10th and 11th. As waves moved along the front, periods of heavy rainfall moved across southern West Virginia. Rainfall started during the morning of the 10th, with the heaviest rain from late afternoon overnight into the 11th. The most rain fell across portions of Mingo, McDowell, Wyoming, Logan and Raleigh Counties, where 2-3 inches of rain fell with many roads closed due to flooding. The cooperative observer at Oceana in Wyoming County measured 2.56 inches of rain, and at R.D. Bailey Lake on the Wyoming/Mingo border, 2.37 inches was measured. The cooperative observer at Man in Logan County measured 2.2, while the VA Hospital in Beckley got 2.09 inches of rain. Farther north generally 1-2 inches of rain fell, which still caused some minor problems due to saturated ground. ||As the water drained through the creeks and streams, several rivers also flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to high water. This included Route 19 in both Cool Ridge and Shady Spring. Odd Road in Ghent was closed due to flooding along Laurel Creek. Coal City Road was also closed near Coal City. Beaver Creek flooded, closing C and O Dam Road near Daniels. Winding Gulf and Tommy Creeks both flooded near Amigo, and a rock slide closed Tams Highway near Helen. Stonecoal Creek and Riffe Branch also flooded near Eastgulf.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Before the month could end, there was another deluge on the horizon. An active southern stream of the jet drove a storm system toward the region on the 27th. The system triggered the next round of downpours. Rain and isolated thunderstorms arrived during the afternoon and evening of the 27th, and continued through much of the 28th. Two to more than four inches of rain was common in central and southern sections of the state.  Forty eight hour rainfall through 600 am CST on March 1st included 4.53 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County), 4.10 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 3.42 inches at Pine Bluff (Jefferson County), and 3.02 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread Flash Flooding was ongoing in and near the communities of Alexander, Shannon Hills, Bauxite, Sardis and Bryant in Saline County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ridge Rd. in El Paso was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system slid down the coast and stayed offshore, pulling cold air from east of the Cascades into southwest Washington. This brought snow levels down to sea level, and moisture from the low pressure system meant snow down to sea level around Vancouver and along the lower Columbia River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report via social media of 7.0 inches North of Battleground.  Another report via Facebook of 8.0 inches of snow  at 750 ft in Battleground. Elsewhere around the Vancouver area there were several reports of 4 to 6 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observer reported 8.0 inches of snow 9 miles north of Yacolt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist low pressure system brought heavy snow to the Cascades. Snow levels started around 1500 ft but rose to settle around 2500 ft for the rest of the event, with most of the snow falling above 2500 ft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SNOTEL sites and NWAC stations above 3,000 feet recorded anywhere from 13 to 18 inches of snow from this event, with highest amounts at higher elevations, generally above 5,000 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extreme and severe drought persisted in western north Texas through the first half of the month. Toward the last week of February, rainfall brought some relief to the eastern parts of this area, pushing the severe and extreme drought westward a bit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved off the South Carolina coast on the morning of the 17th, then travelled rapidly northeast to the Gulf of Maine by the morning of the 18th.  The low then moved rapidly away from the area.  The low brought a heavy snowfall to the southwestern part of the State with snowfall amounts generally ranging from 6 to 9 inches.
Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 10 and 14 inches of snow across far northern Indiana on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow, heavy at times, produced between 2 and 7 inches of snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 9th. The heaviest snow was reported across far northern portions of the county. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the western side of the Appalachians Tuesday night, February 6th into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 7th. Initially the precipitation started as snow across the upper Ohio Valley. As the warm air surged north, precipitation type changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain. Locations in northern West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania changed over to rain with temperatures climbing into the upper 30s to lower 40s. Eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia Panhandle, and locations from central Beaver county, northeast into southern Jefferson county, Pennsylvania switched over to freezing rain. Ice accumulation was around a quarter of an inch for these places. Farther north along the I-80 corridor and parts of interior southeastern Ohio, cold air remained socked in, keeping the precipitation all snow. Several inches of snow fell with the highest amounts located across parts of northern Butler county northeast into Clarion, Jefferson, and Forest counties. For eastern Ohio, Columbiana, Carroll, southwest into Coshocton county around six inches of snow fell.

A frontal system was draped across the central Appalachians on the 10th and 11th. As waves moved along the front, periods of heavy rainfall moved across southern West Virginia. Rainfall started during the morning of the 10th, with the heaviest rain from late afternoon overnight into the 11th. The most rain fell across portions of Mingo, McDowell, Wyoming, Logan and Raleigh Counties, where 2-3 inches of rain fell with many roads closed due to flooding. The cooperative observer at Oceana in Wyoming County measured 2.56 inches of rain, and at R.D. Bailey Lake on the Wyoming/Mingo border, 2.37 inches was measured. The cooperative observer at Man in Logan County measured 2.2, while the VA Hospital in Beckley got 2.09 inches of rain. Farther north generally 1-2 inches of rain fell, which still caused some minor problems due to saturated ground. ||As the water drained through the creeks and streams, several rivers also flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Big Branch flooded, causing high water to close Route 152 near Dunlow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Before the month could end, there was another deluge on the horizon. An active southern stream of the jet drove a storm system toward the region on the 27th. The system triggered the next round of downpours. Rain and isolated thunderstorms arrived during the afternoon and evening of the 27th, and continued through much of the 28th. Two to more than four inches of rain was common in central and southern sections of the state.  Forty eight hour rainfall through 600 am CST on March 1st included 4.53 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County), 4.10 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 3.42 inches at Pine Bluff (Jefferson County), and 3.02 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sorrells Rd. at Old Warren Rd. was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding reported at Sexton Road and Bodega Highway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Arctic cold front moved across the region on the 1st. Temperatures were warm ahead of the front, and a lot of the precipitation fell as rain. However, cold air rushed in during the evening, changing the rain to snow. Moisture was already pulling out of the lowlands by this time, but enough remained across the southern and central mountainous counties to give a quick dose of accumulating snow. The highest amounts were measured in southeastern Raleigh and Fayette counties, where 5 to 7 inches of snow accumulated from the 1st into the morning of the 2nd. The snow observer near the Beckley Airport measured 6.8 inches, and the cooperative observer at the VA Hospital in Beckley got 5.5 inches. Around 5 inches was reported in the southeastern portions of Fayette and Nicholas Counties by broadcast media and CoCoRAHS observers. There very highest elevations of Pocahontas, Randolph and Webster got 4 to 6 inches. ||Outside of these higher amounts, generally 1 to 3 inches of snow accumulated across the southern Coal Fields and mountainous counties.

Low pressure over the northeast Pacific on the 17th moved southeast, reaching northern California on the 18th. This system brought high winds and snowfall to the Sierra Nevada and northeastern California.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bitterly cold air and wind chill temperatures prevailed over southern WI from Christmas Day through January 6th. Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero occurred at times with low temperatures below zero for most nights. There are eight known deaths related to hypothermia.  Water main breaks and frozen pipes in homes and businesses were a common occurrence across southern WI. Some water damage occurred indoors due to pipes bursting. The cold conditions also caused pavement to buckle on the Beltline Highway in Madison on two separate occasions with one causing a 12 vehicle accident. Some public and private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero, and low temperatures below zero occurred at times during this period of prolonged arctic air. Water main breaks and burst pipes occurred across the area. Some public and private events were cancelled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking from Iowa across southeast WI and into Lower MI brought a long duration snow event to southern WI. Lake enhanced snow also contributed to the snow totals near Lake MI. Snow amounts ranged from 2-7 inches inland from Lake MI, to 6-14 inches near Lake MI. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred. Some private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to seven inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal system was draped across the central Appalachians on the 10th and 11th. As waves moved along the front, periods of heavy rainfall moved across southern West Virginia. Rainfall started during the morning of the 10th, with the heaviest rain from late afternoon overnight into the 11th. The most rain fell across portions of Mingo, McDowell, Wyoming, Logan and Raleigh Counties, where 2-3 inches of rain fell with many roads closed due to flooding. The cooperative observer at Oceana in Wyoming County measured 2.56 inches of rain, and at R.D. Bailey Lake on the Wyoming/Mingo border, 2.37 inches was measured. The cooperative observer at Man in Logan County measured 2.2, while the VA Hospital in Beckley got 2.09 inches of rain. Farther north generally 1-2 inches of rain fell, which still caused some minor problems due to saturated ground. ||As the water drained through the creeks and streams, several rivers also flooded.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tug Fork at Williamson surged into moderate flood stage on the 11th. The river first rose above its flood stage of 27 feet just after 7 AM on the 11th. It surpassed moderate flood stage of 32 feet at 11:30 AM, and crested near 36 feet around 5:30 that evening. The river dropped back below flood stage at 6 AM on the 12th. The moderate flooding on the Tug closed multiple roads in and around Williamson. This included Route 612, and Harvey Street. The rail yard was also flooded by water from the Tug.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An oscillating surface boundary with multiple waves of low pressure brought periods of moderate to heavy rainfall from the 22nd into the 25th. This caused another round of flooding on small creeks and streams across the middle Ohio River Valley, and eventually lead to minor flooding on the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor street flooding occurred on several roads in Huntington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 10 and 14 inches of snow across far northern Indiana on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration moderate to heavy snow event produced between 9 and 15 inches of snow on February 9th. There was a report of 15.0 inches of total snow accumulation in Granger. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the 7th through 9th, North-Central and Southwest Montana resided underneath northwesterly flow aloft associated with the polar front jet stream. In addition, multiple disturbances embedded within this flow interacted with a frontal boundary that wavered over the area from southwest to northeast and vice versa. The resulting lift, combined with abundant moisture in the low- to mid-level atmosphere, contributed to the formation of periods of snow over North-Central and Southwest Montana. In addition, it is believed mesoscale bands of heavy snow that affected portions of North-Central Montana on the 8th into early morning of the 9th were tied to frontogenesis in the 850 mb to 700 mb layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Montana DOT reported severe driving conditions along MT-464 (i.e. Duck Lake Road) from Browning to 12 miles north of Browning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of localized freezing rain occurred in northcentral Mendocino County on February 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two collisions occurred due to freezing rain on February 24th south of the Leggett area. The first collision occurred at 830 AM PST, and was located on US-101 north of mile post marker 101 MEN 83.35. One person sustained suspected minor injuries. The second collision, which occurred at 845 AM PST, was located on US-101 south of mile post marker 101 MEN 81.98, and there were no injuries sustained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Arctic front dropped temperatures into the upper 20s and lower 30s, followed by overrunning precipitation, leading to significant amounts of freezing rain across the northwestern third of the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported five-hundredths of an inch of freezing rain in the city of Dublin, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Arctic front dropped temperatures into the upper 20s and lower 30s, followed by overrunning precipitation, leading to significant amounts of freezing rain across the northwestern third of the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report indicated a hundredth of an inch of freezing rain approximately 4 miles north of the city of Cisco, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the western side of the Appalachians Tuesday night, February 6th into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 7th. Initially the precipitation started as snow across the upper Ohio Valley. As the warm air surged north, precipitation type changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain. Locations in northern West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania changed over to rain with temperatures climbing into the upper 30s to lower 40s. Eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia Panhandle, and locations from central Beaver county, northeast into southern Jefferson county, Pennsylvania switched over to freezing rain. Ice accumulation was around a quarter of an inch for these places. Farther north along the I-80 corridor and parts of interior southeastern Ohio, cold air remained socked in, keeping the precipitation all snow. Several inches of snow fell with the highest amounts located across parts of northern Butler county northeast into Clarion, Jefferson, and Forest counties. For eastern Ohio, Columbiana, Carroll, southwest into Coshocton county around six inches of snow fell.
Snow, moderate at times, accompanied an upper level system that dropped 2 to 6 inches of snow on February 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow with temperatures falling through the 20s created difficult travel conditions on February 4th. Many locations received between 2 and 4 inches of total snow accumulation. There were reports of accidents and a few school closings the following day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the 7th through 9th, North-Central and Southwest Montana resided underneath northwesterly flow aloft associated with the polar front jet stream. In addition, multiple disturbances embedded within this flow interacted with a frontal boundary that wavered over the area from southwest to northeast and vice versa. The resulting lift, combined with abundant moisture in the low- to mid-level atmosphere, contributed to the formation of periods of snow over North-Central and Southwest Montana. In addition, it is believed mesoscale bands of heavy snow that affected portions of North-Central Montana on the 8th into early morning of the 9th were tied to frontogenesis in the 850 mb to 700 mb layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter located 16-miles WSW of Bynum reported 6-inches of new snow in 12-hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist low pressure system brought heavy snow to the Cascades. Snow levels started around 1500 ft but rose to settle around 2500 ft for the rest of the event, with most of the snow falling above 2500 ft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SNOTEL sites recorded 12 to 17 inches of snow from this event. McKenzie SNOTEL recorded 17 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist low pressure system brought heavy snow to the Cascades. Snow levels started around 1500 feet but rose to settle around 2500 feet for the rest of the event, with most of the snow falling above 2500 feet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pinto Rock SNOTEL recorded 14 inches of snow, and June Lake SNOTEL recorded 12 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow band of heavy snow fell across portions of central and east central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of February 5th.  Storm total snowfall amounts included 8.0 inches in Cornell; 7.5 inches in Odell; 6.4 inches in Streator and 6.0 inches in Beaverville.

A narrow band of heavy snow fell across portions of central and east central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of February 5th.  Storm total snowfall amounts included 8.0 inches in Cornell; 7.5 inches in Odell; 6.4 inches in Streator and 6.0 inches in Beaverville.
Very heavy rain fell across northwest Indiana on February 19th and February 20th which caused areal flooding across some areas and major flooding on some rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many areas of Newton County were flooded with some roads flooded and closed.  A storm total rainfall of 6.11 inches was measured three miles east southeast of Conrad.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rain fell across northwest Indiana on February 19th and February 20th which caused areal flooding across some areas and major flooding on some rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many areas of Lake County were flooded with some roads flooded and closed.  In Lake Station, a voluntary evacuation order was issued as the Deep River overflowed its banks and began to flood nearby homes.  Storm total rainfall of 4.44 inches of rain was measured one mile north of Crown Point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rounds of cold air continued surging toward Arkansas to begin February. On the 6th, readings were at or below freezing in northwest sections of the state, and subfreezing air spread slowly to the southeast. A storm system over the middle of the country provided moisture, and there was a potential for wintry precipitation.  The incoming cold air was shallow, with warmer conditions (above freezing) overhead. Any snow or sleet would surely melt aloft, but would likely turn to ice (freezing rain) upon reaching the ground. During the nighttime hours of the 6th and early on the 7th, a Winter Weather Advisory was posted across northern Arkansas, with an Ice Storm Warning and up to a quarter inch of ice in the northeast.  For the most part, moisture tended to build over the southern and eastern counties, and stayed out of the north. Any ice in the north was minor and spotty. In the northeast, while there was some ice on trees and power lines (leading to spotty power outages), temperatures did not go much below 32 degrees and roads were generally wet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ice accumulated to around 1/4 inch, mostly on elevated surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure moved off the South Carolina coast on the morning of the 17th, then travelled rapidly northeast to the Gulf of Maine by the morning of the 18th.  The low then moved rapidly away from the area.  The low brought a heavy snowfall to the southwestern part of the State with snowfall amounts generally ranging from 6 to 9 inches.

Bitterly cold air and wind chill temperatures prevailed over southern WI from Christmas Day through January 6th. Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 34 below zero occurred at times with low temperatures below zero for most nights. There are eight known deaths related to hypothermia.  Water main breaks and frozen pipes in homes and businesses were a common occurrence across southern WI. Some water damage occurred indoors due to pipes bursting. The cold conditions also caused pavement to buckle on the Beltline Highway in Madison on two separate occasions with one causing a 12 vehicle accident. Some public and private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill temperatures of 20 below to 30 below zero, and low temperatures below zero occurred at times during this period of prolonged arctic air. Water main breaks and burst pipes occurred across the area. Some public and private events were cancelled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms developed across North and Central Texas Wednesday Feb 28 as a deep upper trough moved through the Southern Plains. Training thunderstorms across the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex led to widespread urban flooding and localized Flash Flooding in the DFW area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported multiple water rescues near the intersection of Jeanette Way and North Denton Dr in the city of Carrollton, TX.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Carrollton Police Department reported that Luna Rd south of Belt Line Rd was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions developed across several locations generally along and west of the Interstate 35 corridor by early February. Significant rainfall during the Feb 20-28 time frame led to much improved conditions for the majority of the region by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions for most of February improved during the final week of the month due to multiple days of beneficial rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Before the month could end, there was another deluge on the horizon. An active southern stream of the jet drove a storm system toward the region on the 27th. The system triggered the next round of downpours. Rain and isolated thunderstorms arrived during the afternoon and evening of the 27th, and continued through much of the 28th. Two to more than four inches of rain was common in central and southern sections of the state.  Forty eight hour rainfall through 600 am CST on March 1st included 4.53 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County), 4.10 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 3.42 inches at Pine Bluff (Jefferson County), and 3.02 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heathscott Rd. near Georgetown was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved through the central Appalachians on the 17th, driving a lot of low level moisture into the middle Ohio River Valley. While this system also pulled warmer air northward, it remained cold enough across southeastern Ohio for a period of snow during the early afternoon before changing over to rain by late afternoon. There was a narrow band that experienced a brief period of very heavy snow, with reports of 2 to 3 inches accumulating in an hour. This band was across portions of Jackson, Vinton, Athens, Meigs, and Washington Counties. Even across individual counties, snowfall accumulations varied drastically based on the location of the heaviest band. For example, in Meigs County, a member of the public measured just over 4 inches of snow near Tuppers Plains, while in Chester only 2 inches accumulated. In Washington County, 3 inches of snow was measured near Reno, with under an inch in Marietta. In Jackson County, the city of Jackson was hit hard where the cooperative observer measured 3 to 4 inches of snow in less than 2 hours, however the southern part of the county only got a couple inches.

A low pressure system moved through the central Appalachians on the 17th, driving a lot of low level moisture into West Virginia. While this system also pulled warmer air northward resulting in heavy rain across the southern part of the state, it remained cold enough across northern West Virginia for a period of snow before transitioning to brief sleet or freezing rain, and then all rain. There was a narrow band that experienced a brief period of very heavy snow, with reports of 1 to 2 inches accumulating in an hour. This band was across portions of Wood, Pleasants, Ritchie and Tyler Counties. Even across individual counties, snowfall accumulations varied drastically based on the location of the heaviest band. For example, in Wood County, a member social media postings indicated 3 to 4 inches of snow across the southern part of the county, while near Parkersburg the US Army Corps of Engineers measured 1.5 inches. In Ritchie County, the emergency manager measured 3 inches before the snow changed to rain. Pleasants and Tyler Counties saw 2 to 3 inches of snow measured by CoCoRaHS volunteers and social media users.||Colder air lingered a bit longer across the higher mountains, namely in Pocahontas County where 3 to 6 inches of snow fell. For example, the cooperative observer at Snowshoe measured 6 inches, 5 inches of snow fell in near Bartow, and the observer in Frost received 4 inches.

Heavy rains over several days brought flooding to many rivers in Arkansas. Through 6 am CST on the 25th, four to more than ten inches of water was measured in a five day period. At many locations, this was two months of rain in just a few days. Amounts included 10.55 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 9.82 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County), and 8.83 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought flooding to the Saline River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong but shallow cold front moved through East Texas during the afternoon hours of February 10th, with temperatures falling to or below freezing during the late evening hours. Weak overrunning atop this shallow arctic air mass resulted in patchy freezing drizzle developing around midnight throughout the early morning hours on February 11th across portions of Northeast Texas, resulting in icing of bridges across Lake Cypress Springs in Franklin County, as well as vehicles and elevated objects in Red River and Smith Counties. ||Temperatures remained at or below freezing across much of Northeast Texas during the daytime hours on February 11th, as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas, with light accumulations of sleet on grassy and road surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses throughout Smith, Wood, and Upshur Counties. Elsewhere across Northeast Texas, only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded, with very little if any impacts observed. ||In Smith County, 0.2 inches of sleet was recorded at Tyler, as well as areas from Lake Palestine near the Teaselville community to Flint, Whitehouse, and Bullard. In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.

A band of snow dropped southward across southern Missouri. A brief period of moderate snow within the band dropped visbilities to near 1/2 mile at times. This band of snow was accompanied by a surge of colder air which dropped temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of snow impacted Interstate 44 resulting in reduced visibilities and snow and ice covered pavement leading to a multiple vehicle accident northeast of Lebanon, with numerous injuries and 1 fatality.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County comms reported several trees blown down and blocking trails in South Mountains State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County comms reported a tree blown down on a power line in the Henrietta area and another tree down on a power line near the Cleveland County line west of Mooresboro.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County comms reported a few trees blown down in the Hudson area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ham radio operator reported quarter size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of hail up to around 2 inches in diameter were received from the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved southeast across Northeast Texas, Southwest Arkansas, and Northern Louisiana during early morning hours of February 6th. Meanwhile, overrunning increased during the daytime hours which led to the development of scattered showers behind the front, which developed into embedded thunderstorms as upper level disturbances shifted northeast across the area enhancing large scale lift, ahead of an upper level shortwave trough which moved into the Southern Plains during the afternoon from the Four Corners region. Steep lapse rates ahead of this shortwave trough contributed to elevated instability aloft, with deep layer shear also adequate enough for some organized post-frontal thunderstorms within a cool air mass with surface temperatures in the lower 50s. As a result, a few of these storms became severe, producing numerous reports of small and large hail across portions of Northeast Texas during the afternoon hours. The strong to severe thunderstorms diminished by early evening as the post-frontal rains became more widespread across the area, thus diminishing the elevated instability.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail fell on the southwest wide of Lindale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 10 and 14 inches of snow across far northern Indiana on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration moderate to heavy snow event produced between 6 and 11 inches of snow on February 9th, heaviest across northern portions of Lagrange County. There was a report of 7.9 inches of total snow accumulation in Lagrange. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper produced a brief burst of snow late February 5th into the early morning hours of February 6th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quick 3 to 5 inches of snow created difficult travel conditions. There were accidents reported across the region, along with several school closings and delays on February 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Arctic cold front moved across the region on the 1st. Temperatures were warm ahead of the front, and a lot of the precipitation fell as rain. However, cold air rushed in during the evening, changing the rain to snow. Moisture was already pulling out of the lowlands by this time, but enough remained across the southern and central mountainous counties to give a quick dose of accumulating snow. The highest amounts were measured in southeastern Raleigh and Fayette counties, where 5 to 7 inches of snow accumulated from the 1st into the morning of the 2nd. The snow observer near the Beckley Airport measured 6.8 inches, and the cooperative observer at the VA Hospital in Beckley got 5.5 inches. Around 5 inches was reported in the southeastern portions of Fayette and Nicholas Counties by broadcast media and CoCoRAHS observers. There very highest elevations of Pocahontas, Randolph and Webster got 4 to 6 inches. ||Outside of these higher amounts, generally 1 to 3 inches of snow accumulated across the southern Coal Fields and mountainous counties.

A strong cold front approached Eastern NC late on January 12th, 2018. A shortwave trough moved through the area prior to the cold front, with high-shear and limited instability, leading to several marine thunderstorm wind gusts across the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: WeatherFlow site at Hatteras High observed a 53 knot marine thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system in the Gulf of Alaska combined with a high pressure system over the mainland to cause a tight gradient through the Chugach Range. This was further enhanced by a cold dome of air located over the Copper River Basin, bringing high winds to Thompson Pass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road Weather Information System station in Thompson Pass (Elev 2740 ft) reported gust of 80 mph starting at 2:50pm 1/28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system in the Gulf of Alaska formed a new center close to the Prince William Sound. As this low brought a trough through the Prince William Sound area, the trough combined with a dome of cold air over the Copper River Basin to cause blizzard conditions through the gaps of the Chugach Range.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from DOT Maintenance Camp in Thompson Pass indicated variable visibility between 0-100 ft. Worst conditions between miles 25-28 on the Richardson Highway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system in the Gulf of Alaska shifted westward towards Kodiak Island, tightening the pressure gradient. A series of troughs increased the winds over the Alaska Peninsula and caused near blizzard conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: King Cove AWOS reported a peak gust of 67 knots at 5:23 p.m. on January 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tight pressure gradients across the area resulted in some high wind gusts across portions of Northern Sweet Grass County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 mph was reported 13 miles southwest of Greycliff.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tight pressure gradients along the Upper Stillwater Valley resulted in very strong wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 75 mph was recorded at the Stillwater Mine.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and light winds accompanying an Arctic ridge of high pressure resulted in significant nocturnal cooling on New Year's Eve evening into the morning of New Year's Day, prompting a wind chill warning for portions of North-Central Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Havre Airport ASOS reported wind chill of -56F with sustained wind of 13 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and light winds accompanying an Arctic ridge of high pressure resulted in significant nocturnal cooling on New Year's Eve evening into the morning of New Year's Day, prompting a wind chill warning for portions of North-Central Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: MT DOT station near Inverness reported wind chill of -51F and sustained wind of 12 mph.

A strong low pressure system moved through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 7th. North and west of this low, surface temperatures remained at or below freezing. This resulted in a period of freezing rain, sleet and snow. Ice accretion of 0.25 to 0.3 inches occurred in a strip across Vinton, Athens, Perry and Morgan County. Scattered power outages occurred across Perry and Morgan counties where the widespread icing brought down trees and power lines. There was a sharp line between the freezing rain/sleet, and where it was all snow. The far northwestern corner of Perry County got several inches of snow instead of the ice. Closer to the Ohio River, generally a light coating up to 0.2 inches of ice was measured through mid morning, before temperatures rose above freezing.

A warm front lifted through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 6th. Surface temperatures across portions of West Virginia remained at or below freezing through mid morning while temperatures above the surface had already warmed above freezing. This resulted in a period of light freezing drizzle, with a light coating of ice across a narrow swath of central and western West Virginia.

A warm front lifted through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 6th. Surface temperatures across portions of West Virginia remained at or below freezing through mid morning while temperatures above the surface had already warmed above freezing. This resulted in a period of light freezing drizzle, with a light coating of ice across a narrow swath of central and western West Virginia.

A cold front moved southeast across Northeast Texas, Southwest Arkansas, and Northern Louisiana during early morning hours of February 6th. Meanwhile, overrunning increased during the daytime hours which led to the development of scattered showers behind the front, which developed into embedded thunderstorms as upper level disturbances shifted northeast across the area enhancing large scale lift, ahead of an upper level shortwave trough which moved into the Southern Plains during the afternoon from the Four Corners region. Steep lapse rates ahead of this shortwave trough contributed to elevated instability aloft, with deep layer shear also adequate enough for some organized post-frontal thunderstorms within a cool air mass with surface temperatures in the lower 50s. As a result, a few of these storms became severe, producing numerous reports of small and large hail across portions of Northeast Texas during the afternoon hours. The strong to severe thunderstorms diminished by early evening as the post-frontal rains became more widespread across the area, thus diminishing the elevated instability.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime size hail fell in South Tyler.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail fell in the Hideaway Lake Subdivision.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 3 and 7 inches of snow across far northwest Ohio on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of moderate to heavy snow produced between 3 and 7 inches of snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 9th, heaviest across far northwest portions of the county. There was a report of 5.5 inches of total snow accumulation in Bryan. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper produced a brief burst of snow late February 5th into the early morning hours of February 6th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quick 4 to 6 inches of snow created difficult travel conditions. There were accidents reported across the region, along with several school closings and delays on February 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong but shallow cold front moved through East Texas during the afternoon hours of February 10th, with temperatures falling to or below freezing during the late evening hours. Weak overrunning atop this shallow arctic air mass resulted in patchy freezing drizzle developing around midnight throughout the early morning hours on February 11th across portions of Northeast Texas, resulting in icing of bridges across Lake Cypress Springs in Franklin County, as well as vehicles and elevated objects in Red River and Smith Counties. ||Temperatures remained at or below freezing across much of Northeast Texas during the daytime hours on February 11th, as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas, with light accumulations of sleet on grassy and road surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses throughout Smith, Wood, and Upshur Counties. Elsewhere across Northeast Texas, only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded, with very little if any impacts observed. ||In Smith County, 0.2 inches of sleet was recorded at Tyler, as well as areas from Lake Palestine near the Teaselville community to Flint, Whitehouse, and Bullard. In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.

In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.

A strong low pressure system moved through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 7th. North and west of this low, surface temperatures remained at or below freezing. This resulted in a period of freezing rain, sleet and snow. Ice accretion of 0.25 to 0.3 inches occurred in a strip across Vinton, Athens, Perry and Morgan County. Scattered power outages occurred across Perry and Morgan counties where the widespread icing brought down trees and power lines. There was a sharp line between the freezing rain/sleet, and where it was all snow. The far northwestern corner of Perry County got several inches of snow instead of the ice. Closer to the Ohio River, generally a light coating up to 0.2 inches of ice was measured through mid morning, before temperatures rose above freezing.

In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.
Heavy rain developed across portions of the region in association with a cold front. Some of this heavy rain produced flash flooding. A weak tornado also touched down in Neshoba County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stowood Road was flooded. There was street flooding at The Highlands with some homes being threatened by flood waters.

A band of snow dropped southward across southern Missouri. A brief period of moderate snow within the band dropped visbilities to near 1/2 mile at times. This band of snow was accompanied by a surge of colder air which dropped temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and Ice covered roads lead to a multiple vehicle accident on Interstate 44, 6 miles east of Marshfield. This lead to a number of injuries and 1 fatality. One inch of snow was reported 2 miles northeast of Northview in Webster county at 17:35 local standard time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding at 6th St on ramp to I-280 S 8 to 10 inches of water in number 1 and 2 lanes.
