EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, heavy at times, accumulated to between 9 and 15 inches of snow across southern Michigan on February 9th creating hazardous travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long duration moderate to heavy snow event produced between 10 and 15 inches of snow on February 9th. There was a report of 12.5 inches of total snow accumulation in Buchanon. This created difficult travel, accidents, and numerous school closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Arctic cold front moved across the region on the 1st. Temperatures were warm ahead of the front, and a lot of the precipitation fell as rain. However, cold air rushed in during the evening, changing the rain to snow. Moisture was already pulling out of the lowlands by this time, but enough remained across the southern and central mountainous counties to give a quick dose of accumulating snow. The highest amounts were measured in southeastern Raleigh and Fayette counties, where 5 to 7 inches of snow accumulated from the 1st into the morning of the 2nd. The snow observer near the Beckley Airport measured 6.8 inches, and the cooperative observer at the VA Hospital in Beckley got 5.5 inches. Around 5 inches was reported in the southeastern portions of Fayette and Nicholas Counties by broadcast media and CoCoRAHS observers. There very highest elevations of Pocahontas, Randolph and Webster got 4 to 6 inches. ||Outside of these higher amounts, generally 1 to 3 inches of snow accumulated across the southern Coal Fields and mountainous counties.

As a wave of low pressure developed and moved along a stationary front over the Deep South, moisture spread into western North Carolina during the early morning hours of the 4th. The precipitation began as a mixture of rain, sleet, and snow in many areas. While some light accumulation of sleet and snow was reported across the mountain valleys, all areas except for the high peaks and ridge tops transitioned to freezing rain by mid-morning. Most of any measurable ice was reported in the Piedmont and foothills, where amounts of .1 to .2 inch were common. Due to temperatures hovering right around freezing, roads generally remained wet, and ice accretion was primarily confined to elevated surfaces and vegetation. Meanwhile, snowfall of 5-7 inches was reported above about 5000 feet.
Abundant Pacific moisture brought heavy snow to the Absaroka/Beartooth Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fisher Creek and White Mill Snotels, along with Cooke City, received about 20 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant Pacific moisture brought heavy snow to the Absaroka/Beartooth Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fisher Creek and Mystic Lake Snotels each received about 12 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air aloft brought a period of freezing rain to portions of the Billings Forecast Area. This was followed by an arctic air intrusion. Once the arctic air was in place, a moist flow aloft off the Pacific Ocean produced an overrunning snow event. As a result, heavy snow occurred across a large portion of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hysham received 7 to 9 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air aloft brought a period of freezing rain to portions of the Billings Forecast Area. This was followed by an arctic air intrusion. Once the arctic air was in place, a moist flow aloft off the Pacific Ocean produced an overrunning snow event. As a result, heavy snow occurred across a large portion of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5 to 7 inches was reported across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong occluded low tracked northeast across far southeast WI. An area of showers and thunderstorms transitioned to moderate to heavy snowfall over southeast WI. |6-9 inches of snow accumulation occurred in Walworth County and western portions of Racine and Kenosha Counties. Lesser amounts of snow occurred surrounding this area but still with icy and snow covered roads. Schools were closed and some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of snow accumulation in the southeast portion of the county with one to three inches elsewhere.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong occluded low tracked northeast across far southeast WI. An area of showers and thunderstorms transitioned to moderate to heavy snowfall over southeast WI. |6-9 inches of snow accumulation occurred in Walworth County and western portions of Racine and Kenosha Counties. Lesser amounts of snow occurred surrounding this area but still with icy and snow covered roads. Schools were closed and some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to nine inches of snow accumulation with the highest amounts in the eastern portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A widespread snow event took place over Iowa and Illinois during the day through evening on the February, 5th, 2018. In most locations, this event produced a widespread 3 to 6 inch accumulation in about 12 hours, which combined with very light winds, to produce moderate impacts corresponding to a Winter Weather Advisory. A band of much heavier snow fell on the south edge of the widespread snow event, and was only 20 to 30 miles wide, but generally stretched across Iowa and Illinois along a line from near Grinnell, Iowa, to near Wapello, Iowa, to just north of Galesburg, Illinois. In that narrow axis, 7 to 10 inches of snow was observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather spotters and public all reported 7 to 9 inches of snow.

A strong but shallow cold front moved through Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours on February 10th. Temperatures fell to freezing across much of Southwest Arkansas by daybreak on the 11th, and remained at or below freezing during the daytime hours as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas into Southwest Arkansas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas and Southwest Arkansas, but only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, Miller, and Lafayette Counties, with very little if any impacts observed.

A strong but shallow cold front moved through Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours on February 10th. Temperatures fell to freezing across much of Southwest Arkansas by daybreak on the 11th, and remained at or below freezing during the daytime hours as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas into Southwest Arkansas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas and Southwest Arkansas, but only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, Miller, and Lafayette Counties, with very little if any impacts observed.

An upper level trough shifted southeast through the Great Basin into New Mexico during the late afternoon hours of the 10th. A strong cold front had shifted southwest into the eastern plains of New Mexico prior to the arrival of the upper level wave. Areas of freezing fog, light snow, and cold temperatures impacted eastern New Mexico behind the front. Meanwhile, another cold front in association with the upper level wave crossed into northwestern New Mexico and helped force a well-defined band of snow into the northern and western high terrain during the late evening hours of the 11th. The two fronts merged along the central mountain chain before shifting southward into southern New Mexico. The combination of cold temperatures and light snow along the Interstate 25 corridor produced severe travel conditions between Colmor and Las Vegas. Icy conditions along the Interstate 40 corridor near Gallup produced a motor vehicle accident that briefly shut down the highway. The east slope of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains benefited the most out of this system with snowfall amounts of six to nine inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 inches combined with cold temperatures produced hazardous travel conditions along the I-40 corridor between Gallup and Grants. A motor vehicle accident a few miles east of Gallup briefly shut down the highway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches combined with very cold temperatures created severe travel conditions for several hours along the I-25 corridor between Colmor and Las Vegas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: US 101 at 3rd Ave on ramp, severe flooding in 1 lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a relatively mild January and first few days of February, an arctic air mass came over the Continental Divide into Northwest Montana during the morning of February 3 bringing strong winds, heavy snow, and localized freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic air-mass moved over the Continental Divide into West-Central Montana during the evening of the 3rd, leading to snow, blowing snow, and icy roads. Wind gusts of 35 to 45 miles per hour combined with falling snow led to low visibility and drifting snow.  Widespread snow amounts of 3 to 6 inches were measured with isolated totals to 12 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another push of arctic air came back over the Continental Divide the evening of the 4th, reaching Kalispell during the morning commute on the 5th. Winds were not as strong along U.S. Highway 2 as the previous day but were stronger in Kalispell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe driving conditions occurred on U.S. Highway 2 from late on the 4th to early on the 5th due to a combination of freezing rain, heavy snow, blowing snow, and icy roads. Snow amounts of 4 to 8 inches were common with wind gusts to 35 miles per hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Saturated soils caused by abundant rainfall during early February lead to a fallen tree and traffic accident on US Highway 12.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain lead to a fallen tree across U.S. Highway 12 near milepost 52 and subsequent car accident at 4:08 am on the 5th. One person was injured in the incident and the highway was blocked for one and a half hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air once again spilled over the Divide the morning of the 8th leading to a period of gusty winds, blowing snow, moderate to heavy snowfall, icy conditions and much colder temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe driving conditions were observed on U.S. Highway 2 due to a combination of falling snow and blowing snow as winds gusted to 50 mph. Power outages were also noted around Bad Rock Canyon and Swan Lake due to falling trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air once again spilled over the Divide the morning of the 8th leading to a period of gusty winds, blowing snow, moderate to heavy snowfall, icy conditions and much colder temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy snow developed over Missoula and the northern Bitterroot Valley during the morning commute on the 9th. Numerous traffic accidents occurred on key travel corridors as snow turned to slush and then froze to the roadways.  A total of 5.7 inches of snow was observed at the Missoula International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning March 6th, and lasting into mid May, severe drought was reported along and south of Highway 40 in Cheyenne County.  Total precipitation from around the county in March ranged from 0.02 to 0.26.
Heavy rain developed across portions of the region in association with a cold front. Some of this heavy rain produced flash flooding. A weak tornado also touched down in Neshoba County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 tornado briefly touched down at the intersection of Highways 15 and 19. It blew out the doors and some insulation a large metal shop and caused minor damage to nearby trees. The tornado was observed by fire department personnel and reported by Neshoba County Emergency Management.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong but shallow cold front moved through East Texas during the afternoon hours of February 10th, with temperatures falling to or below freezing during the late evening hours. Weak overrunning atop this shallow arctic air mass resulted in patchy freezing drizzle developing around midnight throughout the early morning hours on February 11th across portions of Northeast Texas, resulting in icing of bridges across Lake Cypress Springs in Franklin County, as well as vehicles and elevated objects in Red River and Smith Counties. ||Temperatures remained at or below freezing across much of Northeast Texas during the daytime hours on February 11th, as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas, with light accumulations of sleet on grassy and road surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses throughout Smith, Wood, and Upshur Counties. Elsewhere across Northeast Texas, only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded, with very little if any impacts observed. ||In Smith County, 0.2 inches of sleet was recorded at Tyler, as well as areas from Lake Palestine near the Teaselville community to Flint, Whitehouse, and Bullard. In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.

An Alberta Clipper produced a brief burst of snow late February 5th into the early morning hours of February 6th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A quick 4 to 6 inches of snow created difficult travel conditions. There were accidents reported across the region, along with several school closings and delays on February 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking from Iowa across southeast WI and into Lower MI brought a long duration snow event to southern WI. Lake enhanced snow also contributed to the snow totals near Lake MI. Snow amounts ranged from 2-7 inches inland from Lake MI, to 6-14 inches near Lake MI. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred. Some private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front approached Eastern NC late on January 12th, 2018. A shortwave trough moved through the area prior to the cold front, with high-shear and limited instability, leading to several marine thunderstorm wind gusts across the coastal waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local NWS marine platform at Cedar Island reported a 43 knot marine thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moved through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 7th. North and west of this low, surface temperatures remained at or below freezing. This resulted in a period of freezing rain, sleet and snow. Ice accretion of 0.25 to 0.3 inches occurred in a strip across Vinton, Athens, Perry and Morgan County. Scattered power outages occurred across Perry and Morgan counties where the widespread icing brought down trees and power lines. There was a sharp line between the freezing rain/sleet, and where it was all snow. The far northwestern corner of Perry County got several inches of snow instead of the ice. Closer to the Ohio River, generally a light coating up to 0.2 inches of ice was measured through mid morning, before temperatures rose above freezing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air aloft brought a period of freezing rain to portions of the Billings Forecast Area. This was followed by an arctic air intrusion. Once the arctic air was in place, a moist flow aloft off the Pacific Ocean produced an overrunning snow event. As a result, heavy snow occurred across a large portion of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6 to 10 inches, snow covered roads and reduced visibilities occurred across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm air aloft brought a period of freezing rain to portions of the Billings Forecast Area. This was followed by an arctic air intrusion. Once the arctic air was in place, a moist flow aloft off the Pacific Ocean produced an overrunning snow event. As a result, heavy snow occurred across a large portion of the Billings Forecast Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain was followed by 4 to 5 inches of snow. Travel was dangerous with numerous slideoffs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall around 6 inches was reported across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured in the town of Cascade.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured 5 miles ESE of Pendroy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong but shallow cold front moved through Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours on February 10th. Temperatures fell to freezing across much of Southwest Arkansas by daybreak on the 11th, and remained at or below freezing during the daytime hours as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas into Southwest Arkansas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas and Southwest Arkansas, but only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded across Little River, Sevier, Howard, Hempstead, Miller, and Lafayette Counties, with very little if any impacts observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air once again spilled over the Divide the morning of the 8th leading to a period of gusty winds, blowing snow, moderate to heavy snowfall, icy conditions and much colder temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe driving conditions occurred in the Flathead and Mission valleys the evening of the 8th through the morning of the 9th due to snow and blowing snow.  A peak wind gust of 56 mph occurred at Glacier Park International Airport at 4:46 pm on the 8th during the evening commute with minor power outages also noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a relatively mild January and first few days of February, an arctic air mass came over the Continental Divide into Northwest Montana during the morning of February 3 bringing strong winds, heavy snow, and localized freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass rushed over the Continental Divide the morning of the 3rd, reaching Essex around 11 am and followed the U.S. Highway 2 corridor into West Glacier by 2 pm. Blizzard conditions were observed as falling snow combined with wind gusts of 45 to 55 miles per hour.  A peak wind gust of 57 mph was observed at Essex with gusts over 40 mph for 9 consecutive hours, resulting in an extended period of severe driving conditions.  An avalanche official reported these were the worst conditions he had seen in his 13 years in the Essex area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another push of arctic air came back over the Continental Divide the evening of the 4th, reaching Kalispell during the morning commute on the 5th. Winds were not as strong along U.S. Highway 2 as the previous day but were stronger in Kalispell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and blowing snow on the morning of the 5th caused poor driving conditions and numerous accidents during the morning rush hour. The peak wind gust of 39 mph at Glacier Park International Airport occurred at 8:01 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pushed across the Divide and into the Kalispell area on the evening of 14th leading to a period of moderate snow and gusty winds with associated impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe driving conditions occurred in the Flathead Valley due to a combination of snow, blowing snow, and flash-frozen roads. A peak wind gust of 41 mph was observed at the Glacier Park International Airport, along with 4 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow, blowing snow, and a flash freeze led to severe driving conditions late on the 17th into the 18th.  Wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph on the morning of the 18th combined with snow to produce greatly reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe driving conditions were observed on major travel routes due to snow and blowing snow. Wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were common creating localized ground blizzard conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous slide off crashes and jackknifed semi trucks occurred on Interstate 90 due to snow and blowing snow.  Widespread snowfall amounts of 8 to 12 inches were common with wind gusts of 35 to 45 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm survey found a downburst damage that began at West Paces Rd at the shoreline of Lake Norman and continued about north-northeast, ending at Goodwin Circle and Highway 150. Roof damage occurred to a number of  businesses and homes, while multiple trees were blown down throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another push of arctic air came back over the Continental Divide the evening of the 4th, reaching Kalispell during the morning commute on the 5th. Winds were not as strong along U.S. Highway 2 as the previous day but were stronger in Kalispell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snow slide occurred across State Highway 1 at mile marker 27.5 near Georgetown Lake early on the morning of the 5th.  The northbound lane was impassable with up to 15 inches of snow on the southbound lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracking from Iowa across southeast WI and into Lower MI brought a long duration snow event to southern WI. Lake enhanced snow also contributed to the snow totals near Lake MI. Snow amounts ranged from 2-7 inches inland from Lake MI, to 6-14 inches near Lake MI. Some vehicle slide-offs and accidents occurred. Some private events were cancelled.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 6th. Surface temperatures across portions of West Virginia remained at or below freezing through mid morning while temperatures above the surface had already warmed above freezing. This resulted in a period of light freezing drizzle, with a light coating of ice across a narrow swath of central and western West Virginia.

This resulted in a period of light freezing drizzle, with a light coating of ice across a narrow swath of central and western West Virginia.

Clearing skies and light winds accompanying an Arctic ridge of high pressure resulted in significant nocturnal cooling on New Year's Eve evening into the morning of New Year's Day, prompting a wind chill warning for portions of North-Central Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP station near Rudyard reported wind chill of -51F with sustained wind of 12 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and light winds accompanying an Arctic ridge of high pressure resulted in significant nocturnal cooling on New Year's Eve evening into the morning of New Year's Day, prompting a wind chill warning for portions of North-Central Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: MT DOT station near Pendroy reported -44F wind chill with sustained wind of 17 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust at the Browning MDT site.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak gust at the Bowmans Corner DOT site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of severe driving conditions occurred much of the 17th into the 18th due to heavy snow with some gusty winds.  Twenty-four hour snow amounts included 26 inches at Lookout Pass and 22 inches just west of Trout Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell ahead of a warm front on the 17th, especially across Northwest Montana.  An Arctic front brought strong winds and additional snow late on the 17th into the 18th across all of western Montana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe driving conditions with chains required were reported on U.S. Highway 2 from Columbia Falls to Marias Pass due to snow as well as blowing and drifting of snow.  Essex reported 18 inches of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds on the backside of an upper level storm system reached the ground in Hitchcock and Red Willow counties.  The peak wind gust was 66 MPH at McCook.  The high winds also fueled a wildfire which consumed a house on the north side of McCook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Station at Dundy Stratton County High School in Benkelman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure moved through eastern Washington. North Idaho was under the cold side of this low pressure track and received widespread heavy snow during the day on February 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lookout Pass ski resort reported 13 inches of new snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public in Hunters reported 8.0 inches of new snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1117 PM EST, Dartmouth Street in Natick was flooded with two feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary brought several periods of heavy rain to the Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on highway 19 between highway 213 and new street which closed all lanes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary brought several periods of heavy rain to the Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on highway 7 at Howard Street which closed all lanes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe storms developed ahead of a cold front during the late afternoon in a moist and unstable air mass. A more organized comma head and trailing line of storms moved into the area mid to late evening. Some of the storms produced wind damage across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five trees were reported down on Lake Forest Drive north of Badin Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Tennessee valley across southern New England on February 7th. It was a quick but potent system with duration of 6 to 8 hours and snowfall rates of an inch or more for several hours, which made for a hazardous evening commute. Snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 inches were observed across much of Vermont.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 6 to 12 inches of snow fell across Addison county, including 12 inches in Vergennes and 9 inches in Orwell. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at times was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure moved through eastern Washington. North Idaho was under the cold side of this low pressure track and received widespread heavy snow during the day on February 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure moved through eastern Washington. North Idaho was under the cold side of this low pressure track and received widespread heavy snow during the day on February 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Corona Public Library weather station reported peak wind gusts between 58 mph and 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured 11 miles NNE of Augusta.

CZ_NAME: HAWK CHANNEL FROM OCEAN REEF TO CRAIG KEY OUT TO THE REEF
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated gale-force convective wind gust occurred along the Reef offshore Ocean Reef, as low pressure was beginning to develop over the northern Bahamas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 37 knots was measured at an automated WeatherFlow station at Carysfort Reef Light.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong arctic high pressure had built into the Yukon Territory up to 1037 MB on 1/9 and 1/10. Very strong outflow winds were reported in Downtown Haines up to 60 mph causing damage on the afternoon of 1/9.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marine Exchange observation recorded gusts to 60 MPH for the Haines Harbor (Downtown) on the afternoon of 1/9. Local newspaper reported that a ski rack was torn off a car and went through the window of a downtown business. Other damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving eastward from the central United States on Thursday March 1st, intensified rapidly as it moved offshore Thursday night and early Friday, deepening to 974 mb by the evening of Friday March 2nd.||Strong winds were present in the low levels of the atmosphere due to the strengthening pressure gradient, and were able to mix down to the surface in strong wind gusts under northwest flow cold air advection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 mph was reported in Upper Marlboro. A wind gust of 61 mph was reported at Andrews Air Force Base. Numerous trees were down across the county from high winds. The Prince Georges County 911 center reported approximately 1000 wind-related calls, mainly for trees and wires down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving eastward from the central United States on Thursday March 1st, intensified rapidly as it moved offshore Thursday night and early Friday, deepening to 974 mb by the evening of Friday March 2nd.||Strong winds were present in the low levels of the atmosphere due to the strengthening pressure gradient, and were able to mix down to the surface in strong wind gusts under northwest flow cold air advection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 60 mph was reported near Tompkinsville. The Charles County 911 Center reported approximately 80 reports of downed trees or power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 64 mph was reported at Annapolis (KNAK). A wind gust of 62 mph was reported at Glen Burnie, and 61 mph was reported at Baltimore-Washington International. ||The Anne Arundel County 911 Center reported around 65 calls due to trees and wires down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 60 mph was reported near Chaptico and a wind gust of 69 mph was reported at Patuxent River. Shingles and siding was blown off of multiple homes near California, and several trees were down. ||The St. Marys 911 center reported around 150 calls due to wind damage to trees, wires and shingles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong but shallow cold front moved through East Texas during the afternoon hours of February 10th, with temperatures falling to or below freezing during the late evening hours. Weak overrunning atop this shallow arctic air mass resulted in patchy freezing drizzle developing around midnight throughout the early morning hours on February 11th across portions of Northeast Texas, resulting in icing of bridges across Lake Cypress Springs in Franklin County, as well as vehicles and elevated objects in Red River and Smith Counties. ||Temperatures remained at or below freezing across much of Northeast Texas during the daytime hours on February 11th, as a weak upper level disturbance traversed Northern and Eastern Texas. Scattered areas of light freezing rain mixed with sleet fell across portions of Northeast Texas, with light accumulations of sleet on grassy and road surfaces, as well as bridges and overpasses throughout Smith, Wood, and Upshur Counties. Elsewhere across Northeast Texas, only trace amounts of freezing rain and sleet were recorded, with very little if any impacts observed. ||In Smith County, 0.2 inches of sleet was recorded at Tyler, as well as areas from Lake Palestine near the Teaselville community to Flint, Whitehouse, and Bullard. In Wood County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded in Mineola and Quitman. In Upshur County, 0.1 inches of sleet was recorded near Big Sandy.

Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of showers and thunderstorms moved across the foothills during the afternoon, producing 2-3 inches of rainfall in just a couple of hours. This resulted in sporadic flash flooding along some small streams in central Burke County. These included Canoe Creek, which reportedly flooded Highway 126 near Brookstone Dr, Lowwr Creek, which flooded Antioch Rd near Highway 18, forcing evacuations of several homes in this area. Dentons Chapel Rd was also flooded and impassable at Jeter Carswell Rd, likely due to flooding along Double Branch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Media reported trees and power lines blown down on Lions Hill St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weather front brought precipitation into the Panhandle on 1/13. Temperatures started at the surface well below freezing along the Klondike Highway.  Strong warm air advection was occurring as the front passed which produced periods of heavy snow along the Klondike Highway during the night of 1/13. At least 7 inches of new snow fall along the highway. Precipitation rates diminished while temperatures continued to warm early on 1/14 which ended the warning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least 7 inches of new snow fell along the Klondike Highway during the night of 1/13. No damage reported. Impact was snow removal by DOT.

CZ_NAME: JUNEAU BOROUGH AND NORTHERN ADMIRALTY ISLAND
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong warm front advanced over the Panhandle with a very cold air mass still in place.  |This combined with an upper level disturbance moving in from NW. Significant  snow amounts occurred before the warm air advection changed the snow over to rain late 1/12 to early 1/13. Snow amounts ranged from an inch to 6 inches overnight. No significant damage was reported. Impact was snow removal followed by rain and freezing rain on roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Juneau forecast office measured 6 inches new snow overnight by the morning of 1/13. Other amounts were less, but rain on top of snow made driving conditions poor. Impact was snow removal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted through the middle Ohio River Valley on the 6th. Surface temperatures across portions of West Virginia remained at or below freezing through mid morning while temperatures above the surface had already warmed above freezing. This resulted in a period of light freezing drizzle, with a light coating of ice across a narrow swath of central and western West Virginia.

The large area of high pressure which prevailed over the area toward the end of January continued to hold it's grip on Central California as February began. Area of dense fog formed in the southwestern portion of the San Joaquin Valley on the morning of February 1 and patches of dense fog persisted until late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below 200 feet was reported in the Hanford area at 328 am PST and remained under a quarter mile through 930 am PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While fog was more localized on February 2, the large ridge centered off the California coast strengthened overnight resulting in dense fog becoming more prevalent during the morning of February 3 a low level inversion persisted over the San Joaquin Valley. The fog dissipated by late morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Visibility below a quarter mile was reported in Atwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm developing in the wake of a cold front moved across the northwest Upstate during the evening and produced hail in Oconee County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple Social Media reports of pea to nickel size hail were received from the Oakway area to locations south of Seneca.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated afternoon thunderstorms developed over the North Carolina Piedmont in association with a frontal zone and area of low pressure. One of the storms produced brief wind damage in Cabarrus County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ham Radio operator reported a couple of trees and some power lines blown down on Hudspeth Road. A small tree was also downed closer to the Speedway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The arctic front was close to Skagway on the afternoon of 1/2 through 1/3. Warm air from the south aloft caused heavy snow to the Klondike Highway overnight along higher elevations. The impact was road closure and snow removal. Avalanche danger was enhanced, but none were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alaska DOT measured 5 inches new 8-12 mile and from 12-14.  Winds 15-20 mph near the pass.	Impact was snow removal, road closure, and elevated avalanche potential.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper-level disturbance tracking from the Northern Rockies into the Ohio River Valley brought a period of moderate to heavy snow to north-central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of February 5th.  A persistent mesoscale band developed...depositing 6 to 10 inches of snow along and north of a Galesburg to Lacon line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather observers across Stark County reported 6 to 10 inches of snow...including 9.0 in Wyoming and 6.2 in West Jersey.  Numerous traffic accidents occurred due to snow-covered roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US 101 NB at SFO large flooding number 1 lane.

This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sierra Blanca Regional Airport reported peak wind gusts between 58 mph and 76 mph for several consecutive hours. Peak wind gusts occurred around 8 am on the 20th.

CZ_NAME: LITTLE COLORADO RIVER VALLEY IN APACHE COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to parts of northern Arizona.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: St Johns Airport reported wind gusts of 58 MPH or higher from 1245 PM to 200 PM. The peak wind gust was 63 MPH at 1254 PM. Petrified Forest National Monument reported a peak wind gust of 60 MPH at 1223 PM.  The wind sensor in Lupton reported a peak wind gust of 65 MPH at 0343 PM. The peak wind gust at Springerville Airport was 72 MPH at 1120 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the late evening Tuesday, February 20th, and the overnight and morning hours on Wednesday, February 21st. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind Chills as low as 30 below occurred in western Cherry County during the overnight  and into the morning hours.  Nearby Nearby Pine Ridge, South Dakota ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 11 pm MST. Nearby Valentine ASOS recorded a lowest wind chill of 30 below at 5 am MST and again at 7 am MST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bitter cold arctic air mass brought dangerous wind chills to portions of north central Nebraska during the late evening Tuesday, February 20th, and the overnight and morning hours on Wednesday, February 21st. Lowest wind chills of 30 to 39 below occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave aloft brought a band of precipitation into a cold air mass that was already in place over southern Oregon in the morning hours on this date.  This caused a brief but intense snow event over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous school closures and delays were reported across the area.  Traffic was slowed considerably due to accidents and chain requirements along major highways including Interstate 5.  A CoCoRaHS observer 4W Tiller reported 6.5 inches of snow at 22/0700 PST.  A spotter in Glendale reported 6.0 inches of snow at 22/1030 PST.  A member of the public in Azalea reported 5.0 inches of snow at 22/0714 PST. A member of the public in the Tri-City area reported 4.0 inches of snow at 22/1000 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two episodes of strong winds lead to blowing and drifting snow on the Camas Prairie including the town of Grangeville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second round of blowing and drifting snow occurred on the 25th with even stronger winds compared to the previous day; a gust to 56 mph was observed at Grangeville Airport. Snow drifted across U.S. Highway 95 west and south of Grangeville, and on State Highway 13 east of Grangeville. County officials took until the 27th to clear drifts of up to 6 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US 101 N at Alemany Blvd off ramp, number 1 lane flooded 6 to 8 inches deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1018 AM EST, an amateur radio operator reported flooding related to an ice jam on the Ware River in Ware.  The Ware Airport was flooded, and a portion of Church Street was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Transwestern Pump station for Columbia Scientific Balloon Facility reported a brief peak wind gust up to 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured 7 miles SE of Glen.

Traffic was slowed considerably due to accidents and chain requirements along major highways including Interstate 5.  A CoCoRaHS observer 1 NNW Merlin reported 7.2 inches of snow at 22/0800 PST. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper-level disturbance tracking from the Northern Rockies into the Ohio River Valley brought a period of moderate to heavy snow to north-central Illinois during the afternoon and evening of February 5th.  A persistent mesoscale band developed...depositing 6 to 10 inches of snow along and north of a Galesburg to Lacon line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather observers across Knox County reported 6 to 10 inches of snow...including 9.0 in Altona and 7.0 in Galesburg.  Numerous traffic accidents occurred due to snow-covered roadways.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several weather observers across Marshall County reported 6 to 10 inches of snow...including 10.0 in Sparland, 9.0 in Camp Grove, and 8.3 in Toluca.  Numerous traffic accidents occurred due to snow-covered roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front brought high winds to parts of northern Arizona.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Flagstaff Airport ASOS reported a peak wind gust of 59 MPH wind at 11:18 AM.  Several ponderosa pine trees were blown over in Sunset Crater National Monument. A local ski resort (9,000 to 11,500 feet) was closed all day because of the high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large trough of low pressure moved down the West Coast to the Los Angeles Basin,  eastward across Arizona, and then into New Mexico as it filled. This brought wind, rain, and snow to northern Arizona.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Flagstaff Airport received 8.5 inches of snow.  Other areas from Munds Park to Flagstaff received 7 to 9 inches of snow. Flagstaff area school had their first snow day of the season. Coconino County and Flagstaff City offices opened two hours late because of the snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving eastward from the central United States on Thursday March 1st, intensified rapidly as it moved offshore Thursday night and early Friday, deepening to 974 mb by the evening of Friday March 2nd.||Strong winds were present in the low levels of the atmosphere due to the strengthening pressure gradient, and were able to mix down to the surface in strong wind gusts under northwest flow cold air advection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were down across Montgomery County. A large tree fell onto a house near Laytonsville, and siding was also blown off the house. A wind gust of 60 mph was reported in Clarksburg.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was down blocking Frederick Road between Carrs Mill Road and Morgan Station Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was down blocking the 4500 Block of Fessenden Street. A 64 mph was reported near Silver Spring. A wind gust of 66 mph was reported at Catholic University.||A tree fell into a building along the 100 Block of Joliet Street Southwest, resulting in an injury. Emergency Management reported around 172 trees down due to high wind across the District of Columbia.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 mph was measured at the Martinsburg Airport. Numerous trees were reported down across Berkeley County. Roofing from a mobile home was removed near Inwood. A Gas Station sign was blown out near Berkeley. The Berkeley County 911 Center reported over 100 calls of trees and power lines down due to high winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 58 mph was reported near Bakerton. A roof was ripped off an autobody shop at the 18400 Block of Jefferson Davis Highway. The 911 Center reported around 80 reports of downed trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of mixed winter precipitation moved over the area with warm air aloft overriding a deep layer of cold air at the surface. This resulted in sleet initially that transitioned to freezing rain before temperatures eventually increased above freezing. Several areas saw nearly an inch of sleet combined with around one half of an inch of freezing rain. This resulted in thousands of power outages and substantial tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain combined with wind caused multiple trees to fall and power lines to fall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at Solomons Island indicated that parking lots near Charles Street in Solomons began to flood, with several inches of water covering portions of both Charles Street and Williams Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong onshore flow led to moderate tidal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at Maine Avenue indicated that the unprotected area on the Southwest Waterfront at the DC seafood market began to flood. Water approached parts of the Hains Point Loop Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong onshore flow led to moderate tidal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The water level at Maine Avenue indicated that the unprotected area on the Southwest Waterfront at the DC seafood market began to flood. Water approached parts of the Hains Point Loop Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front from late morning through the afternoon across Upstate South Carolina. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County comms reported trees blown down on Harris Bridge Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured 18 miles SW of Augusta.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured 6 miles SSW of Great Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong jet nosing into the area led to a period of strong and, at times, damaging wind gusts over the plains of Central Montana. Widespread wind gusts of 50-70 mph occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust measured 9 miles WSW of Stanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and mid elevation snow melt caused the Palouse river to flood on February 4th and February 5th. In the three day period leading up to the flooding a COOP weather station at Potlach recorded 1.16 inches of rain. The river extensively flooded a local road bed but no damage to structures was noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS Palouse River Gage at Potlach recorded a rise above the Flood Stage of 15.0 feet at 8:45 PM February 4th. The river crested at 15.9 feet at 10:45 AM February 5th and then receded below Flood Stage at 10:30 PM February 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front begun to shift southeast across extreme Southeast Oklahoma and adjacent sections of Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon hours on February 20th, replacing a very warm and humid air mass with cooler and drier air. Areas of showers and a few embedded thunderstorms developed along and behind the front, as strong overrunning had begun as warmer air surged atop the cooler but shallow air mass behind the front. Enough elevated instability was present to allow for isolated strong to severe thunderstorms to develop along the front during the late afternoon across Northern Sevier and Howard Counties in Southwest Arkansas, before they quickly exited the area and weakened. These storms produced strong winds which downed a few trees near Horatio and DeQueen while also damaging several outbuildings and chicken houses north of Dierks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorm winds damaged 4 hog buildings, removed the roof off of 3 chicken houses, and debris knocked the windows out of one vehicle north of Dierks near the Athens community.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of mixed winter precipitation moved over the area with warm air aloft overriding a deep layer of cold air at the surface. This resulted in sleet initially that transitioned to freezing rain before temperatures eventually increased above freezing. Several areas saw nearly an inch of sleet combined with around one half of an inch of freezing rain. This resulted in thousands of power outages and substantial tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain combined with wind caused multiple trees to fall and power lines to fall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of mixed winter precipitation moved over the area with warm air aloft overriding a deep layer of cold air at the surface. This resulted in sleet initially that transitioned to freezing rain before temperatures eventually increased above freezing. Several areas saw nearly an inch of sleet combined with around one half of an inch of freezing rain. This resulted in thousands of power outages and substantial tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of heavy sleet and one-half inch of measured ice resulted in multiple power outages and trees down throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 7th and into the early morning hours of February 8th strong winds down sloping off the Cascades in the wake of a frontal passage caused scattered power outages due to trees interacting with power lines in the Wenatchee and Entiat area. The highest recorded wind gust was 52 mph at the Wenatchee airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chelan County Public Utilities reported about 1500 customers lost power during the night of February 7th and morning of February 8th when strong winds broke tree limbs and downed a number of trees into power lines in and around Wenatchee and in the Entiat area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 642 PM EST, an amateur radio operator reported significant street flooding on Pleasantdale Road in Rutland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through. EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 825 PM EST, an amateur radio operator reported the intersection of Hathaway Road and US Route 6 closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure moved through eastern Washington. North Idaho was under the cold side of this low pressure track and received widespread heavy snow during the day on February 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Potlatch reported 6.0 inches of new snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell across north-central Idaho the afternoon of the 17th ahead of a warm front, then continued on the 18th along an Arctic front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy bursts of snow with amounts around 12 inches were common leading to difficult travel over area mountain passes. The highway department noted that it was difficult to keep up with snow rates near Lolo Pass late on the 17th. Also, 24 inches of snow fell at Powell from the 16th through the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy upslope snow fell across the mountains of northwest Montana on the 24th into the 25th, with snow bands leading to isolated heavy snow late on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant impacts were felt on major travel corridors. Interstate 90 was blocked several times due to jackknifed semi trucks in addition to periodic severe driving conditions. A 24 hour snow amount of 25 inches of snow was reported at Lookout Pass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two episodes of strong winds lead to blowing and drifting snow on the Camas Prairie including the town of Grangeville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing and drifting snow were a significant impact as wind gusts to 40 mph transported newly fallen snow late on the 23rd into the 24th. Snow drifted across U.S. Highway 95 west and south of Grangeville leading to treacherous road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front from late morning through the afternoon across Upstate South Carolina. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS Storm Survey found the path of a weak tornado that began along Mountainview Road, where large tree branches were broken. The tornado moved very quickly northeast, crossing Highway 55, where it then passed through the Timberlake Subdivision. Several homes in the subdivision sustained roof, siding, and window damage. A number of hardwood trees were also uprooted, with large branches downed from others. A plastic fence also was destroyed. The tornado proceeded northeast, uprooting additional hardwood trees before dissipating near Kerrydale Ct.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front from late morning through the afternoon across Upstate South Carolina. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported up to quarter size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ham Radio operator reported a tree blown down onto a house near the intersection of Forbes Road and Hemphill Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement and public reported multiple trees blown down along Highway 273 south of Belmont. A large tree fell on a house and briefly trapped occupants near the intersection of South Forest Ln and Brook Forest Dr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous afternoon thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front moved into the North Carolina Piedmont from South Carolina during the early afternoon. Several of the storms produced severe weather in the form of large to very large hail and locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 68 mph (59 kts) was measured by the ASOS at the Charlotte Douglas Airport at 1413 EST. While wind damage was reported across several areas of Mecklenburg County, including at least a couple of large trees down near the Uptown Charlotte, most of the damage was reported across the western part of the county, especially from Mountain Island Lake to the southern and eastern shores of Lake Norman. Many trees were blown down in this area, with damage to some outbuildings reported in the area around Brown Mill Rd and Beatties Ford Rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: County comms reported multiple trees blown down from Midland to Mount Pleasant, with most of the damage occurring in the Midland area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clines Corners reported peak wind gusts periodically between 58 mph and 71 mph for several consecutive hours. NMDOT reported a semi truck rolled over on Interstate 40.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 7th and into the early morning hours of February 8th strong winds down sloping off the Cascades in the wake of a frontal passage caused scattered power outages due to trees interacting with power lines in the Wenatchee and Entiat area. The highest recorded wind gust was 52 mph at the Wenatchee airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed trees closed Navarre Coulee Road for about three hours while road crews cleared the damaged trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong storm center dominated the Gulf of Alaska on the afternoon of 1/13. Warm air rising over the cold air near the Klondike Highway resulted in heavy snow. Impact was snow removal, road closure, and increased avalanche danger.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alaska DOT observed 7 inches of new snow from State Street to Milepost 14 as of 9:38 AM (1/13) on 511 website. The pass was a real mess. Impact was snow removal, road closure, and increased avalanche potential. Temperatures warmed making snow removal challenging.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Nor'easter developed off the SE CONUS on January 3rd and proceeded to move   on shore between eastern Maine and western Nova Scotia late in the day of January 4th. Widespread snow moved across Vermont during the morning hours, becoming steadier/heavier for much of eastern VT during the 4th. Wraparound snowfall during the night of the 4th and the day of the 5th added snowfall to Vermont's northern peaks and western slope communities. Overall snowfall statewide was 3 to 7 inches with upwards of 8-12 inches along the northern western slopes of the Green Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread 4 to 8 inches of snow observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 3 to 6 inches was observed but isolated 10 inches along a few communities along the western slopes as snow continued through the evening of the 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced 6 to 9 inches of snow in a 12 hour period across Schuylkill County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions continued through February over the Upper Rio Grande Valley. A few weak storm systems moved through the area during mid to late February with only light rain and snow amounts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: I persistent upper level flow of moist southerly air brought waves of flooding and flash flooding to the region.  Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area.  Two deaths were also reported, one person was washed away attempting to cross a stream, while a motorist was swept away in flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous road closures occurred as a result of flooding across the western portion of the county.

Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: US-220 was closed north of Picture Rocks. Numerous additional roads were also closed in eastern Lycoming county, as a result of flooding occurring alongside Muncy Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and Southwest Arkansas during the early morning hours of February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across Northeast Texas during the evening hours on the 20th through much of the 21st before gradually diminishing during the late evening hours. However, additional periods of moderate to heavy rain spread across much of East Texas on February 22nd north of the cold front, and continued through the morning hours on the 23rd. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of nine inches fell across much of East Texas during this 3 day period, resulting in widespread flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water on FM 1254 northeast of Mineola.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and Southwest Arkansas during the early morning hours of February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across Northeast Texas during the evening hours on the 20th through much of the 21st before gradually diminishing during the late evening hours. However, additional periods of moderate to heavy rain spread across much of East Texas on February 22nd north of the cold front, and continued through the morning hours on the 23rd. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of nine inches fell across much of East Texas during this 3 day period, resulting in widespread flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail fell just north of Mount Vernon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water over the west end of Jot-Em Down Road. Grover Jones Road from Blue Ridge back towards Gibsland was impassable. Iron Bridge Road north and west of Gibsland, Domino Road, Danzy Road, Kenneth Road, CC Road, Castor Creek Road, Guin Road, Shady Grove Road between LA 155 and LA 501 at Fourcher Creek and on the east side of Shady Grove Road, Cabin Creek Road, Pine Grove Road at various culverts, and Danville Road at the Coulee Creek Road bridge were all flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clearing skies and cold dry air combined to bring freezing temperatures to the southern Oregon coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures ranged from 30 to 33 degrees.
