EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public report of 4.0 inches of snow at an elevation of 1700 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported 8 inches of snow falling during the overnight period. Elevation was 2800 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Pullman recorded 5.0 inches of new snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHs observer in Thornton recorded 4.7 inches of new snow accumulation from this storm. A member of the public near Thornton reported 5.5 inches of new snow via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near Metaline Falls reported 4.2 inches of new snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Grand Cane were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions over the San Juan Mountains deteriorated even further to extreme drought on February 13, 2018. A few weak storm systems moved through the area during February with light to moderate rain and snow amounts. This additional precipitation was no match for the well below normal snowpack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary brought several periods of heavy rain to the Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Considerable flooding was reported on the northern half of Kent Island.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several periods of heavy rain fell along a slow moving frontal boundary across the region. Rainfall amounts ranged one to just over two inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on state highway 73 between Bridge and church roads was reported which closed all lanes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several periods of heavy rain fell along a slow moving frontal boundary across the region. Rainfall amounts ranged one to just over two inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on Neiffer road between Game Farm and Big roads which closed all lanes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: I persistent upper level flow of moist southerly air brought waves of flooding and flash flooding to the region.  Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area.  Two deaths were also reported, one person was washed away attempting to cross a stream, while a motorist was swept away in flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fishing Creek flooded into nearby fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance in the jet stream and an associated weak trough of low pressure within a relatively moist air mass produced showers across the region. On Tuesday Night March 13th , some breaks in the clouds across the Southern Poconos allowed temperatures to fall into the upper 20s, which lead to some of the precipitation to fall as freezing rain. The nearby ASOS in Sussex, New Jersey, reported a short period of light freezing rain from 3:55 AM to 4:13 AM on Wednesday March 14th. There was at most a Trace of radial ice accretion due to the freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A disturbance in the jet stream and an associated weak trough of low pressure within a relatively moist air mass produced showers across the region. On Tuesday Night March 13th , some breaks in the clouds across the Southern Poconos allowed temperatures to fall into the upper 20s, which lead to some of the precipitation to fall as freezing rain. The nearby ASOS in Sussex, New Jersey, reported a short period of light freezing rain from 3:55 AM to 4:13 AM on Wednesday March 14th. There was at most a Trace of radial ice accretion due to the freezing rain.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE SANGRE DE CRISTO MOUNTAINS

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter measured 8 inches of snow that occurred overnight, with snow drifts to 1 foot. Elevation of observation was 2800 feet. Location was 40.47N/-123.67W.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and Southwest Arkansas during the early morning hours of February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across Northeast Texas during the evening hours on the 20th through much of the 21st before gradually diminishing during the late evening hours. However, additional periods of moderate to heavy rain spread across much of East Texas on February 22nd north of the cold front, and continued through the morning hours on the 23rd. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of nine inches fell across much of East Texas during this 3 day period, resulting in widespread flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was washed off of County Road 4115 off of FM 990 southeast of Dekalb.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observer reported several trees down around town in Springfield.  The Eugene Airport ASOS recorded wind gusts of 45 to 49 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CoCoRaHS observer south of Molalla reported that a few composition shingles were blown off his roof.  Another observer east of Stayton reported a power outage. A weather station in Mill City reported wind gusts up to 57 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and across the southwest interior of Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weather station on Cape Disappointment reported wind gusts up to 65 mph.  Another weather station at Toke Point reported sustained winds up to 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level storm system will approach West Texas and Southeast New Mexico Monday, resulting in increasing winds through the Guadalupe Mountains.
An upper level storm system will approach West Texas and Southeast New Mexico Monday, resulting in increasing winds through the Guadalupe Mountains.

A strong upper level storm system will move across the central Rockies and central Plains later today and Saturday. Strong winds will develop in the Guadalupe Mountains as this system passes by to the north.
As a strong jet stream and an associated Pacific front passes through the area, west winds will become strong in the Guadalupe Mountains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and Southwest Arkansas during the late evening and early morning hours of February 20th-21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across Southeast Oklahoma, and persisted throughout the early afternoon hours on the 21st before diminishing. However, additional moderate to heavy rainfall developed and fell across much of Southeast Oklahoma throughout the 22nd. Widespread rainfall amounts of seven to in excess of nine inches fell across McCurtain County, which resulted in periods of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Dodge truck drove around a barricade on Currence Road near Yunabee Creek and attempted to drive through floodwaters after the creek overflowed its banks. The truck was washed away into the creek, but the two male occupants were able to escape the truck through a window uninjured and call police.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave lifting NNE brought a quick-hitting cold front into northwest Oregon. The front brought a short period of high winds to beaches and headlands along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Oregon DOT weather station reported wind gusts up to 61 mph on Megler Bridge.  Another weather station across the river on Cape Disappointment reported sustained winds up to 44 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist front sagged south over southwest Washington, and stayed in place for much of the day on April 14th. Heavy rain in the area of the Grays River led the river to rise above flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grays River near Rosburg crested at 12.6 feet around 1 AM, which is 0.6 foot above flood stage. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave aloft brought a band of precipitation into a cold air mass that was already in place over southern Oregon in the morning hours on this date.  This caused a brief but intense snow event over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous school closures and delays were reported across the area.  Traffic was slowed considerably due to accidents and chain requirements along major highways.  A CoCoRaHS observer 10 W Steamboat reported 4.3 inches of snow at 22/0815 PST.  A spotter 11 WSW Steamboat reported 4.3 inches of snow at 22/0830 PST. The cooperative observer at Toketee Falls reported 8.5 inches of snow in the past 24 hours as of 22/1900 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mixed precipitation began in the evening of the 10th and changed to all snow by morning. There were reports of over 6 inches of snow by daybreak. Most of the snow diminished greatly by 4 PM, but a gravity wave band of moderate to heavy snow continued into the early evening along the north shore and into eastern Carlton County. ||Snowfall amounts in the Minnesota Arrowhead ranged from 7 to over 9 inches. Specific amounts were 9.3 at Winton, 8.2 25 miles east of Ely, 8 at Soudan and 7.1 in Cook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total measured 6.6 in Chisholm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall total measured 6.5 in Bigfork.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure brought heavy, wet snow to southeast portions of central Indiana. The heaviest of the snow fell across portions of Lawrence and Decatur counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CBS4 relayed a snow amount of 6.0 inches in the Greensburg area. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure brought heavy, wet snow to southeast portions of central Indiana. The heaviest of the snow fell across portions of Lawrence and Decatur counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHS report of 7.4 inches of snow was reported four miles east of Mitchell. Additionally, a CoCoRaHS report of 6.8 inches of snow was reported five miles northeast of Mitchell. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Davenport recorded 5.7 inches of snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in northwestern Cherry county during the early evening hours of June 8th. This activity developed along a stationary front which was anchored from northwestern Nebraska into east central Nebraska. As this activity pushed east along the front, a line of storms developed and tracked to the east southeast into portions of central Nebraska. Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.

Isolated thunderstorms developed in northwestern Cherry county during the early evening hours of June 8th. This activity developed along a stationary front which was anchored from northwestern Nebraska into east central Nebraska. As this activity pushed east along the front, a line of storms developed and tracked to the east southeast into portions of central Nebraska. Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.

Snow developed ahead of an area of low pressure and an upper level trough. Plentiful moisture combined with strong frontogenetical forcing produced an narrow area of heavy snow. To the southwest of the heavy snow, rain fell along with a few thunderstorms. To the northeast of the snow band, very dry air caused a sharp cut-off to the snow. A narrow band of intense snow produced amounts of 8 to 12 inches, with some locations receiving over 2 inches per hour. The 10.2 inches of snow at Indianapolis set the daily snowfall record and became the second highest one day total for the month of March. Visibility at the Indianapolis International Airport was a quarter of a mile or less from about 2:30 PM to 4:30 PM EDT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 7 to 10.5 inches was reported from Marion County. The highest amount reported came in from one mile north-northeast of Clermont at 10.5 inches. Owing partially to the event being well forecast and on a Saturday, no other impacts were reported.

Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought continued through February over Union County. A couple weak weather systems moved through the area but brought mainly trace amounts of rain and snow. Episodes of critical fire weather increased by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought continued through February over the Southwest Mountains. An area of extreme drought that developed near Luna toward the end of January did not deteriorate further into February as a few weak weather systems moved across the area with mainly light rain and snow amounts. Snowpack in the higher terrain was nearly nonexistent.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended winter storm began in 02/28/18 and continued into March.  Several locations in Siskiyou county got heavy snow on the last night of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A CoCoRaHs observer 5.1 NW Mount Shasta City reported 14.0 inches of snow in 24 hours ending at 01/0800, but a good portion of it fell before midnight.  A spotter in Mount Shasta City reported 6.0 inches of snow ending at 01/0230 PST.  The Mount Shasta Ranger Station reported 13.0 inches of snow in 24 hours as of 01/0800 PST.  The cooperative observer in McCloud reported 12.0 inches of snow in 24 hours ending at 01/0900 PST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms occurred across the Wiregrass on February 7th ahead of a cold front. One storm briefly became severe in the Madrid area of Houston county.  A mobile home blew over due to high straight line winds, resulting in two minor injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down across the carport of a residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought continued through February over the San Francisco River Valley. A few weak weather systems moved across the area by mid to late February and prevented further deterioration of drought conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water covered Creswell Avenue near Dudley Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of low pressure systems moved across central, southern Vermont with a redeveloping coastal low off the New England shoreline. A prolonged period of light to moderate snow fell across the region with scattered heavier snowfalls as well. A widespread 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across the region with 6 to 12 inches across portions of southern VT and the Northeast Kingdom.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 5 to 10 inches of snow fell across Rutland county with some reports up to 12 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of low pressure systems moved across central, southern Vermont with a redeveloping coastal low off the New England shoreline. A prolonged period of light to moderate snow fell across the region with scattered heavier snowfalls as well. A widespread 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across the region with 6 to 12 inches across portions of southern VT and the Northeast Kingdom.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 5 to 10 inches of snow fell across Windsor county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms developed in the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of June 6th. As this activity tracked east, a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls, thunderstorm wind gusts to 70 MPH and a brief tornado touchdown were reported. Heavy rain also fell leading to flash flooding in western Keith county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cooperative observer reports water over highway 30 approximately 3 miles west of Brule.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in northwestern Cherry county during the early evening hours of June 8th. This activity developed along a stationary front which was anchored from northwestern Nebraska into east central Nebraska. As this activity pushed east along the front, a line of storms developed and tracked to the east southeast into portions of central Nebraska. Hail up to two inches in diameter and thunderstorm wind damage was reported. The activity persisted into the early morning hours of June 9th.

A series of low pressure systems moved across central, southern Vermont with a redeveloping coastal low off the New England shoreline. A prolonged period of light to moderate snow fell across the region with scattered heavier snowfalls as well. A widespread 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across the region with 6 to 12 inches across portions of southern VT and the Northeast Kingdom.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowfall of 4 to 7 inches occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of low pressure systems moved across central, southern Vermont with a redeveloping coastal low off the New England shoreline. A prolonged period of light to moderate snow fell across the region with scattered heavier snowfalls as well. A widespread 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across the region with 6 to 12 inches across portions of southern VT and the Northeast Kingdom.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowfall of 4 to 7 inches occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Raton Crews Airport reported a peak wind gust up to 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific cold front accompanied by a sharp surface low pressure trough crossed North-Central and Southwest Montana during the late morning through evening of March 9th. This front was followed by a period of breezy and westerly downslope winds. In several locations, these winds gusted to warning-criteria strength.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sieben Flats Montana DOT station recorded peak gust of 59 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow developed ahead of an area of low pressure and an upper level trough. Plentiful moisture combined with strong frontogenetical forcing produced an narrow area of heavy snow. To the southwest of the heavy snow, rain fell along with a few thunderstorms. To the northeast of the snow band, very dry air caused a sharp cut-off to the snow. A narrow band of intense snow produced amounts of 8 to 12 inches, with some locations receiving over 2 inches per hour. The 10.2 inches of snow at Indianapolis set the daily snowfall record and became the second highest one day total for the month of March. Visibility at the Indianapolis International Airport was a quarter of a mile or less from about 2:30 PM to 4:30 PM EDT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5 to 10 inches was reported from Boone County. The highest amount reported came in from one mile east of New Ross at 9.7 inches. Owing partially to the event being well forecast and on a Saturday, no other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure moved through eastern Washington. North Idaho was under the cold side of this low pressure track and received widespread heavy snow during the day on February 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A member of the public in Post Falls reported 4.0 inches of new snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Wilbur recorded 5.0 inches of snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: I persistent upper level flow of moist southerly air brought waves of flooding and flash flooding to the region.  Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area.  Two deaths were also reported, one person was washed away attempting to cross a stream, while a motorist was swept away in flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Floodwaters were observed across Honey Valley Road near the intersection with South Franklin Street. A water rescue also occurred on Fissels Church Road near Bortner Road and High Valley Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Easterly flow off the Atlantic Ocean and a warm front west of the Appalachians lead to an overrunning regime across the region. Temperatures across Sussex County were cold enough for light freezing rain during the daylight hours of February 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Easterly flow off the Atlantic Ocean combined and a warm front west of the Appalachians lead to an overrunning regime across the region. Temperatures across Sussex County were cold enough for light freezing rain during the daylight hours of February 23rd. A trained spotter in High Point, NJ, reported 0.10 of freezing rain at 10:15 AM EST, February 23, 2018.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak gust of 61 mph recorded at WFO Great Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain, falling across the Thomas Fire burn scar, resulted in significant mud and debris flows across sections of Ventura county. Highway 101, a main route from Ventura to Santa Barbara, was closed in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mud and debris flow across Highway 150, near Steckel Park. Heavy rain, exceeding USGS thresholds, generated the debris flow.

CZ_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MOUNTAINS EXCLUDING THE SANTA MONICA RANGE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed in the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed across the mountains of Los Angeles county. Some reports from local RAWS stations include: Chilao (gusting to 58 MPH) and Sandberg (gusting to 60 MPH).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell to between minus 10 and minus 15 degrees during the morning hours. After a morning low of 2 above zero, the actual high temperature at Evansville was only 11 above zero. Arctic high pressure centered over the northern Plains produced these dangerously cold wind chills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A ranch five miles southeast of Placitas reported peak wind gusts between 58 mph and 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall over several days caused minor flooding across the Missouri Ozarks. Between four and eight inches of rainfall fell over the course of about a week.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway CC near Racine was closed due to flooding.  West McCord Street and Spring Street in Neosho was also closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shed Road was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season Atmospheric River impacted the area in early April. A very moist airmass made landfall across the North Bay before moving southward across the rest of the Bay Area. The Oakland sounding measured record PWAT values of 1.69. The absence of large scale forcing prevent record breaking rainfall. Enough rain did fall, however, to cause minoir/nuisance flooding across much of the region. Numerous flood advisories were issued. Storm total rainfall amounts up to 7 were reported. The bulk of the impacts were felt on April 6,7.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reporting mud/dirt/rocks covering northbound Highway 1 near Anderson Canyon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through the region bringing narrow bands of heavy rain (cold frontal rain bands) and gusty winds. No flooding was reported as a result of the heavy rain and no wind damage was reported. Convection behind the front produced isolated small hail in San Benito County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported hail at school peak gabilan range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance in the jet stream and an associated weak trough of low pressure within a relatively moist air mass produced showers across the region. On Tuesday Night March 13th , some breaks in the clouds across the Southern Poconos allowed temperatures to fall into the upper 20s, which lead to some of the precipitation to fall as freezing rain. Freezing rain was reported at the Mount Pocono ASOS.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A disturbance in the jet stream and an associated weak trough of low pressure within a relatively moist air mass produced showers across the region. On Tuesday Night March 13th , some breaks in the clouds across the Southern Poconos allowed temperatures to fall into the upper 20s, which lead to some of the precipitation to fall as freezing rain. Freezing rain was reported at the Mount Pocono ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance in the jet stream and an associated weak trough of low pressure within a relatively moist air mass produced showers across the region. On Tuesday Night March 13th , some breaks in the clouds across the Southern Poconos allowed temperatures to fall into the upper 20s, which lead to some of the precipitation to fall as freezing rain. The nearby ASOS in Sussex, New Jersey, reported a short period of light freezing rain from 3:55 AM to 4:13 AM on Wednesday March 14th. There was at most a Trace of radial ice accretion due to the freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A disturbance in the jet stream and an associated weak trough of low pressure within a relatively moist air mass produced showers across the region. On Tuesday Night March 13th , some breaks in the clouds across the Southern Poconos allowed temperatures to fall into the upper 20s, which lead to some of the precipitation to fall as freezing rain. The nearby ASOS in Sussex, New Jersey, reported a short period of light freezing rain from 3:55 AM to 4:13 AM on Wednesday March 14th. There was at most a Trace of radial ice accretion due to the freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of mixed winter precipitation moved over the area with warm air aloft overriding a deep layer of cold air at the surface. This resulted in sleet initially that transitioned to freezing rain before temperatures eventually increased above freezing. Several areas saw nearly an inch of sleet combined with around one half of an inch of freezing rain. This resulted in thousands of power outages and substantial tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain combined with wind caused multiple trees to fall and power lines to fall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure brought a prolonged period of unseasonably warm temperatures to begin February as temperatures were 10 degrees or more above seasonal normals across much of the are for the first 10 days of the month. A low pressure system dropping into the Great Basin on the 10th brought a period of increased winds to the Kern County Mountains and Deserts during the late morning and early afternoon as strong mid level winds mixed down to the surface where there were numerous reports of gusts between 45 and 50 mph. Another trough pushed through the Great Basin on the evening of the 11th through the morning of the 12th which pushed a cold front through Central California and brought another period of increased winds to the area and there were several reports of wind gusts between 50 and 55 mp in the Kern County Mountains and Deserts. this system also brought some light precipitation to the area with amounts generally less than a tenth of an inch of liquid precipitation in post-frontal showers on the 12th. A weak tornado briefly touched down in rural farmland near Sanger during the late morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down in rural farmland between Riverbend Ave. and Goodfellow Ave. southeast of Sanger and was captured on video and relayed to the NWS by a media source.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A progressive weather pattern across the western United States continued to provide regular bouts of winter weather over northern and western New Mexico. An upper level wave that moved quickly east from Arizona spread snow and wind along the Continental Divide and the northern mountains of New Mexico. Snowfall amounts averaged three to six inches between Gallup and Grants northeastward toward Cuba. The greatest amounts focused from near Dulce to Chama and within the high terrain of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains where six to 10 inches was reported. Difficult travel conditions were reported in many of these areas. The five inches reported at Dulce was the greatest 24-hour snowfall amount so far for the winter season. Strong winds were reported around the Ruidoso area once again as this storm system pulled eastward into the Great Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported between three and six inches of snow around Dulce.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell to between minus 10 and minus 15 degrees during the morning hours. After a morning low of 2 above zero, the actual high temperature at Evansville was only 11 above zero. Arctic high pressure centered over the northern Plains produced these dangerously cold wind chills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably cold air mass combined with nighttime cooling brought sub-freezing temperatures to the Oregon coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported low temperatures ranged from 25 to 27 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions over the Jemez Mountains deteriorated even further to extreme drought on February 13, 2018. A few weak storm systems moved through the area during February with light to moderate rain and snow amounts. This additional precipitation was no match for the well below normal snowpack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered road led to a 19 vehicle accident at the intersection of Highway 101 and Highway 255. 16 injuries were reported.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL WATERS FROM OCHLOCKONEE RIVER TO APALACHICOLA FL OUT TO 20 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong storms moved across the coastal waters ahead of a cold front.  The C Tower measured gusts in excess of 34 knots with this line of storms.

CZ_NAME: COASTAL WATERS FROM OCHLOCKONEE RIVER TO APALACHICOLA FL OUT TO 20 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong storms moved across the coastal waters ahead of a cold front.  The C Tower measured gusts in excess of 34 knots with this line of storms.

CZ_NAME: APALACHEE BAY OR COASTAL WATERS FROM KEATON BEACH TO OCHLOCKONEE RIVER FL OUT TO 20 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms crossed the marine area during the morning hours of April 15th.  Two sites along the Wakulla county coast saw measured wind gusts in excess of 34 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Site SHPF1 at Shell Point measured a wind gust of 38 knots.

CZ_NAME: APALACHEE BAY OR COASTAL WATERS FROM KEATON BEACH TO OCHLOCKONEE RIVER FL OUT TO 20 NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms crossed the marine area during the morning hours of April 15th.  Two sites along the Wakulla county coast saw measured wind gusts in excess of 34 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Site PRWF1 along the Wakulla county coast measured a wind gust of 35 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow developed ahead of an area of low pressure and an upper level trough. Plentiful moisture combined with strong frontogenetical forcing produced an narrow area of heavy snow. To the southwest of the heavy snow, rain fell along with a few thunderstorms. To the northeast of the snow band, very dry air caused a sharp cut-off to the snow. A narrow band of intense snow produced amounts of 8 to 12 inches, with some locations receiving over 2 inches per hour. The 10.2 inches of snow at Indianapolis set the daily snowfall record and became the second highest one day total for the month of March. Visibility at the Indianapolis International Airport was a quarter of a mile or less from about 2:30 PM to 4:30 PM EDT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer's report of 9.4 inches of snow was received from five miles south of Crawfordsville. Owing partially to the event being well forecast and on a Saturday, no other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 255 PM EST, an amateur radio operator reported a tree down on Johnson Street and wires down on Bay Road near Lakeview Avenue in Taunton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderating temperatures led to snowmelt flooding in many valleys of Broadwater County toward the middle of March.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadwater County Emergency Manager reported widespread snowmelt flooding for valley locations in the county. Water was entering basements of some homes. Some roadways were flooded too.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Great Falls Airport ASOS recorded 58 mph peak gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain, falling over the Thomas Fire burn scar, resulted in significant mud and debris flows around the community of Montecito. Rain gauges in the area indicating rainfall rates exceeding the USGS thresholds for both 30 minute and 1 hour rainfall. The most significant mud and debris flow occurred along Bella Vista Drive, near Romero Canyon Road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported significant mud and debris flows near the community of Montecito. Along Bella Vista Drive, near Romero Canyon Road, a 12-14 foot wide mud and debris flow was reported.

Strong winds were reported around the Ruidoso area once again as this storm system pulled eastward into the Great Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP and SNOTEL reports across eastern Rio Arriba County reported between six and 11 inches of snowfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sierra Blanca Regional Airport reported peak wind gusts up to 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of locally heavy snow occurred across western Greenbrier County in the wake of a strong cold front.  A plume of moisture off of Lake Michigan interacted with a combination of strong lift associated with a passing upper level disturbance and orographic lift on the eastern side of the Appalachians, resulting in a brief period of enhanced snowfall rates.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total snowfall amounts across much western Greenbrier County varied from 5 to 8 inches.  Snow began falling around midnight on the 2nd, with accumulating snow tapering off to flurries around noon later that day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Odessa reported 6.0 inches of snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure system moving into NW Washington and Vancouver Island feed lots of moisture into southwest Washington. This meant heavy snow in the south Washington Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Swift Creek SNOTEL recorded 18 inches of snow, Pinto Rock SNOTEL recorded 17 inches of snow, and Lone Pine SNOTEL recorded 16 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure system moving into NW Washington and Vancouver Island feed lots of moisture into Northwest Oregon. This meant heavy snow in the North Oregon Cascades.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bear Grass and Red Hill SNOTELs reported 15 inches of snow, Mt Hood Meadows NWAC station recorded 18 inches of snow, and Timberline NWAC station recorded 17 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave lifting NNE brought a quick-hitting cold front into southwest Washington.  The front brought a short period of high winds to beaches and headlands along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Oregon DOT weather station on Megler Bridge reported wind gusts up to 61 mph.  Another weather station on Cape Disappointment reported sustained winds up to 44 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the first time since January 2017, an event including both flooding and tornadoes impacted our area starting on February 11, 2018. Two tornadoes touched down across inland portions of the Florida Panhandle before sunrise, followed by persistent heavy rainfall that resulted in flooding at several river sites.  As an upper level trough dug southward across the western and central U.S., southerly flow drew moisture from the Gulf of Mexico northward into the tri-state area over the weekend. Upper air soundings measured this increased moisture with precipitable water values around 1.5 inches on Sunday, well above the 90th percentile and a record for the 12z February 11 sounding, although the record for that date and time are below the average max for this time of year. With a cold front and upper level trough west of the area, the persistent deep layer moisture helped to create a favorable set-up for high rainfall amounts.  This wet pattern resulted in copious amounts of rainfall across the tri-state region. The highest rainfall amounts were across the Florida Panhandle where 8 to 10 inches fell with localized areas receiving more than 10 inches across coastal Walton and Bay counties. The highest observed rainfall total was in Walton County, where a 48-hour rainfall total of 11.45 inches was recorded. Across southeast Alabama and portions of southwest Georgia, widespread 6 to 8 inches of rain fell. While one Flash Flood Warning was issued, the majority of the impacts from this event were from moderate rainfall rates over a prolonged period of time as convection trained across the tri-state area. These high rainfall totals resulted in numerous road closures across the Florida Panhandle from water covered roads and washed out roadways. In addition, a few roads were closed across southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water covered the roadway at Bunker and Steel Field Roads and resulted in road closure.  A small creek intersects this area and likely overflowed from a long duration of moderate to occasionally heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Malmstrom Air Force Base AWOS recorded 59 mph peak gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: I persistent upper level flow of moist southerly air brought waves of flooding and flash flooding to the region.  Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area.  Two deaths were also reported, one person was washed away attempting to cross a stream, while a motorist was swept away in flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A landslide closed PA-441 both ways between Old Chickies Hill Road and Klinesville Road in West Hempfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain, falling across the Thomas Fire burn scar, resulted in significant mud and debris flows across sections of Ventura county. Highway 101, a main route from Ventura to Santa Barbara, was closed in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a mud and debris flow across Highway 101, near Mussel Shoals. Heavy rain, exceeding USGS thresholds, generated the debris flow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed in the mountains of Ventura and Los Angeles counties. Wind gusts up to 60 MPH were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong and gusty northerly winds developed across the mountains of Ventura county. The RAWS sensor at La Granada Mountain reported winds gusting to 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense negative tilt upper-level trough pushed out across the Rockies and into the Plains on March 5, deepening into a very strong closed low across Iowa by early on March 6. 500 hPa heights fell as much as 27 dam in 24 hours as the system deepened. As a result, winds increased to a gusty 35 to 45 mph and produced brief periods of near whiteout conditions. The system was dynamic enough to produce a few thunderstorms early on March 5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hazardous winter weather evolved during the morning of March 5, as rain changed to light to moderate snowfall and was accompanied by winds gusting as high as 43 mph at Sioux Falls, 37 mph at Madison and 35 mph at Brookings. There were brief blizzard or near blizzard conditions during the midday hours around Sioux Falls, but not persistent enough to be defined as a blizzard. Total snowfall was generally 3 to 6 inches, including 4.2 inches at Brookings. Flandreau and Sioux Falls, and 3.6 inches 2 miles north of Chester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow developed ahead of an area of low pressure and an upper level trough. Plentiful moisture combined with strong frontogenetical forcing produced an narrow area of heavy snow. To the southwest of the heavy snow, rain fell along with a few thunderstorms. To the northeast of the snow band, very dry air caused a sharp cut-off to the snow. A narrow band of intense snow produced amounts of 8 to 12 inches, with some locations receiving over 2 inches per hour. The 10.2 inches of snow at Indianapolis set the daily snowfall record and became the second highest one day total for the month of March. Visibility at the Indianapolis International Airport was a quarter of a mile or less from about 2:30 PM to 4:30 PM EDT.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 8 to 13 inches was reported from Hendricks County. The highest amount reported came in from three miles south of Brownsburg at 12.6 inches. Owing partially to the event being well forecast and on a Saturday, no other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure moved through eastern Washington. North Idaho was under the cold side of this low pressure track and received widespread heavy snow during the day on February 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer 10 miles northeast of Sandpoint reported 9.7 inches of new snow accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Spokane International Airport received 7.3 inches of snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Rosalia recorded 4.0 inches of new snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions continued through February over the Central Highlands. A few weak storm systems moved through the area during mid to late February with only light precipitation amounts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water over Winfield Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and Southwest Arkansas during the early morning hours of February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across Northeast Texas during the evening hours on the 20th through much of the 21st before gradually diminishing during the late evening hours. However, additional periods of moderate to heavy rain spread across much of East Texas on February 22nd north of the cold front, and continued through the morning hours on the 23rd. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of nine inches fell across much of East Texas during this 3 day period, resulting in widespread flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: FM 1818 was closed due to a washout on the southbound side between FM 844 and US Highway 69 South. Report from TXDOT Twitter page.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On January 13th at 852 AM EST, a large tree was reported down and blocking route 112.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On January 13th at 805 AM EST, a tree was blocking Forest Street in Upton. At 818 AM EST, a tree was down on power lines on Leicester Street in Auburn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast on Jan. 16th and tracked across southern New England on the 17th. Snow changed to rain across much of the region, but heavy snow, on the order of 6 to 7 inches, fell in the immediate slopes of the Berkshires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to seven inches of snow fell in western Franklin County.  6.8 inches was reported in Ashfield with 5.5 inches in Colrain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure developed off the Mid-Atlantic coast on Jan. 16th and tracked across southern New England on the 17th. Snow changed to rain across much of the region, but heavy snow, on the order of 6 to 7 inches, fell in the immediate slopes of the Berkshires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to seven inches of snow fell in western Hampshire County.  Seven inches was reported in Chesterfield with six inches in Westhampton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Oregon DOT wind sensor measured wind gusts up to 64 mph.  Reported via Facebook, a 40 foot tree was snapped half way up, closing a road. Also, a spotter reported a power line went down in Bay City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind sensor on the Yaquina Bridge reported wind gusts up to 67 mph. Also, a wind sensor in Gleneden Beach reported wind gusts up to 62 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful Nor'easter developed off the SE CONUS on January 3rd and proceeded to move   on shore between eastern Maine and western Nova Scotia late in the day of January 4th. Widespread snow moved across Vermont during the morning hours, becoming steadier/heavier for much of eastern VT during the 4th. Wraparound snowfall during the night of the 4th and the day of the 5th added snowfall to Vermont's northern peaks and western slope communities. Overall snowfall statewide was 3 to 7 inches with upwards of 8-12 inches along the northern western slopes of the Green Mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 2 to 4 inches was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell to between minus 10 and minus 15 degrees during the morning hours. After a morning low of 2 above zero, the actual high temperature at Evansville was only 11 above zero. Arctic high pressure centered over the northern Plains produced these dangerously cold wind chills.

Wind chills fell to between minus 10 and minus 15 degrees during the morning hours. After a morning low of 2 above zero, the actual high temperature at Evansville was only 11 above zero. Arctic high pressure centered over the northern Plains produced these dangerously cold wind chills.
Southwest winds strengthened above high wind criteria as an upper air trough moved near the islands.  No significant property damage or injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an approaching front interacted with low-level moisture in the area, showers and isolated thunderstorms developed over parts of the island chain.  The rainfall caused small stream and drainage ditch flooding, and ponding on roadways.  No significant injuries or property damage were reported.

Mixed precipitation began in the evening of the 10th and changed to all snow by morning. There were reports of over 6 inches of snow by daybreak. Most of the snow diminished greatly by 4 PM, but a gravity wave band of moderate to heavy snow continued into the early evening along the north shore and into eastern Carlton County. ||Snowfall amounts in the Minnesota Arrowhead ranged from 7 to over 9 inches. Specific amounts were 9.3 at Winton, 8.2 25 miles east of Ely, 8 at Soudan and 7.1 in Cook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall measured 7.7 in Winton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the first time since January 2017, an event including both flooding and tornadoes impacted our area starting on February 11, 2018. Two tornadoes touched down across inland portions of the Florida Panhandle before sunrise, followed by persistent heavy rainfall that resulted in flooding at several river sites.  As an upper level trough dug southward across the western and central U.S., southerly flow drew moisture from the Gulf of Mexico northward into the tri-state area over the weekend. Upper air soundings measured this increased moisture with precipitable water values around 1.5 inches on Sunday, well above the 90th percentile and a record for the 12z February 11 sounding, although the record for that date and time are below the average max for this time of year. With a cold front and upper level trough west of the area, the persistent deep layer moisture helped to create a favorable set-up for high rainfall amounts.  This wet pattern resulted in copious amounts of rainfall across the tri-state region. The highest rainfall amounts were across the Florida Panhandle where 8 to 10 inches fell with localized areas receiving more than 10 inches across coastal Walton and Bay counties. The highest observed rainfall total was in Walton County, where a 48-hour rainfall total of 11.45 inches was recorded. Across southeast Alabama and portions of southwest Georgia, widespread 6 to 8 inches of rain fell. While one Flash Flood Warning was issued, the majority of the impacts from this event were from moderate rainfall rates over a prolonged period of time as convection trained across the tri-state area. These high rainfall totals resulted in numerous road closures across the Florida Panhandle from water covered roads and washed out roadways. In addition, a few roads were closed across southeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over portions of Cook Road caused a road closure from Creek Road to 2729 Cook Road.  This was due to a long period of moderate to occasionally heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The widespread severe drought conditions at the end of January worsened over New Mexico through early February as below normal precipitation continued across the state. The wet conditions experienced across central and eastern New Mexico from the monsoon season into late September were a distant memory by February. Several rounds of wind and very low humidity prompted red flag warnings on several days across eastern New Mexico. The weather pattern became more active for northern and western New Mexico by the middle of the month. A few winter storms impacted the higher terrain bringing modest improvements by the end of February. Statewide snowpack rebounded to a paltry 28 percent of median by the end of the month. Severe drought expanded to almost 80 percent of the state and extreme drought conditions were introduced to the northern high terrain. Weather conditions by the end of February 2018 began drying out once again with more critical fire weather. Grass fires were reported around Lincoln County prompting burn bans for the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought continued through February over the Far Northwest Highlands. A few weak weather systems moved across the area by mid to late February with mainly light rain and snow amounts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions over the West Slopes of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains deteriorated even further to extreme drought on February 13, 2018. A few weak storm systems moved through the area during February with light to moderate rain and snow amounts. This additional precipitation was no match for the well below normal snowpack.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather station on Mt Hebo reported wind gusts up to 64 mph.

CZ_NAME: CENTRAL COAST RANGE OF W OREGON
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rockhouse RAWS reported wind gusts up to 74 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large branches and a couple trees were downed by winds. Winds also caused power outages, with at least 5500 people losing power.  A weather station in Lake Oswego on top of Iron Mountain reported wind gusts up to 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system tracking northeast towards Vancouver Island generated strong winds along the Coast and in the Willamette Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Salem Airport reported wind gusts up to 45 mph.  Across the Portland/Salem area, 5500 people lost power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and Southwest Arkansas during the early morning hours of February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across Northeast Texas during the evening hours on the 20th through much of the 21st before gradually diminishing during the late evening hours. However, additional periods of moderate to heavy rain spread across much of East Texas on February 22nd north of the cold front, and continued through the morning hours on the 23rd. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of nine inches fell across much of East Texas during this 3 day period, resulting in widespread flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many low lying, poor drainage areas were flooded across Franklin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: I persistent upper level flow of moist southerly air brought waves of flooding and flash flooding to the region.  Significant flooding was reported across eastern portions of the area.  Two deaths were also reported, one person was washed away attempting to cross a stream, while a motorist was swept away in flood waters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Floodwaters 3-4 deep were over US-209. State Road 325/Gold Mine Road was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front crossed New England from the afternoon of January 12 to the morning of January 13. Strong southerly winds ahead of the front drew mild and humid air north over Southern New England. This helped generate heavy downpours before the front moved through.  Rainfall amounts ranged from one to three inches, except in Southeast Massachusetts where amounts ranged up to four inches.  Maximum wind gusts ranged from 45 to 65 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 751 PM EST, an amateur radio operator reported wires down in Boston on Sherwood Street.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 717 PM EST, an amateur radio operator reported a tree down in Middleborough on Chestnut Street at Daniel Drive.  At 837 AM on January 13, an amateur radio operator reported a tree down on wires in Lakeville on Pierce Avenue.
