EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the night of February 13th a surface low pressure formed over eastern Washington and tracked southeastward into central Idaho on February 14th before weakening. The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Spokane National Weather Service Office received 8.3 inches of snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system progressed east southeast from the Pacific Northwest into the Central and Southern Rockies on the morning of February 20th, reinforcing a cold front slowly southeast into East Texas and North Louisiana during the morning and afternoon hours on February 21st. A deep southwest flow aloft was present along and behind the front across the Southern Plains and Mississippi Valley, with weak embedded disturbances in the flow helping to enhance the development of scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms along and behind the front on the 21st. A warm, moist, and weakly unstable air mass had already spread north ahead of the front into Northeast Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana, with the southwest flow aloft tapping into the subtropical jet, thus transporting Pacific moisture northeast along and behind the front. Periods of moderate to at times, heavy rainfall fell along and behind the front across North Louisiana, and persisted through the early morning hours on the 23rd before diminishing. Widespread rainfall amounts of four to in excess of eight inches fell across North Louisiana from the morning hours of February 21st through the early morning hours on the 23rd. This resulted in periods of widespread flash flooding across much of North Louisiana during this 3 day period. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms developed across the southeast sections of Northcentral Louisiana on February 21st within the warm sector along the front, which produced wind damage across Western La Salle Parish.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Gate at Barksdale Air Force Base was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mixed precipitation began in the evening of the 10th and changed to all snow by morning. There were reports of over 6 inches of snow by daybreak. Most of the snow diminished greatly by 4 PM, but a gravity wave band of moderate to heavy snow continued into the early evening along the north shore and into eastern Carlton County. ||Snowfall amounts in the Minnesota Arrowhead ranged from 7 to over 9 inches. Specific amounts were 9.3 at Winton, 8.2 25 miles east of Ely, 8 at Soudan and 7.1 in Cook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall measured 6.2 6 miles southwest of Snowbank Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough dug southward across the Pacific Northwest during February 18th and 19th. Numerous hail showers developed along the coast, and snowfall occurred across the interior mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail/snow pellet covered road led to a 7 vehicle accident. Approximately a half inch of hail accumulated on the roadway. CHP reports that the multi-vehicle crash involved a motorcyclist who suffered minor injuries to her leg.

The western Columbia Basin received minor accumulations of snow which quickly melted during the day, however the rising terrain of the eastern basin including the Palouse region and the Spokane area as well as the northeastern mountains of Washington were north of the track and under the most intense precipitation from this storm. Widespread heavy snow accumulations resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The COOP Observer at Odessa recorded 4.0 inches of snow accumulation from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system approaching from the Great Basin combined with deepening surface low pressure over eastern New Mexico on the 18th. Strong southwest winds spread over the entire area by late in the afternoon and continue over much of the region through the 19th. Powerful wind gusts were reported in many areas with speeds topping out between 60 mph and 80 mph for an extended period of time around the higher terrain. Snow also developed with this system as moisture arrived beneath the upper level low pressure system. Snow showers first developed over the northern and western high terrain by late in the day on the 18th then gradually increased in coverage and intensity while moving slowly eastward toward the central mountain chain through the 19th. The heaviest snowfall impacted the area along the Continental Divide where roughly 2 to 6 inches was reported from near Quemado to Cuba. The Sangre de Cristo Mountains also picked up another 4 to 10 inches along with blowing snow. This system brought the second latest measurable snowfall to the Albuquerque Sunport with three tenths of an inch on February 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Raton Crews Airport reported sustained winds up to 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms developed in the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of June 6th. As this activity tracked east, a broken line of strong to severe thunderstorms developed. Hail up to the size of ping pong balls, thunderstorm wind gusts to 70 MPH and a brief tornado touchdown were reported. Heavy rain also fell leading to flash flooding in western Keith county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at the Ogallala Airport.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public estimated wind gust of 60 MPH at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought mixed wintry precipitation to the region. Precipitation began as snow during the morning hours but changed to a mix of sleet, freezing rain and snow during the afternoon hours, mixing as far north as the town of Schenectady. Precipitation transitioned back to snow during the evening hours before exiting the region northwest to southeast. Snowfall and sleet totals ranged from 1 inch to 12 inches, with the higher totals generally north and west of the Greater Capital District.
Temperatures dropped into the upper 20s to around 30 degrees on the morning of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures dropped into the upper 20s to around 30 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Winter Storm impacted the Big Country during the morning and early afternoon of February 21.  With surface temperatures in the middle to upper 20s, heavy sleet mixed with freezing rain fell across the Big Country.  This freezing precipitation resulted in numerous school closures and traffic accidents.  As the heavy precipitation ended by early afternoon on February 21, light freezing drizzle continued through the night across the Big Country into the early afternoon on February 22.  The weight of the ice resulted in some downed tree branches across the area.  ||The heavy sleet and freezing rain abated by the early afternoon on February 21 and became freezing drizzle as it continued across the remainder of West Central Texas, south of Interstate 20 during the night of February 21 and into the morning on February 22.  This continued to cause ice to accumulate on some roads, bridges, elevated objects and trees.  ||These conditions lead to a multiple vehicle pileup on Interstate 10 near Sonora.  Many school districts across West Central Texas began school about two hours late on February 22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and sleet fell at the airport and across Tom Green County on the morning of February 21.  Freezing drizzle returned during the overnight hours into the morning of February 22.  This freezing rain did collect on elevated objects like trees.  Some branches broke under the weight of the ice.  Many schools started classes by 10 AM on February 22.

This freezing rain did collect on elevated objects like trees.   Bronte and Robert Lee Independent School Districts started classes by 10 AM on February 22.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms to the north of a stalled frontal boundary produced locally heavy rainfall across much of east central and northeastern Oklahoma on the 23rd and 24th. Areas of McIntosh, Muskogee, Cherokee and Mayes Counties received between 2.5 and 6 inches of rain, which resulted in some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of several roads were reported flooded northwest of Tahlequah.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably high amounts of moisture flowed into central Indiana from the southwest and south during the latter part of February. At times during the period of February 19th to the 24th, the precipitable water values (a measure of moisture in the atmosphere) reached record levels for February.||Heavy rainfall fell early in the week (February 19/20) across northern sections of central Indiana. The second round of heavy rain on the 24th fell across southern sections of the area. In all, 7-day totals ending the morning of February 25th were from 3 to 6 inches across much of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported County Road 800 North closed from County Road 100 East to County Road 200 East due to high water from heavy rainfall.

CZ_NAME: UTAHS DIXIE AND ZION NATIONAL PARK
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds developed over Utah in association with a cold front on the morning of February 10, with the strongest wind gusts observed over the mountains of northern Utah. Behind the front, gusty canyon winds developed in far southwest Utah during the late afternoon and early evening hours of February 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The White Reef RAWS recorded a peak wind gust of 63 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds developed over Utah in association with a cold front on the morning of February 10, with the strongest wind gusts observed over the mountains of northern Utah. Behind the front, gusty canyon winds developed in far southwest Utah during the late afternoon and early evening hours of February 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Empire Peak in Deer Valley recorded a peak wind gust of 82 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm entered the state on February 18, bringing heavy snowfall to both valley and mountain locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall included 24 inches at Snowbird and Alta Ski Area, 23 inches at Brighton Resort, and 20 inches at SunCrest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant winter storm entered the state on February 18, bringing heavy snowfall to both valley and mountain locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Salt Lake and Tooele Valleys saw widespread heavy snowfall. Storm total snowfall reports included 25 inches in Sandy, 23 inches in Cottonwood Heights, 17.5 inches in Tooele, 15 inches in Olympus Cove, and 14 inches in Taylorsville. For the calendar day of February 19, Tooele recorded 13 inches of snow, which broke the calendar day record of 8 inches, set in 1945.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level shortwave trough moved from the Pacific Northwest and northern California to central Montana and western Wyoming from the early evening of March 3rd through late evening of March 4th. At 700 mb, a low- to mid-level shortwave trough shifted from Idaho and vicinity to eastern Montana. Simultaneously, a low pressure center developed within this shortwave. Horizontal wind shear associated with the counter-clockwise, inward circulation of this low led to weak 850-700 mb frontogenesis and associated ascent over North-Central and Southwest Montana. Large-scale ascent associated with the aforementioned frontogenesis and upper-level divergence ahead of the shortwave trough, combined with sufficient moisture, led to the development of snow over the region. At the surface, a front meandered near the Rocky Mountain Front and the mountains near Great Falls. This front separated cold air to its north from relatively-milder air to its south. This system delivered significant snow amounts to portions of North-Central and Southwest Montana, while the heaviest snow was focused east of I-15. While snow fell March 3rd through 5th, the bulk of accumulation occurred on the 3rd and 4th. In addition, Great Falls set a new snowfall record for March 4th (5.1 inches). The previous record was 4.0 inches set in 1918.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: MT-66 closed in Blaine County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of light to moderate rain led to flooding across portions of eastern Kentucky, particularly southeastern Kentucky, beginning during the overnight hours of Friday, February 9 into Saturday, February 10, 2018. This occurred along and ahead of a slow moving frontal boundary as generally between 1.5 and 4.5 inches of rain fell across eastern Kentucky. The hardest hit area was Harlan County, where flooding occurred across much of the county as up to 5.5 inches of rain fell. A state of emergency was declared as the Cumberland River at Baxter reached major flood stage, prompting the closure of all of the city of Harlan's floodgates. The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of Highway 476 was flooded near Lost Creek due to Troublesome Creek coming out of its banks. A portion of Wolverine Road was flooded due to the North Fork of the Kentucky River overflowing its banks. Kentucky Highway 541 was under water near Jackson. A car was stranded in the flood water near the Kentucky Mountain Bible College in this same location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of light to moderate rain led to flooding across portions of eastern Kentucky, particularly southeastern Kentucky, beginning during the overnight hours of Friday, February 9 into Saturday, February 10, 2018. This occurred along and ahead of a slow moving frontal boundary as generally between 1.5 and 4.5 inches of rain fell across eastern Kentucky. The hardest hit area was Harlan County, where flooding occurred across much of the county as up to 5.5 inches of rain fell. A state of emergency was declared as the Cumberland River at Baxter reached major flood stage, prompting the closure of all of the city of Harlan's floodgates. The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded in and around Pineville and Middlesboro including: Old Pineville Pike in Middlesboro, Highway's 2013 and 1534 in Pineville, Highway 221 at mile marker 9 in Stoney Fork and the intersection of 17th Street and Cumberland Ave in Middlesboro. A water rescue had to be performed 4 miles west northwest of Pineville at Magnet Hollow on Kentucky Highway 92 after a motorist drove into a flooded roadway. There was several feet of water across portions of Old Bell High Road near Pineville. Flooding also caused a mudslide on Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro. The road was closed for around 2 weeks to clear the mudslide and repair the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow caused minor travel delays in the Motherlode. Weather spotters reported 1 of snow in Placerville, a trace at Shingle Springs(elevations 1400 feet), and a trace in Auburn (elevation 1500 feet).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Winter Storm impacted the Big Country during the morning and early afternoon of February 21.  With surface temperatures in the middle to upper 20s, heavy sleet mixed with freezing rain fell across the Big Country.  This freezing precipitation resulted in numerous school closures and traffic accidents.  As the heavy precipitation ended by early afternoon on February 21, light freezing drizzle continued through the night across the Big Country into the early afternoon on February 22.  The weight of the ice resulted in some downed tree branches across the area.  ||The heavy sleet and freezing rain abated by the early afternoon on February 21 and became freezing drizzle as it continued across the remainder of West Central Texas, south of Interstate 20 during the night of February 21 and into the morning on February 22.  This continued to cause ice to accumulate on some roads, bridges, elevated objects and trees.  ||These conditions lead to a multiple vehicle pileup on Interstate 10 near Sonora.  Many school districts across West Central Texas began school about two hours late on February 22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An inch of sleet mixed with freezing rain was estimated in Anson via social media.  All schools were canceled as roads became treacherous.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Winter Storm impacted the Big Country during the morning and early afternoon of February 21.  With surface temperatures in the middle to upper 20s, heavy sleet mixed with freezing rain fell across the Big Country.  This freezing precipitation resulted in numerous school closures and traffic accidents.  As the heavy precipitation ended by early afternoon on February 21, light freezing drizzle continued through the night across the Big Country into the early afternoon on February 22.  The weight of the ice resulted in some downed tree branches across the area.  ||The heavy sleet and freezing rain abated by the early afternoon on February 21 and became freezing drizzle as it continued across the remainder of West Central Texas, south of Interstate 20 during the night of February 21 and into the morning on February 22.  This continued to cause ice to accumulate on some roads, bridges, elevated objects and trees.  ||These conditions lead to a multiple vehicle pileup on Interstate 10 near Sonora.  Many school districts across West Central Texas began school about two hours late on February 22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Plenty of sleet and freezing rain was reported in Ballinger via social media.  All schools were canceled as roads became treacherous.  A few trees were uprooted by the weight of the ice on the trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure brought snow to parts of southwestern Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and western Maryland starting the afternoon of the 17th and ending early in the morning on the 18th. The snow started fast with 1-2 per hour accumulations. With a recent warm up, accumulation was largely confined to grassy surfaces. The highest snowfall totals fell in the mountains of northern West Virginia, western Maryland, and the Laurels of southwestern Pennsylvania, where the snow ranged from 6-8 inches in the highest peaks.

Over two inches of rain fell in portions of Knox county on the 24th of February, leading to some isolated flooding.||Unseasonably high amounts of moisture flowed into central Indiana from the southwest and south during the latter part of February. At times during the period of February 19th to the 24th, the precipitable water values (a measure of moisture in the atmosphere) reached record levels for February.||Heavy rainfall fell early in the week (February 19/20) across northern sections of central Indiana. The second round of heavy rain on the 24th fell across southern sections of the area. In all, 7-day totals ending the morning of February 25th were from 3 to 6 inches across much of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over parts of State Road 61 between Monroe City and the Pike County line due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms early in the morning of March 5 produced a damaging lightning strike.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike early in the morning of March 5 started a fire which burned down a corn crib.  The resulting fire damaged an auger and two farm trailers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of snow melt and rainfall brought middle portions of the Big Sioux River above flood stage in early March. Crests were at minor flood stage near Hawarden (HWDI4) and Akron (AKRI4), impacting only lowland agricultural areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall along with snow melt caused minor flooding of lowland agricultural areas along middle portions of the Big Sioux River. The river reached a crest of 0.1 feet above flood stage near Akron (gage site AKRI4) on March 8.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of snow melt and rainfall brought minor flooding to portions the Rock River. A crest at minor flood stage occurred near Hardwick (HRDM5), impacting only lowland agricultural areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall along with snow melt caused minor flooding of lowland agricultural areas along upper portions of the Rock River. The river reached a crest of 2.2 feet above flood stage near Hardwick (gage site HRDM5) on March 6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of snow melt and a minor ice jam produced minor flooding on Pipestone Creek. A crest at minor flood stage occurred at Pipestone (PIPM5), impacting lowland agricultural areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water levels with snow melt and a minor ice jam resulted in minor flooding along Pipestone Creek. The river reached a crest of 0.3 feet above flood stage at Pipestone (gage site PIPM5) on March 20.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall, along with runoff from melting snow from March 23-24, pushed much of the Little Sioux River back above flood stage after a few days below flood stage.  Reaches from Milford (MIFI4) to Spencer (SPWI4) to Linn Grove (LNNI4) again had waters invade mainly agricultural lowlands, along with city greenways in Spencer and Sioux Rapids.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow melt runoff on top of already high river levels produced minor flooding of lowland agricultural areas along upper portions of the Little Sioux River. River levels reached 0.9 feet above flood stage near Milford (gage site MIFI4) by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific cold front accompanied by a sharp surface low pressure trough crossed North-Central and Southwest Montana during the late morning through evening of March 9th. This front was followed by a period of breezy and westerly downslope winds. In several locations, these winds gusted to warning-criteria strength.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet station 9-miles WSW of Stanford recorded 60 mph peak gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact shortwave trough moved northward along and near the Continental Divide in Montana. This system delivered accumulating snow to most of the mountains of North-Central and Southwest Montana. Most lower elevations in both regions experienced a mix of rain and snow, with minor snow accumulations and impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Montana DOT reported chains required on MT-200 from Rogers Pass to junction with Flesher Pass Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported 77 mph peak gust in Babb.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported 66 mph wind gust 1-mile northeast of Choteau.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably cold temperatures and frost caused potentially significant damage to the 2018 Central Valley almond crop harvest by happening during the sensitive blooming phase. Temperatures in many locations reached or fell below the critical bloom temperature of 27. Some in the agricultural community were projecting frost damage ...worst since perhaps the 1970s. (AgFax Tree Crops, Feb 26, 2018). ||Snow fell in the Sierra, with unusually cold temperatures allowing snow down into the Sierra foothills, to elevations as low as 1400 feet. This caused some travel slow downs and delays in areas that usually don't see accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow caused chain controls and travel delays in the Sierra, with road sensor data showing speeds briefly dropping to around 15 mph on I80 near pass level on the 19th and again on the 22nd. Caltrans reported 6 of snow at Soda Springs, 3 at Kingvale. Kirkwood Ski Resort reported 10 of new snow. Other reports include 6 at Bear Valley Ski Resort, 6 at Squaw-Alpine Ski Resort, 5 at Sugar Bowl Ski Resort, 4 at Tahoe Donner Ski Resort, and 2 at Dodge Ridge Ski Resort.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue had to be performed in Bonnyman on Typo Road. Four individuals and pets were trapped inside a home after it had become surrounded by 4 feet of water after First Creek overtopped its banks. A water rescue also had to be performed on Cherokee Hills Road in Hazard after a man drove his car into the north fork of the swollen Kentucky River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of light to moderate rain led to flooding across portions of eastern Kentucky, particularly southeastern Kentucky, beginning during the overnight hours of Friday, February 9 into Saturday, February 10, 2018. This occurred along and ahead of a slow moving frontal boundary as generally between 1.5 and 4.5 inches of rain fell across eastern Kentucky. The hardest hit area was Harlan County, where flooding occurred across much of the county as up to 5.5 inches of rain fell. A state of emergency was declared as the Cumberland River at Baxter reached major flood stage, prompting the closure of all of the city of Harlan's floodgates. The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over the Florida Peninsula throughout the afternoon hours and pushed west towards the Gulf Coast through the early evening. Some of these storms produced marine wind gusts along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The WeatherFlow station on Egmont Key (XEGM) recorded a 40 knot marine thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over the Florida Peninsula throughout the afternoon hours and pushed west towards the Gulf Coast through the early evening. Some of these storms produced marine wind gusts along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at St. Pete-Clearwater International Airport (KPIE) recorded a 40 knot marine thunderstorm wind gust.

CZ_NAME: ENGLEWOOD TO TARPON SPRINGS FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed over the eastern Gulf of Mexico and pushed east towards the coast. A wind gust from one thunderstorm capsized a boat, causing minor injuries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A parasailing boat was about 2 miles west of Blind Pass when it was hit by a thunderstorm wind gust. The sail was open at the back of the boat, but no one was in the harness. The crew was unable to pull the sail in due to the wind and the boat capsized, injuring one of the crew and causing minor injuries to some of the passengers. It is unknown if the boat sustained any damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another cold front moved through the area bringing strong northwest winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another cold front moved through the area bringing strong northwest winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed in Sanford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep area of low pressure passed off the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at New Haven Airport measured a wind gust to 58 mph at 1113 am. Around 130 pm,the media reported a downed tree on Mather Street, closing the street. Social media reported a large tree down onto Mitchell Drive in New Haven at 140 pm. In West Haven, media reports of many trees down across the town were received at 325 pm. Law Enforcement in the town of Hamden reported a tree and wires down at Circular Avenue and Gilbert Avenue at 325 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the Tennessee Valley early on the 7th to the New Jersey coast by the late afternoon of the 7th to off the New England coast by the late evening. This low brought a heavy snow to a large part of central New York on the 7th. Snowfall totals ranged from 5 to 12 inches over many locations in central New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 6 to 10 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the Tennessee Valley early on the 7th to the New Jersey coast by the late afternoon of the 7th to off the New England coast by the late evening. This low brought a heavy snow to a large part of central New York on the 7th. Snowfall totals ranged from 5 to 12 inches over many locations in central New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 8 to 11 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms moved east through the Tampa Bay area throughout the late morning and early afternoon hours. One storm developed a brief tornado as it interacted with an outflow boundary, damaging the roof of an apartment in Tampa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported on moderate roof damage to a 2 story apartment building, where a portion of a roof was removed. Little, if any, surrounding damage was observed. A weak radar rotation was observed in the vicinity at the same time, indicating that the damage was likely caused by a tornado.

CZ_NAME: WILMETTE HARBOR TO NORTHERLY ISLAND IL
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front produced a narrow line of thunderstorms which moved across southern Lake Michigan during the afternoon of February 20th.

Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet recorded 72 mph peak gust 9-miles SSW of Fort Benton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mesonet recorded 63 mph peak gust 7-miles east of Geyser.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported 62 mph peak gust 1-mile ESE of Great Falls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow caused significant travel problems as well as school delays and closures in the foothills. Snow also resulted in chain controls and travel slowdowns in the mountains. The snow continued into early March, bringing additional impacts.||Thunderstorms with large amounts of small hail blanketed portions of the Sacramento, causing major travel problems. Funnel clouds were also reported in the Sacramento area, but no tornado touchdowns observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least one funnel cloud was reported near Sacramento International Airport. No touchdown or damage was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure along an occluded front in the Tennessee Valley redeveloped off the North Carolina Coast on Monday Night March 12th and underwent rapid deepening as it moved northeast toward to the 40 North/70 West benchmark coordinates on the Tuesday Morning March 13th. This strong low and a weaker area of low pressure in the Great Lakes lead to the development of precipitation across the region on the afternoon of the 12th, which persisted into the morning of the 13th. The precipitation was mainly snow to the north of The Pennsylvania Turnpike. Further to the south, precipitation began as rain and gradually changed over to snow on Monday Night. Snowfall amounts over Eastern Pennsylvania ranged from 3 to 5 inches across the Southern Poconos, 1 to 3 inches over the Lehigh Valley, and generally less than one inch further southeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low pressure along an occluded front in the Tennessee Valley redeveloped off the North Carolina Coast on Monday Night March 12th and underwent rapid deepening as it moved northeast toward to the 40 North/70 West benchmark coordinates on the Tuesday Morning March 13th. This strong low and a weaker area of low pressure in the Great Lakes lead to the development of precipitation across the region on the afternoon of the 12th, which persisted into the morning of the 13th. The precipitation was mainly snow to the north of The Pennsylvania Turnpike. Further to the south, precipitation began as rain and gradually changed over to snow on Monday Night. Snowfall amounts over Eastern Pennsylvania ranged from 3 to 5 inches across the Southern Poconos, 1 to 3 inches over the Lehigh Valley, and generally less than one inch further southeast. In Carbon County, snowfall amounts ranged from 1.4 inches 4 miles West-Southwest of Lehighton to 3.5 inches in Albrightsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure brought snow to parts of southwestern Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and western Maryland starting the afternoon of the 17th and ending early in the morning on the 18th. The snow started fast with 1-2 per hour accumulations. With a recent warm up, accumulation was largely confined to grassy surfaces. The highest snowfall totals fell in the mountains of northern West Virginia, western Maryland, and the Laurels of southwestern Pennsylvania, where the snow ranged from 6-8 inches in the highest peaks.

In most of southeast Missouri except the Mississippi River delta counties of Scott, New Madrid, and Mississippi, wind chills fell to between minus 10 and minus 15 degrees during the morning hours. After a morning low of 2 above zero, the actual high temperature at Cape Girardeau was only 15 degrees. Arctic high pressure centered over the northern Plains produced these dangerously cold wind chills.

Widespread dense fog over far southern Illinois formed during the early evening hours and persisted through late evening. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less at times. The dense fog formed under a weak surface high pressure ridge that extended from the central Plains east across the lower Ohio Valley.

CZ_NAME: TARPON SPRINGS TO SUWANNEE RIVER FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture along a stalled cold front across the northern Gulf of Mexico led to scattered thunderstorms moving east into the Florida Peninsula during the morning and afternoon hours. A couple of these storms produced gusty winds along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NOS NWLON station at Cedar Key (CKYF1) recorded a 37 knot thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture along a stalled cold front across the northern Gulf of Mexico led to scattered thunderstorms moving east into the Florida Peninsula during the morning and afternoon hours. A couple of these storms produced gusty winds along the coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Albert Whitted Airport (KSPG) measured a 24 knot thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early Spring storm moved out of the Rockies, swinging across Nebraska early on the morning of the 24th. Precipitation blossomed within the leading warm advection region, including a few thunderstorms on the evening of the 23rd, which transitioned from rain to snow lifting northeast across northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, starting as a brief period of rain, became heavy at times in the early morning hours of March 24. Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, with snowfall accumulating to 6 to 9 inches, including 9.0 inches at Sibley, 7.0 inches 4 miles east of Sioux Rapids, 6.5 inches at Spencer and near Everly, 6.2 inches at Sanborn and 6.0 inches at Primghar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early Spring storm moved out of the Rockies, swinging across Nebraska early on the morning of the 24th. Precipitation blossomed within the leading warm advection region, including a few thunderstorms across northwest Iowa during the evening of the 23rd, which transitioned from rain to snow lifting northeast across northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, starting as a brief period of rain, became moderate to briefly heavy by late evening on March 23 and into the early morning hours of March 24. Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, with snowfall accumulating to 3 to 6 inches, including 5.0 inches at Cherokee, 4.5 inches at Rock Rapids, 4.1 inches at Washta, and 4.0 inches at Orange City, Sioux Center and Holstein and 3.2 inches at Remsen.

Runoff from snow melt along with periods of rainfall and some minor ice jams through mid March caused minor flooding along portions of the Vermillion River. Impacts were found generally in lowland agricultural locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall along with snow melt and some ice jamming caused minor flooding of lowland agricultural areas along portions of the Vermillion River. The river reached an estimated crest of 0.6 feet above flood stage near Wakonda (gage site WKAS2) on March 27.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure passed by to the south behind a cold front. There was enough cold air that  moved in behind the front for rain to end as a period of accumulating snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totaled up to 3.0 inches near Slanesville.

An area of low pressure tracked across the Great Lakes on Sunday the 4th as another area of low pressure moved up the east coast reaching the New England coast by the early morning hours on the 5th. The low pressure over the Great Lakes eventually merged with the low moving up the east coast. This brought a widespread snow to a large part of north central New York from the early morning hours on the 4th to the evening of the 4th. Snowfall totals ranged from 6 to 12 inches with locally up to 17 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 5 to 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread showers and thunderstorms to the north of a stalled frontal boundary produced locally heavy rainfall across much of east central and northeastern Oklahoma on the 23rd and 24th. Areas of McIntosh, Muskogee, Cherokee and Mayes Counties received between 2.5 and 6 inches of rain, which resulted in some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Gulick Street were flooded and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Winter Storm impacted the Big Country during the morning and early afternoon of February 21.  With surface temperatures in the middle to upper 20s, heavy sleet mixed with freezing rain fell across the Big Country.  This freezing precipitation resulted in numerous school closures and traffic accidents.  As the heavy precipitation ended by early afternoon on February 21, light freezing drizzle continued through the night across the Big Country into the early afternoon on February 22.  The weight of the ice resulted in some downed tree branches across the area.  ||The heavy sleet and freezing rain abated by the early afternoon on February 21 and became freezing drizzle as it continued across the remainder of West Central Texas, south of Interstate 20 during the night of February 21 and into the morning on February 22.  This continued to cause ice to accumulate on some roads, bridges, elevated objects and trees.  ||These conditions lead to a multiple vehicle pileup on Interstate 10 near Sonora.  Many school districts across West Central Texas began school about two hours late on February 22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Crockett County had a two hour delay because of ice on roads.  Area observations did show light freezing drizzle occurred throughout the night into mid morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a lack of rainfall, severe drought spread over the western two thirds of Oklahoma and extreme drought encroached upon much of western Oklahoma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong nearly dry cold front pushed across our area, resulting in a few non-thunderstorm severe wind gusts across western Oklahoma, where a High Wind Warning was in effect.  Strong wind gusts had occurred behind the front across central Oklahoma, where a wind advisory was in effect.

A strong nearly dry cold front pushed across our area, resulting in a few non-thunderstorm severe wind gusts across western Oklahoma, where a High Wind Warning was in effect.  Strong wind gusts had occurred behind the front across central Oklahoma, where a wind advisory was in effect.
The Scullin fire burned approximately 2100 acres in Murray county on the 18th.
The Hopewell fire burned approximately 200 acres in Murray county on the 19th.
The Tabler fire burned approximately 600 acres in Love county on the 22nd.
The Barick and Meachum fires burned approximately 993 acres in Custer county on the 27th.

A winter storm brought mixed wintry precipitation to the region. Precipitation began as snow during the morning hours but changed to a mix of sleet, freezing rain and snow during the afternoon hours, mixing as far north as the town of Schenectady. Precipitation transitioned back to snow during the evening hours before exiting the region northwest to southeast. Snowfall and sleet totals ranged from 1 inch to 12 inches, with the higher totals generally north and west of the Greater Capital District.

With a front and upper air trough in the area and low level moisture around the state, heavy showers and thunderstorms occurred from Kauai to the Big Island of Hawaii.  The precipitation produced small stream and drainage ditch flooding and ponding on roadways in most cases.  There was also a flash flood that affected northern sections of Kauai on the 4th, plus a report from Maui in the afternoon of the 5th indicated small hail had dropped from a thunderstorm.   No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the Tennessee Valley early on the 7th to the New Jersey coast by the late afternoon of the 7th to off the New England coast by the late evening. This low brought a heavy snow to a large part of central New York on the 7th. Snowfall totals ranged from 5 to 12 inches over many locations in central New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 7 to 9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the western side of the Appalachians Tuesday night, February 6th into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 7th. Initially the precipitation started as snow across the upper Ohio Valley. As the warm air surged north, precipitation type changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain. Locations in northern West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania changed over to rain with temperatures climbing into the upper 30s to lower 40s. Eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia Panhandle, and locations from central Beaver county, northeast into southern Jefferson county, Pennsylvania switched over to freezing rain. Ice accumulation was around a quarter of an inch for these places. Farther north along the I-80 corridor and parts of interior southeastern Ohio, cold air remained socked in, keeping the precipitation all snow. Several inches of snow fell with the highest amounts located across parts of northern Butler county northeast into Clarion, Jefferson, and Forest counties. For eastern Ohio, Columbiana, Carroll, southwest into Coshocton county around six inches of snow fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of low pressure systems moved across central, southern Vermont with a redeveloping coastal low off the New England shoreline. A prolonged period of light to moderate snow fell across the region with scattered heavier snowfalls as well. A widespread 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across the region with 6 to 12 inches across portions of southern VT and the Northeast Kingdom.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowfall of 2 to 4 inches occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from the Tennessee valley across southern New England on February 7th. It was a quick but potent system with duration of 6 to 8 hours and snowfall rates of an inch or more for several hours. Snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 inches were observed across much of northern New York.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread 5 to 10 inches of snow fell across Clinton county, including 10 inches in Dannemora and Beekmantown. Snowfall rates were 1-2 inches per hour at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of rainfall was generated along the backside of a slow moving cold front across portions of Arkansas on February 21st. Areal flooding continued into February 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County road 912 at the intersection of county road 907 closed due to flooding along the Whitten Creek. One water rescue was done from a driver entering the flooded portion of the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water temporarily blocked Highway 79, near the railroad trestle, in Marianna.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 166 was blocked at mile 3 due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms pushed rapidly east at 50 mph across northern Alabama between 8 pm and Midnight.  Numerous reports of wind damage were reported, including trees and power lines being knocked down, and some structural damage.  The heaviest damage occurred in several narrow swaths  where winds exceeded 70 mph across Lauderdale and Colbert Counties including the Muscle Shoals, Sheffield, Tuscumbia and Florence area, and Morgan County, including the city of Decatur where damage was quite extensive.  Power outages resulted in several of these locations as well.  Other swaths of tree and power line damage occurred in Cullman, Madison, Jackson, Marshall and DeKalb Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were knocked down at the campground on CR 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line of strong to severe thunderstorms pushed rapidly east at 50 mph across northern Alabama between 8 pm and Midnight.  Numerous reports of wind damage were reported, including trees and power lines being knocked down, and some structural damage.  The heaviest damage occurred in several narrow swaths  where winds exceeded 70 mph across Lauderdale and Colbert Counties including the Muscle Shoals, Sheffield, Tuscumbia and Florence area, and Morgan County, including the city of Decatur where damage was quite extensive.  Power outages resulted in several of these locations as well.  Other swaths of tree and power line damage occurred in Cullman, Madison, Jackson, Marshall and DeKalb Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was knocked down at 4389 CR 41.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a front and upper air trough in the area and low level moisture around the state, heavy showers and thunderstorms occurred from Kauai to the Big Island of Hawaii.  The precipitation produced small stream and drainage ditch flooding and ponding on roadways in most cases.  There was also a flash flood that affected northern sections of Kauai on the 4th, plus a report from Maui in the afternoon of the 5th indicated small hail had dropped from a thunderstorm.   No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

With a front and upper air trough in the area and low level moisture around the state, heavy showers and thunderstorms occurred from Kauai to the Big Island of Hawaii.  The precipitation produced small stream and drainage ditch flooding and ponding on roadways in most cases.  There was also a flash flood that affected northern sections of Kauai on the 4th, plus a report from Maui in the afternoon of the 5th indicated small hail had dropped from a thunderstorm.   No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

Later in the month, the focus shifted from ice to areas of heavy rain and some severe weather. A front wobbled across the region from the 20th through the 23rd, and a storm system roared through the middle of the country on the 24th.  Forecast models showed there was at least twice the usual moisture for late February. Given a tremendous amount of liquid to wring out of the clouds, and with downpours lasting for several days, flash flooding and eventual river flooding became headlines.  Through 600 am CST on the 25th, four to more than ten inches of water was measured in a five day period. At many locations, this was two months of rain in just a few days. Amounts included 10.55 inches at Mount Ida (Montgomery County), 9.82 inches at Hot Springs (Garland County), and 8.83 inches at Little Rock (Pulaski County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over bridges on Manford Road and Mill Creek Road in Caddo Gap.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of rainfall was generated along the backside of a slow moving cold front across portions of West Tennessee during the late evening hours of February 21st continuing into February 22nd. Another round of rain moved through parts of West Tennessee during the late evening of February 22 into the morning hours of February 23rd. Areal flooding was common across West Tennessee during this period with many closed roads.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in the flooding of several roads in Dyer County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Winter Storm impacted the Big Country during the morning and early afternoon of February 21.  With surface temperatures in the middle to upper 20s, heavy sleet mixed with freezing rain fell across the Big Country.  This freezing precipitation resulted in numerous school closures and traffic accidents.  As the heavy precipitation ended by early afternoon on February 21, light freezing drizzle continued through the night across the Big Country into the early afternoon on February 22.  The weight of the ice resulted in some downed tree branches across the area.  ||The heavy sleet and freezing rain abated by the early afternoon on February 21 and became freezing drizzle as it continued across the remainder of West Central Texas, south of Interstate 20 during the night of February 21 and into the morning on February 22.  This continued to cause ice to accumulate on some roads, bridges, elevated objects and trees.  ||These conditions lead to a multiple vehicle pileup on Interstate 10 near Sonora.  Many school districts across West Central Texas began school about two hours late on February 22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A multiple vehicle pileup occurred on Interstate 10 on the morning of February 22 around 6 AM between Mile Markers 400 and 401 near Sonora.  Vehicles involved were cars, pickups, commercial tractor trailers and pumpers.  They were scattered across the median as well as east and west bound lanes of the interstate at two separate sites.  This resulted in the closing of about 3 miles of Interstate 10 through noon.   Traffic was rerouted.  There were some injuries, but no fatalities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure brought snow to parts of southwestern Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and western Maryland starting the afternoon of the 17th and ending early in the morning on the 18th. The snow started fast with 1-2 per hour accumulations. With a recent warm up, accumulation was largely confined to grassy surfaces. The highest snowfall totals fell in the mountains of northern West Virginia, western Maryland, and the Laurels of southwestern Pennsylvania, where the snow ranged from 6-8 inches in the highest peaks.

A prolonged period of light to moderate rain led to flooding across portions of eastern Kentucky, particularly southeastern Kentucky, beginning during the overnight hours of Friday, February 9 into Saturday, February 10, 2018. This occurred along and ahead of a slow moving frontal boundary as generally between 1.5 and 4.5 inches of rain fell across eastern Kentucky. The hardest hit area was Harlan County, where flooding occurred across much of the county as up to 5.5 inches of rain fell. A state of emergency was declared as the Cumberland River at Baxter reached major flood stage, prompting the closure of all of the city of Harlan's floodgates. The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick moving low pressure brought snow to parts of southwestern Pennsylvania, northern West Virginia, and western Maryland starting the afternoon of the 17th and ending early in the morning on the 18th. The snow started fast with 1-2 per hour accumulations. With a recent warm up, accumulation was largely confined to grassy surfaces. The highest snowfall totals fell in the mountains of northern West Virginia, western Maryland, and the Laurels of southwestern Pennsylvania, where the snow ranged from 6-8 inches in the highest peaks.

Isolated severe storms developed ahead of a cold front during the late afternoon in a moist and unstable air mass. A more organized comma head and trailing line of storms moved into the area mid to late evening. Some of the storms produced wind damage across portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down on power lines near Lake Lucas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonably high amounts of moisture flowed into central Indiana from the southwest and south during the latter part of February. At times during the period of February 19th to the 24th, the precipitable water values (a measure of moisture in the atmosphere) reached record levels for February.||Heavy rainfall fell early in the week (February 19/20) across northern sections of central Indiana. The second round of heavy rain on the 24th fell across southern sections of the area. In all, 7-day totals ending the morning of February 25th were from 3 to 6 inches across much of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: State Road 234 was shut down due to flooding from heavy rainfall.

CZ_NAME: VOLUSIA-BREVARD COUNTY LINE TO SEBASTIAN INLET 20-60NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating and sufficient moisture allowed for showers and thunderstorms to develop along the east coast sea breeze. During the evening, westerly flow aloft pushed the storms back east across Brevard County and over the open waters of the Atlantic. One storm produced strong winds at a buoy offshore near Brevard County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Buoy 41009 measured a peak wind gust of 37 knots from the west-northwest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures dropped into the upper 20s to around 30 degrees on the morning of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures dropped into the upper 20s to around 30 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of low pressure systems moved across central, southern Vermont with a redeveloping coastal low off the New England shoreline. A prolonged period of light to moderate snow fell across the region with scattered heavier snowfalls as well. A widespread 2 to 5 inches of snow fell across the region with 6 to 12 inches across portions of southern VT and the Northeast Kingdom.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread snowfall of 3 to 5 inches occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall, along with runoff from melting snow from March 23-24, pushed much of the Little Sioux River back above flood stage after a few days below flood stage.  Reaches from Milford (MIFI4) to Spencer (SPWI4) to Linn Grove (LNNI4) again had waters invade mainly agricultural lowlands, along with city greenways in Spencer and Sioux Rapids.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow melt runoff on top of already high river levels produced minor flooding of lowland agricultural areas along upper portions of the Little Sioux River. River levels reached 2.3 feet above flood stage at Spencer (gage site SPWI4) by the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unsettled northwesterly flow aloft resided over North-Central Montana on March 26th into 27th. Within this flow, a shortwave trough moved southeastward over the region during late morning through early evening of the 27th. Along and ahead of this shortwave, a 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak resulted in strong cross-barrier flow along the Rocky Mountain Front. This jet also extended eastward over much of North-Central Montana. The strong cross-barrier flow and associated enhanced mountain wave activity likely contributed to the high winds along the Rocky Mountain Front. In addition, several high wind gusts occurred along the plains of eastern Glacier County as well as Cascade, Chouteau, and Judith Basin Counties. In these areas, a combination of downslope flow and diurnal atmospheric mixing tapping into the 50 to 60 knot 700 mb jet streak likely contributed to the high wind gusts on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cut Bank Airport ASOS recorded 62 mph peak gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level shortwave trough moved from the Pacific Northwest and northern California to central Montana and western Wyoming from the early evening of March 3rd through late evening of March 4th. At 700 mb, a low- to mid-level shortwave trough shifted from Idaho and vicinity to eastern Montana. Simultaneously, a low pressure center developed within this shortwave. Horizontal wind shear associated with the counter-clockwise, inward circulation of this low led to weak 850-700 mb frontogenesis and associated ascent over North-Central and Southwest Montana. Large-scale ascent associated with the aforementioned frontogenesis and upper-level divergence ahead of the shortwave trough, combined with sufficient moisture, led to the development of snow over the region. At the surface, a front meandered near the Rocky Mountain Front and the mountains near Great Falls. This front separated cold air to its north from relatively-milder air to its south. This system delivered significant snow amounts to portions of North-Central and Southwest Montana, while the heaviest snow was focused east of I-15. While snow fell March 3rd through 5th, the bulk of accumulation occurred on the 3rd and 4th. In addition, Great Falls set a new snowfall record for March 4th (5.1 inches). The previous record was 4.0 inches set in 1918.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US-191 closed from Eddie's Corner to junction with US-12 near Harlowton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture and westerly winds allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop along the west coast of Florida during the early afternoon and push east through the afternoon and early evening. One of these storms produced damaging wind gusts. A lightning strike from another storm sparked a house fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning sparked a fire in the attic of a house in Lakeland. Fire crews arrived and quickly put out the fire before it spread to the rest of the home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracked southeast of New York, spreading light to moderate snowfall across southern Vermont. The snowfall primarily fell Saturday night into early Sunday morning, with reports of up to 6.5 inches in the southern Green Mountains.

A low pressure system tracked southeast of New York, spreading light to moderate snowfall across southern Vermont. The snowfall primarily fell Saturday night into early Sunday morning, with reports of up to 6.5 inches in the southern Green Mountains.
Thunderstorms developed along sea breeze boundaries and pushed west into the Nature Coast during the early evening. One of these storms produced damaging wind gusts in Citrus County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Citrus County Emergency Management reported some tree limbs and small branches were knocked down. A sign mounted on a metal pipe was also knocked down, but the pipe was reported to be old and rusted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of light to moderate rain led to flooding across portions of eastern Kentucky, particularly southeastern Kentucky, beginning during the overnight hours of Friday, February 9 into Saturday, February 10, 2018. This occurred along and ahead of a slow moving frontal boundary as generally between 1.5 and 4.5 inches of rain fell across eastern Kentucky. The hardest hit area was Harlan County, where flooding occurred across much of the county as up to 5.5 inches of rain fell. A state of emergency was declared as the Cumberland River at Baxter reached major flood stage, prompting the closure of all of the city of Harlan's floodgates. The floodgate for the city of Pikeville was also closed as the Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy River breached 38 feet. Additional emergency declarations were made in Bell, Clay, Floyd, Knott, Knox, Leslie, Letcher, and Perry Counties, as well as for the city of Pineville, as numerous tributaries and the main stems of the Kentucky, Cumberland, and Levisa Fork of the Big Sandy Rivers exceeded bankfull.||Nearly 2,200 power outages were blamed on the widespread flooding, while thousands of boil water advisories were issued as shelters were opened to provide water. Several bridges were also inspected by engineers for structural integrity as the flood waters receded. A number of water rescues took place during the weekend and into Monday morning, including nearly half a dozen in and around Hazard. Hundreds of people were forced from their homes as river flooding along portions of the Kentucky and Cumberland Rivers continued well into the following week. In addition, the saturated ground led to several landslides and mudslides, including one along Kentucky Highway 74 near Middlesboro.||Maximum storm total rainfall amounts from various eastern Kentucky EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved up the western side of the Appalachians Tuesday night, February 6th into the morning hours of Wednesday, February 7th. Initially the precipitation started as snow across the upper Ohio Valley. As the warm air surged north, precipitation type changed to a wintry mix of sleet and freezing rain. Locations in northern West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania changed over to rain with temperatures climbing into the upper 30s to lower 40s. Eastern Ohio, the northern West Virginia Panhandle, and locations from central Beaver county, northeast into southern Jefferson county, Pennsylvania switched over to freezing rain. Ice accumulation was around a quarter of an inch for these places. Farther north along the I-80 corridor and parts of interior southeastern Ohio, cold air remained socked in, keeping the precipitation all snow. Several inches of snow fell with the highest amounts located across parts of northern Butler county northeast into Clarion, Jefferson, and Forest counties. For eastern Ohio, Columbiana, Carroll, southwest into Coshocton county around six inches of snow fell.

An early Spring storm moved out of the Rockies, swinging across Nebraska early on the morning of the 24th. Precipitation blossomed within the leading warm advection region, including a few thunderstorms across northwest Iowa during the evening of the 23rd, which transitioned from rain to snow lifting northeast across northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, starting as a brief period of rain, became moderate to briefly heavy by late evening on March 23 and into the early morning hours of March 24. Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, with snowfall accumulating to 3 to 6 inches, including 5.0 inches at Cherokee, 4.5 inches at Rock Rapids, 4.1 inches at Washta, and 4.0 inches at Orange City, Sioux Center and Holstein and 3.2 inches at Remsen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early Spring storm moved out of the Rockies, swinging across Nebraska early on the morning of the 24th. Precipitation blossomed within the leading warm advection region, including a few thunderstorms across northwest Iowa during the evening of the 23rd, which transitioned from rain to snow lifting northeast across northwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall, starting as a brief period of rain, became moderate to briefly heavy by late evening on March 23 and into the early morning hours of March 24. Visibility dropped to less than a mile at times, with snowfall accumulating to 3 to 6 inches, including 5.0 inches at Cherokee, 4.5 inches at Rock Rapids, 4.1 inches at Washta, and 4.0 inches at Orange City, Sioux Center and Holstein and 3.2 inches at Remsen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Orlando86 fire burned approximately 169 acres in Payne county on the 30th.
With a lack of rainfall, severe drought spread over the western two thirds of Oklahoma and extreme drought encroached upon much of western Oklahoma.
A significant winter storm entered the state on February 18, bringing heavy snowfall to both valley and mountain locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall in the Utah Valley included 20.5 inches in Santaquin, 16 inches in Elk Ridge, 13 inches in Mapleton, and 12 inches in Springville, Spanish Fork, and Payson. For the calendar day of February 19, Spanish Fork recorded 12 inches of snow, which broke the calendar day record of 10 inches, set in 2007.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture and strong surface heating led to scattered to numerous thunderstorms developing across the Florida Peninsula along sea breeze and outflow boundaries. One of these storms produced Nickel sized hail in southwest Florida.

Scattered thunderstorms developed across the Florida Peninsula during the afternoon and evening hours. A lightning strike from one of the storms caused a fire at an apartment building in Hillsborough County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media widely reported on a fire at a 3 story apartment complex that was believed to be started by a lightning strike. The fire caused major damage to the roof and top floor of the building, damaging 24 units and displacing around 100 residents. No injuries were reported from the fire.

CZ_NAME: ENGLEWOOD TO TARPON SPRINGS FL OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small line of showers formed near the mouth of the Tampa Bay shortly after sunrise at the intersection of a land breeze and an old outflow boundary. A couple of waterspouts were reported with the showers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports and pictures were received of a waterspout, or perhaps two waterspouts, offshore of Egmont Key and Bean Point of Anna Maria Island. The location of the waterspout was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep moisture and westerly winds allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop along the west coast of Florida during the early afternoon and push east through the afternoon and early evening. One of these storms produced damaging wind gusts. A lightning strike from another storm sparked a house fire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts were reported to have knocked down large tree limbs and to have damaged several awnings in Zephyrhills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought mixed wintry precipitation to the region. Precipitation began as snow during the morning hours but changed to a mix of sleet, freezing rain and snow during the afternoon hours, mixing as far north as the town of Schenectady. Precipitation transitioned back to snow during the evening hours before exiting the region northwest to southeast. Snowfall and sleet totals ranged from 1 inch to 12 inches, with the higher totals generally north and west of the Greater Capital District.

Low elevation snow caused significant travel problems as well as school delays and closures in the foothills. Snow also resulted in chain controls and travel slowdowns in the mountains. The snow continued into early March, bringing additional impacts.||Thunderstorms with large amounts of small hail blanketed portions of the Sacramento, causing major travel problems. Funnel clouds were also reported in the Sacramento area, but no tornado touchdowns observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported 14 of snow at Kingvale, with .85 liquid equivalent. Caltrans reported 20 of snow at Castle Peak. Chain controls and significant delays were experienced on mountain highways such as I80 and Highway 50. Kyburz had 4 of new snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low elevation snow caused significant travel problems as well as school delays and closures in the foothills. Snow also resulted in chain controls and travel slowdowns in the mountains. The snow continued into early March, bringing additional impacts.||Thunderstorms with large amounts of small hail blanketed portions of the Sacramento, causing major travel problems. Funnel clouds were also reported in the Sacramento area, but no tornado touchdowns observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weather spotter at Sims reported 3 of snow, elevation 2500 feet. A trace of snow was also reported at Lakehead, elevation 1600 feet. This caused minor delays on I5 and mountain roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ice jam remained in place on the Mohawk River for much of the month of February and was one of the biggest ice jam seen in decades, according to Union College professor John Garver. The ice jam stretched up to 17 miles from Rexford to Crane Hollow throughout the month in February. The ice jam mainly remained in place into late February and received a large amount of media and government attention. Albany County was concerned about impacts downstream if the jam were to give way quickly. Temperatures skyrocketing into the 60s and 70s on February 20-21 coupled with around 0.50-1.00 rainfall on the 19th over the Mohawk basin allowed river levels to rise and flooding occurred by the 21st within the Stockade neighborhood of Schenectady and across the river in Scotia, as well as backwater flooding of the Alplaus Kill. A substantial portion of the ice jam gave way during the early morning hours of the 22nd, leading to concern for flooding in the downstream communities, but it turned out that impacts were minimal. There were some road closures in the Rotterdam Junction and Schenectady area due to the ice jam movement and breakage. The remainder of the jam gradually broke up over the next week or so with little impact.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was backwater flooding along Alplaus Kill from the Mohawk River Ice Jam. Location was estimated.

Precipitation transitioned back to snow during the evening hours before exiting the region northwest to southeast. Snowfall and sleet totals ranged from 1 inch to 12 inches, with the higher totals generally north and west of the Greater Capital District.
